description:
A perfect place for date night!

We had a prix fixe 4 course meals and enjoyed all the dishes! The course includes cold appetizer, warm appetizer, entree and dessert. The server was very attentive and warm. The atmosphere was cute and lovely! My favorite part of the course was dessert because It was not overly sweet and just perfect. 

Great service, decent food and perfect dessert!
I'd highly recommend this place!
author: Clare L.

description:
I didnt see the hype.

My husband and I came 3 months ago, finally got the time to write my 2 cents.

So... they charge for bread and seasalted butter (god damn $5 for 4 slices of baguette, that's MORE than $1/slice)! And THAT tasted the best out of our main meals.

Ambiance was okay. Tables are a little too close for comfort, I can practically hear my neighbor's whole convo (unwillingly). And I'm sure they can ours.

I cant even remember what we ate, that's how UNMEMORABLE the food was. I just remember leaving still hungry and our bill was well over $230 for 2 people and mediocre food.

Overpriced because the food was not worth it, definitely wont be coming back again.

2 stars for nice staff, thasboutit.
author: Eva H.

description:
Came here to celebrate an anniversary, and we loved our meal! When we originally made the reservation they were still doing the 4 course tasting menu for $90, but they just recently changed the menu to be 7 courses for $135. We figured we'd splurge given we were celebrating and it does have a Michelin star. We were not disappointed! The restaurant is small and it has a subdued mellow feel to it, and they have an open kitchen which is awesome to see. The service was also excellent- they definitely do a good job of making your meal an experience. 

For food, we started with an amuse bouche of strawberries with a miso sauce. It was a perfect bite which set the tone for the meal. Each of the 7 following courses was delicious and had a nice smoky flavor tying them all together. Some of our favorites were the roja beans with whipped potatoes and egg yolk, the trout dish, and the frozen peach dessert. The house made sourdough bread with house made butter that comes with the bean dish really takes things to another level! Another nice touch was a couple of extras they threw into the meal- we got a rice milk sorbet as a palate cleanser before desert as well as a caramel and a truffle after dessert. We finished the meal with full stomachs and were impressed by the quality of all of the food. 

Only reason I didn't give 5 stars is the price point. The food is amazing, the atmosphere is lovely, and I'd definitely recommend coming here for a special occasion. There are other places with equally awesome food that are just a little better value for the price. Overall, I loved my meal here and would come back for the right occasion!
author: Rachel D.

description: It was ok. Some of the dishes missed the mark, and the beef, supposed to be the highlight of the meal, was honestly dry and chewy, and a bit over cooked.  Some dishes were great, but half were unimpressive. I would have like to see more tried and true flavor combinations come out, like with the oysters, maybe add some heat.  Service was great and the drinks were awesome, but not a great night for the menu.
author: Paul H.

description:
What an experience! My boyfriend and I walked in, unaware that they had a pre-fixe menu ($75 per person) and how lovely this place was going to be. We sat at the communal table, but were treated just as nice as the other patrons. The courses came on such a timely manner, and not once did we feel rushed or had to wait for a long time. The service was so professional and polite. 

For each course, we had 2-3 options, which was nice, since we wanted to order different things and try more of the dishes. My boyfriend's favorite was the cold summer squash soup (which I ordered!)-- he said that the flavors mixed so well together, which he didn't expect from reading the description on the menu. As for me, my favorite was the lemongrass custard (the dessert)-- omg, it was SO refreshing and it had grapefruit shaved ice and flower petals on top! It was soooo delicious. I couldn't stop thinking about it all night. I also really enjoyed the soft-boiled egg. I thought it had such fun textures going on (the crunch from the rice puffs, the gooeyness from the egg). The only con about eating that dish was getting seaweed strips stuck in my teeth! Haha. 

As for the wine... what a lovely selection. We really enjoyed the glasses we ordered (sorry, we forgot which!). Overall, we both highly recommend this place for an exceptional experience.
author: Christina W.

description:
Someone recommended this place for my husband when he asked for ideas for our 12th wedding anniversary dinner. Great choice!

We had a 6pm reservation and the restaurant was still almost empty, just one other couple was sitting there. Which made it strange that we were seated right next to them even there were multiple 2-tops available and my husband had mentioned when making the reservation that it was our anniversary. So it was a bit awkward start for our date (and their date :)).

They accommodated our dietary restrictions beautifully (I'm vegetarian, he lactose-intolerant), and our servers were very professional and informative about every dish that was brought to us (4 courses $75/pp). 

I mist admit it was one of the best meals I've had in a very long time. The flavors and combinations were just so unique! There were no long waits between the dishes either which was nice.

Our bill came to around $350 which was a bit shocking but we did have 3 glasses of wine between us two... Well, we only celebrate our 12th anniversary once so it was worth it.
author: Kat S.

description:
Aster's is definitely a place to come if you're looking for an intimate and romantic fine dining experience. The cost is about $75 pp for a 4 course pre-fixed menu (cold & warm appetizer, entree and dessert), in addition of +$48 pp for wine pairings for all the winos out there. I believe that their menu can change seasonally. The presentation of each dish was impeccable as the quality and flavors. We especially loved their sourdough bread with house made salted butter (Yes, it was that good to mention!) 

Parking-We ubered here from our place and recommend this. Parking is quite limited on the streets.
author: Grace Y.

description:
Sort of just average and not that cheap. It's cheap because other 1-Michelin star restaurants are charging over $100, but this place is charging $75 for 4 courses. But the food isn't that spectacular though, and the wait between courses is incredibly long, making the experience not that great. 

First course, I got the Dry Aged Beef (beef tartare). That was really good! Second dish, I got the soft boiled egg, which was probably the best dish out of my four courses. The portion was pretty small though. For my entree (third course), I got the trout, which looked a lot like salmon. This was really nothing special at all. You can get this at pretty much any restaurant. It didn't taste bad, but I was pretty disappointed at how unremarkable it was. Dessert (fourth course) was the caramel/chocolate. This was a big portion, probably too big and too sweet, considering how small the other dishes were, and felt sort of overwhelming. 

The server told us about the specials: caviar and truffles, but didn't tell us the price, which wasn't very nice. 

The wait was too long. An hour after we were seated, we only got one course! Unacceptable. Service is way too slow for a Michelin starred restaurant. There were no "snacks" or complimentary treats between the courses. We also had to sit at a communal table, where you can hear every word of your neighbors' conversation. Not a very pleasant dining experience. The upside is, the wait staff were all very pleasant and friendly. Water was very very promptly refilled. 

However, for the price, the long wait between courses, and too crowded dining atmosphere, I would not recommend this place. I can you can pay a tad more to eat much better food at similar-caliber restaurants.
author: Jennifer W.

description: My boyfriend took me here for my birthday and we had a lovely experience. We went with the dinner and wine pairing which turned out to be a great choice. The wine pairing was like a mini tasting that complimented our 7 course meal. Every dish was very rich in flavor and despite the small servings, we were full after. The whole dining experience was about 3 hours. The waitress/sommelier was very sweet and personable. The atmosphere is pretty casual although I dressed up a bit because it was my birthday :)
author: Candice H.

description:
Aster has been on my list to try for quite a while, but we never got around to it even though it's only one block away. Finally decided to try it out for my fiance's birthday.

Personally, I felt the tasting menu was just okay. The service was amazing, food was solid, but for a 1-star Michelin restaurant, I had higher expectations of the overall experience.

* Grilled Gems - solid, but not much wow factor
* Dry aged beef - my favorite dish of the night. The uni was fresh and beef tartare was well-prepared
* Morel - fiance liked this dish, but I thought it was a little one-note
* Soft cooked egg - loved the blend of flavors and egg on egg
* Trout with spring onion-miso broth, summer squash, ramps - perfectly cooked, but could've used a little more textural elements in the dish
* Pork - fiance also liked this dish, but thought it was a bit salty and on the small side
* Dessert - both very good (we tried the macadamia cake and strawberry)
author: Vivian H.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night and was really happy with the excellent food, service and ambiance.  This place is a four course prix fixe (a very reasonably priced $75 for a Michelin-starred restaurant) where you choose among a cold appetizer, warm appetizer, entree and dessert.  I went with the server's recommendation and they were great. 

Cold appetizer - beef tartare with umeboshi, brown rice crisp and kimchi furikake
Warm appetizer - soft-cooked egg with nori, puffed rice, bacon and smoked trout roe 
Entree - Trout with black garlic mole, chard, oro blanco.  The trout skin chip is a really nice touch too. 
Dessert - Smoked Caramel with bitter chocolate, sour orange and vanilla

I also ordered the sourdough bread with house cultured butter (in my opinion, they should just increase the prix fixe price and include this in the meal. It's really that good) and the ginger beer.  Every single dish was excellent. The standout was definitely the soft-cooked egg. Highly recommended.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Chef Brett was one of the invitees at the Maui Chef Invitational at the Mill House earlier this year and the beau and I were able to try his amazing croquette. We stopped by Aster based on this alone, but it was a pleasant surprise this also had one Michelin star. 

We arrived when they opened and the host was very good. The server seemed off for a restaurant of this caliber, maybe because she was starting the night. We had to ask a lot of questions and she seemed a little rushed, though no one had arrived yet besides us and a table of three. The menu is a tasting menu where each person picks a dish for four courses. I chose the delicata squash, mushrooms, trout and pink lady apple. All of the dishes were excellent, the trout was my favorite. We also added on a cheese course with our dessert that was exquisite. I recommend the beverage pairing which had some really great selections, including a number of sparkling wines. In fact, my beau got three sparkling wines with his four courses, a very unique selection.

The atmosphere is comfortable. The service was quite good. I would be glad to return in a different season and try another menu.
author: Ryan L.

description: Wonderful place for a special night.  The food was amazing and the service was top-notch.  The meal was perfectly paced.  The feeling is very intimate even thought the dining room isn't too small.
author: Carmin N.

description: We had a delicious meal here!!!  Came for my husband's birthday and they did not disappoint!  It's a four course tasting menu. Everything I had was divine!  We did the wine pairing as well and they absolutely nailed it. Would highly recommend!!!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
This is one of the better prix fixe options I've had, especially at a price point lower than most others.  It's 4 courses but you get to choose from 4 different categories so you do get some options (pro-tip - definitely opt for the house made sourdough as the bread is really fresh and the butter so salty and creamy).  The menu changes I believe but some quick notes on what I had (3/23/18):

- Dry Aged Beef 3.5/5 - Essentially a beef tartare with a brown rice crisp.  Good but nothing special and could have used a tad more seasoning.

- Soft Cooked Egg 3/5 - This dish sounded great in description but it was very salty and a bit one note.

- Duck 5/5 - This is where the meal really picked up as both entrees I tried were great.  The duck was cooked perfectly and paired with delicious greens.  To top things off there were also a pair of duck confit fritters!

- Trout 4.5/5 - I personally love trout and this was a great version.  The filet was cooked perfectly and the skin crisped expertly.  

Desserts 4.5/5 - I forget the specifics but one dessert was a sort of brittle atop a buttermilk sorbet and the other was a tart fruit sorbet with lots of goodies mixed in (sliced kumquat for sure but I forget the others) 

In a sea of New American restaurants in SF I'd recommend this as definitely worth a try!
author: Aaron K.

description:
Review is long overdue but I have to say what was memorable was the service, or lack of. Came here for a girlfriend's birthday and the waiter we had was incredibly rude. Any time we would ask for something, he either had a passive aggressive response or just kind of snapped at us. From suggesting where the birthday girl should sit, to a matter of items on the menu, every single reply was rude. I get it, I have days at work where I am just over it but I think that to be successful in a service industry, you just have power through. 

Food was okay and of decent quality for the price. I would not come back again but Aster was a decent restaurant to try. We all ordered the tasting menu (as you can see from the pictures I've posted) but nothing was outstanding or super memorable. 

Edit: the pictures aren't auto-linking to my review.. but you should be able to click left and right to see all the pictures. 

https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=F9kK0daeZiXH6K6v8i3Vgg&userid=OKMrqnNwDCflvNXqBDcRCg
author: Denise L.

description:
Originally had plans to celebration my fiance's birthday here and made reservations two months in advance. I just received a call regarding the increase of Aster's tasting menu from $85 to $135 pp. While I appreciate Aster in reaching out to it's current reservations to let everyone know, it is unfortunate that it wasn't announced in advanced so that their potential patrons could locate alternatives ahead of time that is within their budget. Now it'll be tough to make reservations for the next 1.5 weeks with other quality restaurants looking at how popular places fill up quickly.

Unfortunately, the drastic price increase is out of my intended budget and we will not be trying this place out. If I had wanted to spend that much, I would've booked Sons & Daughters or Lazy Bear for just a little more.
author: Rosanna N.

description:
4.5 stars rounding down to 4. I give 5 stars for mind-blowing experiences. 

Came here on Saturday for a dinner date with the boyfie. We actually made reservations the morning of and we were lucky enough to reserve the 5:30pm slot. Aster offers a four course tasting ($75/pp) menu with the option of wine pairing ($48/pp) or reserved wine pairing ($98/pp). We opted for the tasting w/ wine pairing.

Ordered between the two of us:
x SOURDOUGH, house cultured butter ($5) - Must order. The bread is sOOOO good and the butter is divine. 5/5
x GRILLED GEMS buttermilk ranch, milk bread, fennel, bottarga - Nothing spectacular, but it wasn't bad at all. Just a decent salad. 4/5
x DRY AGED BEEF umeboshi, brown rice crisp, kimchi furikake - This was super delicious! Love all the textures and flavors in this dish. 5/5
x CHILLED SUNCHOKE SOUP pohas, kohlrabi, walnut, berbere - Flavors were good, but it was TOO chilled in my opinion. The sake pairing with this put me off as well. Didn't think it went well together :( 2/5
x SOFT-COOKED EGG nori, puffed rice, bacon, smoked trout roe - Favorite of the night. Super yummy and fun textures in the mouth. Beautiful presentation. Must order! 5/5
x TROUT black garlic mole chard, black trumpet, oro blanco - The boyfie really like this one, but I didn't find anything very special about it. Pretty, though :) 3.5/5
x DUCK tatsoi rabe green garlic, vadouvan - I usually hate duck, but this one was SOOO good. I actually ended up eating 90% of it :) The wine pairing with this was fab as well. 5/5
x LEMONGRASS CUSTARD blood orange, mandarin, cocoa nib - SOOO good and refreshing. Just what we needed after the meal. This is a very light dessert. Highly recommend if you aren't huge on desserts. 5/5
x SUNFLOWER PAIN D'ÉPICES pumpkin, ginger, buttermilk - I call this, deconstructed pumpkin pie! Not my favorite, but I'm also not huge on desserts. 3.5/5

The wine pairing was just OK in my opinion. They always are. I really did enjoy my meal here, though. It's a culinary experience and everything was so visually appealing. I would come back if the menu changes :) Definitely worth a visit and well worth the price/star. Bravo, Aster.
author: Anna M.

description:
If I could give Aster a 4.5, I would. I would also gander that Aster provides one of the most affordable Michelin star tasting menus in the city at $75 per person.

When you first see the menu, one of the things that pops up is "whattttt $5 for bread??" But like other reviews affirm, it's totally worth it.  The sourdough was warm and fluffy- definitely might be the best sourdough I've ever had.

The appetizers at Aster were the star of the show, while we found the entrees good, but uninspired. So that we could maximize our tasting potential, my husband and I ordered different things and split every course.

Course 1: dry aged beef tartare with rice puffs and a market salad.  Both were freaking amazing. The tartare was in tiny cubes topped with aioli and it just melted in your mouth. The rice puffs provided a nice crunchy contrast. When I first saw the market salad, my first thoughts were meh, salad, how boring. This salad, however, was super unique and unlike any other salad I've had. The fruits provided a sweet crispness, but there was also a strong umami flavor and sesame seeds. Who knew salads could be so fancy???

Course 2: slow cooked egg and rye spaetzle - you really can't go wrong with a slow cooked egg, honestly.  As expected it was deliciously creamy and well balanced with the things it was served with.  The spaetzle was the pleasant surprise.  My only encounters with spaetzle has been with a typically German preparation. The spaetzle was crispy on the outside and light and fluffy on the inside- it really gives a whole new meaning to spaetzle for me. Highly recommend 

Course 3: lamb 3 ways and the trout - this is where our dinner became a little more normal. The lamb 3 ways was definitely the winner. The lamb was juicy and moist, but not a revelation like our other courses. The trout, unfortunately, is the reason for the drop in the star. The flavors were nice and rich, but unevenly distributed over the trout, and it was slightly over cooked.  Nothing makes me sadder than overcooked fish :(

Course 4: an amuse-bouche if you will... since it was our anniversary, they brought us out a rice gelato with umeboshi. It's a really interesting combination of super salty and sour with the umeboshi balanced with the sweetness of the gelato. I'm not sure I crave it, but it sure did take my taste buds on an interesting trip.

Course 5: dessert!!!! Strawberry 3 ways and chocolate custard - the strawberry was super light and refreshing, with lots of floral hints. On the other end, the chocolate custard was creamy and rich. And they were topped with coconut mochis which I love! The desserts were a win for us!
author: Jenny C.

description:
Aster was deceitful 
I've been a regular client and they even know me when i call for a reservation.  They should have told me that they went from $69/pp fixed menu (which was first increased to $85) to $135 in one shot.  This isn't a price adjustment for inflation, you need to warn us.  I am also not a fan of 7 course menu, Aster was a great casual affordable option, now the dinner had to drag artificially for two hours 

Moreso, I am convinced the food was actually worse than before:  I used to love the bowl which had salmon roe and crunchy stuff and it was replaced with an egg and some average sauce

Finally, even attitude wise, they didn't accept my cancelation...which they used to many times in the past.  This time they explained that they ordered the ingredients 48 hours in advance. As if they had to put an attitude of a $200/pp restaurant.
They told me I had to show up at a given time before losing the table, yet when I arrived there were many open seats.  

In conclusion, it's become extremely expensive for the same food at best and with an attitude.  
Adios, my last time here after 2-3 years we preaching it was my favorite.

Note; they canceled the brunches and even on a Saturday night they were not full.  I predict a downhill from here.
author: Nick T.

description:
I went to this place with the simple expectation of good food and good wine. What a disappointment. How can this place have one Michelin star?!

Let's start with the setting: urban and young might be appealing to the San Francisco youngsters with money, but that is not what I want for fine dining. I don't care about the conversations of my neighbors, and I wish the place were quieter and more intimate.

Now, the real topic: the food. We had the fixed 4 course dinner with wine pairing. It was overall a flatliner, with a single spark and a complete downer. I had the aged beef for starter, and it was just fine. Nothing special about it. My dining partner had the carrots, and I have never seen a sadder plate: a few carrots with hints of condiments that you'd hope would enhance the experience. Alas it didn't. My dish was paired with a prosecco, which I found rather odd.

We then moved to the second course. We both picked the egg, and that was the highlight of the evening. Not only was the dish delicious, it was interestingly paired with a sake, and that was a good experience. I wish the overall dinner had the same level of taste and sophistication.

I then moved to the third course, the pork. It was good, nicely paired with a dry red wine from Italy. My dinner partner however, picked the trout. Not her lucky day, as it was another meh. It looked like salmon with lipstick, and tasted like it. Her white wine from Portugal was better than her dish.

And then we both finished with the same dessert, the so-called bitter chocolate. How do you spell bitter in this place? It was so sweet that we didn't finish it. It was cheap, childish, and a complete downer. What a punishment on the taste buds!

Time to exit, the bill is $400. This is a joke. I know better places for less than half the price. Keep your money and enjoy other restaurants.
author: Olivier C.

description:
I took my fiancee here after recently getting engaged. The food here was excellent. We were impressed with every dish with the creativity, plating, flavor profiles and variety of food. The service was excellent as they were always checking in and asking for feedback.

I found that the restaurant was pleasing to be in. I was seated at the large long table with my fiancee. I would have preferred a booth or side table but it was still fun to be around others and enjoy almost a communal styled evening. 

Aster, as of right now has a 7 course tasting menu. I was pretty disappointed not by the menu but how they performed the transition from a Prix fix to a tasting menu. I was notificed just 1 week in advance about this switch from a 95$ four course Prix fix to a 135$ Prix fix. This put me in a spot where I had to swallow the extra 80$ I will be spending on this meal as getting a reservation elsewhere was practically impossible. I would have preferred a better handling of this transition as I chose aster over other Michelin star restaurants due to the simplicity of choice and the price being slightly less than other places. Possibly a reduced price tasting menu for those who booked before the switch. We did receive dishes we didn't expect but I was still miffed about the whole switch.

Warning: if you do not like certain elements of a dish whether it be lamb, raw fish or have issues with a certain food you may need to consult the restaurant. One of the courses did include a lamb chop that I know is not exactly favored amongst some people. Consult the menu before coming. Luckily, my fiancee and I are not picky and enjoyed all of the dishes provided.

Overall, I had an enjoyable night with my new fiancee. Aster was very nice and did make the right feel special with unique food and a small and intimate environment. I didn't exactly leave full and I would he hard pressed to come back until I've tried all of the other places such as Gary Danko, Michael Mina and more. I'm glad I tried this place and for those who would like to have an enjoyable night consider Aster.
author: Brian H.

description:
My favorite new restaurant in San Francisco. An almost perfect meal -- so really a 4.5 star. 

Every dish was beautifully and artfully prepared (hello Michelin star rating). The way the ingredients played off each other -- every bite was a wonderful exploration of flavors and textures. My favorites were the dry aged beef, the duck (heavenly), and the lemongrass custard. 

Service was wonderful. Friendly, warm, and knowledgable. I can't wait to return.
author: Jeanie S.

description:
Umm, IMO this was not a Michelin star worthy restaurant based on tonight's tasting menu. Food, service or otherwise. 

Let's start with the service. It was a bit strange. I couldn't tell if our server was either bored or didn't care. To be a Michelin star rated restaurant, I was expecting a whole lot more energy and/or knowledge than our server was providing. Also, it was unclear if the person standing behind her was training or just helping. She never introduced him and it made for a very awkward experience. Other than collecting our food/cleaning the table, we were never asked how the dishes were. 

As for the food, it was very different. I'm not going to say I fully understood the menu. TBH, my meat-eating friend said his four course menu was superb. But from more pescetarian POV, the seafood and vegetarian dishes were mediocre at best. The server advised that a SB uni could be added onto any dish. I LOVE me some uni and was expecting a dish married and interwoven w flavors when it arrived. Sadly, they laid ONE piece of uni atop my squid app for an additional 8 bucks (really 10+ after tax and tip). Was that worth the add? Uh, no. The remainder of my dishes were okkkk. Let's just skip to the dessert portion. I honestly cannot even describe to you what it was except that it wasn't good. It looked like tofu slices with cheese on the side. I mean, it was goats milk with what was supposedly a cake mixed w coco nibs. Was it? No. Omg I couldn't even eat a quarter of it. 

When the server finally came around to collect the dishes, she didn't even ask why I didn't finish or if it was okay. She just said finished? Before I could say more than a half yes, she already grabbed the plate to go. My friend and I were treating another friend for his bday...total btw two ppl came out to 190+ each. Was it worth it? Not even close. Pretty disappointed by the entire experience. Esp bc the bday boy said this was one of his fav restaurants in the city...even he said the menu was a let down tonight. 

Though I will end it w them acknowledging my OpenTable note about it being my friends bday. And bringing out a special sorbet for him. Props for that, but likely won't be returning...3 stars
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Besides some serious quality control issues, the food is extremely good. No cocktail menu available.

The rabe in the duck course had a strong ammonia scent and taste. The wine glass served wasn't cleaned so there was lots of dust and hair floating in the wine. Lastly they clean off the table in between courses with a damp rag that leaves the whole table feeling wet, which I personally don't like. I'm easy going and very very rarely have service complains, so these three issues really stood out compared to other restaurants.

The food itself was extremely good - one of the best restaurants I've been to. I got the Dry aged beef tartare, the soft cooked egg, the duck, and the smoked caramel.
author: Lucas D.

description:
Can I say that their bread might be better than tartines and acme? In love with their bread and butter, its amazing! My only compliant is that bread was not complimentary, but only cost $5. I understand why they do charge because it would be nonstop request for free bread. I highly recommend ordering the bread. 

It's was one of my birthday stops with my best friend. Dinner experience was very good. Not every dish was amazing but every course had at least one delicious dishes that made this a good experience. 

Between MCFARLAND SPRING TROUT and DRY AGED BEEF, the winner was the beef. The flavors were all there, very tasty. Love the brown rice crisp for the added texture. 

My best friend and I have a different favorite between POTATO DUMPLINGS, SOFT-COOKED EGG  and the OCTOPUS. Second course was definitely our favorite. The egg was cook to perfection, paired great with nori, puffed rice, bacon, smoked trout roe. I really like the dumplings because it was not too heavy and not too chewy. It was delicious.  

The DUCK beat out the HALIBUT. Halibut is on the lighter side. I feel like it needs more flavor. But the duck was great, especially the sweet kumquat. My taste buds love this dish.  

CHOCOLATE CUSTARD vs STRAWBERRY. We love the strawberry because it was the perfect ending to our dinner. Very light, refreshing and not too sweet. I think the lemon and sesame was the perfect touch to this dessert. 

Service was great and love the open kitchen. Very rustic, home decor.
author: Sandy B.

description:
I was drawn to Aster by their affordable 4 course tasting menu (crazy how $65 in the Bay Area is "affordable"....) so I decided this would be a nice place to celebrate our anniversary. 

Reservations were really easy to make online. The day before our reservation, the restaurant called to confirm and also informed us that they now only offer the 4 course tasting menu (as opposed to having a la carte) and the price is now $75. Womp. 

The restaurant itself isn't that big, with a few two tops, booths and a large communal table in the middle. We were seated at a booth near the kitchen. 

We started with the sourdough bread and butter ($5). The bread was soft and tasty, but I didn't find it to be mind blowing. But if you're starving it's a good thing to get your appetite ready. 

We ordered the following : 

Dry aged beef: I don't eat beef so this was all on the BF. He didn't like it at all. He said there was a strong lemony taste that overpowered the beef. The cracker was good! 

Market Greens: since I don't eat beef, I was disappointed that one of my courses would be a salad. I enjoy salads, but don't necessarily think they're worth ordering at an upscale restaurant. BUT THIS SALAD WAS GOOOOOOD. Tons of flavors and depth. BF is anti-salad and he agreed that this was tasty! 

Squid: tender, cooked perfectly. Just wish there was more!! 

Rye and morel spaetzle: we loveee spaetzle. My family lives in Germany so we're no stranger to the dish, but this was a pleasant twist!! The morels make it meaty and savory. This dish is a must get!! 


Trout: the trout was cooked medium rare, which is fine for us. Skin was crispy! And the miso dashi was delicious. Overall, a light dish but still was flavorful. 


Duck: NOMMMM. Another standout dish. BF usually isn't a fan of duck breast, but really enjoyed this one. Skin was crispy and the meat was tender, not chewy. Then you get a bit of the duck confit on the side which was DELICIOUSSSS. 

Cocoa nib financier: interesting dish. More savory due to the goat cheese foam, so order this if you're not a fan of sweets. 

Chocolate custard: this dish isn't the prettiest lol, just a lot of brown and not a fan of the shape. But the taste was amazing!!! The perfect sweet ending to our dinner! 

We received an anniversary dessert which was light and refreshing. 

Service was friendly and spot on. Water was constantly refilled and tables were cleared and reset after each course.
author: Noelle H.

description:
OH MY GOD I SAW MY LIFE IDOL KEVIN ROSE HERE. Literally almost died. I watched him check in and sit in the booth across from me and basically reverted to my 18 year old self. Was basically swooning over him from afar all night like a crazy person. My date was not amused. 

Came here on a Monday night for a birthday dinner. The restaurant was never full and there was only one couple on the communal table the entire night. Refused to give us a booth but Kevin Rose got one ahem ahem. Some people just live in the light. 

I don't know why there are so many negative reviews regarding the service because everyone was super friendly and nice. I am a huge stickler for service too and I had zero issues. 

The 4 course menu was $75 and my date got the wine pairing and I just ate edibles because I couldn't drink and then I got way too high and was paranoid I looked super high but apparently I looked fine. The wine pairing is a way better deal than any of the wines they have on their menu too. We also got the sour dough bread but only because everyone on here was raving about it and I actually do not think I would order it again, especially because I was crazy full by the end of the meal. They also had a special uni addition that my date added to one of his appetizers. 

We got the same entree and I freaking hate doing that and GUESS WHAT both our entrees were so freaking salty. It was a weird salty/sour thing though so not sure if it was supposed to be like that but otherwise it was tasty. The appetizers were all good and my dessert was horrendous I cannot believe they even served such a thing. Abort abort. It was so dry and not tasty and I had to hijack my dates dessert because it was way prettier and yummier. We also got an additional dessert with candle and errythang because it was his birthday, sweet! 

Definitely the most reasonably priced Michelin restaurant I have ever been to and they literally just increased their prices too so probably better to get on it now before they increase it again.
author: Tiffany V.

description:
This review is specifically for brunch. The restaurant is small and cozy, with an open concept kitchen. We came with a party of 5 and I felt the seating got to be a little crammed and awkward. This place seemed more fitting for a one on one date. 

I would recommend ordering their drip coffee and also their mimosas. For food I had a smoked salmon dish on a toast with avocado spread. The greens they used were very interesting and fresh, which helped balance the strong taste of the smoky salmon. Definitely an enjoyable brunch, and I'd like to see their dinner experience in the future.
author: Angus L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here for my birthday dinner. I was a littler nervous because we made the reservation and then I was reading some nasty Yelp reviews about service. I can definitely say our service experience was far better than what I've read. Our server was very attentive and apologized if he felt as though something took too long. 

Aster is now only a 4 course tasting menu. Here's what I chose:

Dry aged beef tartar
Squid
Trout
Chocolate Custard
+Wine pairing

Everything we ordered we enjoyed. for the 2nd course, my boyfriend got the morel and rye spaetzle. His only complaint was this dish filled him up too much (is that really a complaint though??)

Only other con is they charge $5 for 4 pieces of sourdough. I mean, I get it, it's delicious home made sourdough. However, when you're already paying for a fixed menu, I feel as though they could give you the bread for free. Just saying :-)

 Oh! they also gave me a scoop of ice cream with a candle for my birthday and thankfully no singing. That was sweet. :-)
author: Katlyn H.

description:
Aster was a remarkable experience. A small, intimate space where the focus is entirely on beautifully crafted dishes. The service was seamless. The prix fixe dishes were inventive, colorful, and delicious. I chose a salad, chilled soup,  trout and a delightful custard desert. Expect beautiful plating featuring edible flowers and unique flavors and textures. 

I loved the experience and would easily give Aster 5 stars except for that we booked almost a month in advance but were seated at the communal table. That said the restaurant did give us complementary sparkling rose'. Aside from that misstep, we loved the experience.
author: Arijit P.

description:
3.7? Tasty and good sized portions for a tasting menu, clean, pleasant atmosphere -- but wasn't wow'd by their drink pairing. It was nice that they had a drink pairing per menu item but some of the pairs didn't make much sense to me...they included a lot of sparkling drinks and a dessert wine (which personally is always too sweet for me).

(Good to know -- They included a good variety of options to choose from their menu for both the herbivores and carnivores of the group!)

Beef tartar (added uni on top) -- yum. It was topped by this tasty crispy chip layer. 

Soft egg -- surprised it had a very Japanese essence to it. Good. 

Hen -- juicy, tender, satisfying! Cauliflower purée was a little strong, but the Brussels sprouts were spot on. 

Trout -- perfectly cooked. Very flavorful. Nothing too mind boggling but solid. 

All the desserts were great :)
author: Juliet K.

description:
This review is for my dining experience from 11/2017

Aster is one of the more affordable Michelin star restaurants in SF after doing some research

The staff called me the day before my reservation to confirm my reservation and to ask about any dietary considerations or special occasions for the reservation. Since it was a special occasion they said they would do their best to get us a private table  (they have a communal table in the center of the restaurant)

We arrived around 10 minutes before our reservation and we were quickly seated

The staff was attentive, polite, and considerate - all the good things you'd expect from a Michelin star restaurant 

*Pro Tip Alert*
If you're eating here with a guest pick different dishes for each course and share. The portions are substantial enough to share and still enjoy enough of each dish. Doing this will allow you to try almost everything on the menu!

Here's what we had:
Sourdough bread - this is a must have!
Trout belly appetizer - yes
Market greens - yes
Dry aged beef tartar
Soft cooked egg 
Chanterelle mushrooms
Trout
Hen sausage - yes
Strawberry dessert
Chocolate mousse dessert - this is a must have!

Since it was a special occasion they gave us a small sorbet dessert :)

Expect to pay $150+ for 2 people. Overall a really good 1 Michelin star experience for a special occasion at a relatively good price
author: Will Y.

description:
Interior - Laid back and casual for a Michelin restaurant. 

Four Course Menu - $75/person with 3 choices in each section. So many options and so much to share between you and your date. 

Dietary Restrictions - Despite making reservations and informing them ahead of time of being pescatarian/vegan, the service refused to accommodate. My waitress didn't even tell the kitchen to make alterations in the menu despite promising me that she would. Bummer. 

Sourdough - Extra $5. Bread was moist and fresh. Never had this texture before. Not sure if it was worth $5. Save your stomach for the meal. Asked for the rest to go. They didn't pack the butter that came with the dish. 

Delicata Squash - Refreshing, sweet, light. Probably my favorite dish. 

Dry Aged Beef - Beef tartare eaten with light crispy chips. Good, cold, and savory. 

Soft-Cooked Egg - Stir the egg in rice, bacon, and smoked trout roe. Comforting, nostalgic, and light. 

Chanterelle - The dressing is on the bottom. The top looked like a vine forest. Artistic and savory. 

Trout - Cooked very well. Overwhelmed by how much sauce was on the fish. It doesn't need any sauce at all. 

Hen - Also too much sauce. Took away from the savory flavors and textures. 

Frozen Yogurt - Nice, sweet, comforting finish. 

Chocolate - Was told twice to change my menu options so I pick a dessert without dairy. It still came out with dairy. Looked like poop but it was good. 

Pacing - Good. Our meal started around 9:45pm and we were out by 11:30pm. 

Overall, despite my preferences, the food was objectively Michelin-worthy. I wished they accommodated my dietary preferences. Why would you make a section for special requests if you can't honor those requests? Why would make me  change my selection because you promised me you can modify it and then you don't? Why bother promising me anything at all?
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
My dearest hubby took me here along with our friends as an early birthday dinner. I didn't realize that this place has a Michelin star! So knowing that coming in for dinner, I had my expectations set high.

This restaurant is very cute, modern and intimate. As we walked in, we were greeted by the hostess and seated promptly. We ordered the the sourdough and house special butter first. Who would have thought that such a simple bread and butter will be such a nice way to start the rest of our meals. The butter was smokey and had an umami flavor that set it apart from other bread and butter starters I've had from other places.

We all opted to get the four course tasting menu and we made sure to order different plates for each course to maximize on the opportunity to try as much as we can. 

First Course - DRY AGED BEEF

Oh my! This dish was just spectacular! From the dry aged beef, brown rice crisp to the uni - everything was in harmony. The pickled plum gave the dish a nice touch of brightness. The uni was a very good addition, creamy and salty to round out all the flavors.

Second Course - SOFT-COOKED EGG

Much like the first course, this one was an awesome dish as well. The addition of puffed rice with the soft cooked egg was just enough to make sure textures are balanced. Even with the bacon and salmon roe combination, the dish was not overly salty but instead worked in tandem.

Third Course - PORK

That pork dish was just delish! It wasn't dry and the pork flavor really stands out. It was paired with brussel sprouts and sweet grapes. The addition of grapes was unexpected but was a good one. 

Fourth Course - FROZEN CHOCOLATE

To my fellow chocolate lovers, this is the dessert to get for sure!! It's their version of a frozen chocolate. The block of chocolate in the center was bittersweet which was paired perfectly with the huckleberry compote. For crunchy element, the meringue and cacao nib crumble were an awesome touch. 

Our whole table really enjoyed all the dishes that night. Service was attentive. Our water glasses were always full, plates and silverware cleared out after each course. The tasting menu was reasonably priced for the amount and quality of food we got. I wouldn't mind coming back again here next time we're in the city. Definitely worth checking them out!
author: Patricia A.

description:
Aster has a tasting menu so amazingly crafted, well balanced, well planned and well executed. The flavors were impressive, the presentation was perfect and the colors looked so beautiful. Also, their tasting menu is  one of the most affordable multi course tasting menus ($65)

The boyfriend and I were in the bay for our culinary and wine tour post his PhD graduation. And Aster was one of our stars in our celebration! 

We made a booking in advance and our table was ready when we arrived. The parking is tight so plan to arrive a little early.

We did the tasting menu with the wine pairing. We both got different dishes so we could try a lot more. The "BEETROOT SALAD" was just perfect. The beets had a sort of crunch but softness at the same, which made the texture interesting. We also got the "HEIRLOOM CARROT, PISTACHIO, YOGURT, GOLDEN RAISIN"- beautiful colors! the flavors played on your tongue, making it a well balanced, yum dish. "POTATO DUMPLINGS, BLACK TRUMPET, CAULIFLOWER, PINE NUT, SAGE" very well crafted dish. You could taste every element, feel different textures and the flavors were bang on. The black trumpet, the sage and the pine nuts elevated potatoes from ordinary to extraordinary. The perfect cooked cauliflower only added to the flavor. The "TROUT, ARTICHOKE, SHELLING BEANS, ORO BLANCO, PRESERVED MEYER LEMON" was one of the best cooked fishes I have ever had. Fresh too!

The desserts were decadent and devilishly delicious. designer and divine. They surprised us with Lemon Sorbet with Fig! They gave this as a congratulations complimentary dessert for the boyfriend. Minimalistic and tarty. Personally, I am not a big fan of tarty stuff, but the fig balanced the taste and it was perfect otherwise. We also had "FROZEN CHOCOLATE, HUCKLEBERRY, BOURBON MERINGUE" so rich and chocolate-y and well-balanced sweetness and indulgent!

Our experience here was wonderful. From the cute decor of this place to the polite, professional and sweet hostess to the romantic ambience and a great tasting menu, we had a great time and we will be back here when in Bay!
author: Megha U.

description: We were given a gift certificate over a year ago and finally decided to use it. While the food was really delicious, the price increase over the last year is simply outrageous. Many of the courses were great, but one or two left something to be desired and for $135 a plate that's unacceptable. Plus the level of service just didn't meet the price tag. No one took my coat or bag. They seated us next to a terribly obnoxious and loud party when the restaurant was mostly empty. I won't be returning nor recommending to friends.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
It's a fun place - definitely $$$ - but if you go in prepared to spend, then it's all good. 

Really nice presentation on all the dishes, and generally pretty flavorful and creative food. 

How it works:

They have a tasting menu with four sections with four options. You can order anything Ala carte, or if your entire table chooses to do so, you can get a tasting menu - with one item from each four sections - for $65. Each person gets to choose the dish they want from each section, so if you have a group of four and want to try a lot of things, you actually could try everything for $65 per person. We didn't get all the things, because well, some didn't really appeal, but we got a lot of them (13 of the 16) and for the most part were pretty impressed.  

They also do wine parings for $42 a person. I was impressed by this because they actually pair a wine with every dish. And like I said, we got a lot of different dishes and each one came with a different wine, and they kept them straight and remembered which was which. Also, they were unique wines. A few from grapes I had never heard of! So that was fun to just try some new wines. It seemed like they had really put time and effort into their wine selection.

Best dish of the night in my opinion was the duck. It was just really really perfectly cooked, and the sauce that came with it was light enough to not over power, but still flavorful. I also thought that the Halibut was extremely good. Not over cooked at all and the miso dashi complemented it very well. 

The soft cooked egg was also very flavorful.  That whole dish came together very nicely and was very rich. 

The asparagus, soft cooked egg, and potato dumplings all smelled amazing. 

The homemade sourdough was solid (which is very important coming from a bread nerd) and the homemade butter was super good. 

Really all in all, the food was all around well done. 

The only dish that we didn't really like was the Green Farro, it just sorta had an off taste. 

I was really happy they had a cheese option for the fourth course. I'm just not a sweet desert person and I'm usually sad when it comes to the last course - but not this time. 

Service was prompt, but not too prompt.  We enjoyed our 7 - 9 dining experience, and didn't feel rushed or that we waited an exorbitant amount of time. Maybe a bit slow on the first course? But not really. They did the thing where they had multiple people deliver the food and clear plates so that it was a seamless process (that's fancy!). 

Relatively small space, so felt intimate. Would be a great place for a fancy date, although about 1/3 of their seating is at the community table, so don't go expecting it to be too intimate, because you might be sat at that table. Nice big windows by the street - we got one of those seats which I was excited about - because I love light - and it was on the darker side near the back (although they do have an open kitchen, so if you sat back there you could watch the chefs at work!).
author: Sarah C.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review, rounded up to 4 because holy hell that $5 bread is maybe the best bread I've ever eaten.

Aster is a four-course tasting menu where you select each of your courses, and I made all the wrong selections. My husband made all the right selections, so I was able to taste what Aster is capable of. I just figure if there is one best choice, they should only offer that choice so you don't lead yourself astray!

I had... the market greens (a little too much fennel), soft-cooked egg (sort of just tasted like a bowl of crunch), the lamb (way too rich... I couldn't even eat it all and I was still a bit hungry), and the strawberry (which basically tasted like strawberry shaved ice).

My husband had... the cucumber (perfectly balanced), the mutsutake (not what he was expecting but delightful), trout (delicious), and the chocolate custard. 

Get my husband's menu. Not mine.

And definitely definitely definitely get the bread. I'd come back just for the bread. (It's better than Manresa's, and Manresa has it's own bread shop!)
author: Megan B.

description:
Been wanting to come here for years and it did not disappoint.

Loved the flexibility of the four course menu, gives the diner a chance be an individual and taste your companion's selections.  It was like we had an 8 course meal but with bigger portions.  We were stuffed mid-way through the 3rd course.  

Next time, would skip the $5 housemade sourdough, delicious, but was too much food, you get four slices and we barely finished two.  

Since the server knew we were sharing, he gave us shared plates and directed the staff to place the dishes at the center of the table.  

Spring for the $42 wine pairings, most were spot on and got to try 8 glasses - especially loved the effervescence of the lambrusco.  

Our selections for the night:
*Market Greens, avocado, seeds, mandarin, honey-lime, looks simple, but the toasted seeds really add another dimension
*Dry Aged Beef, pickled plum, brown rice crisp, kimchi furikake, balanced, well-seasoned, textured, a favorite
*Soft-Cooked Egg, nori, puffed rice, salmon roe, bacon vinaigrette, a conundrum, a lot going on and a tad salty
*Potato Dumplings, black trumpet, cauliflower, pine nut, sage, rich pillowy perfection
*Trout, artichoke, shelling beans, oro blanco, preserved meyer lemon, fresh fish, crisped skin, the beans were excessive and a bit out of place
*Duck, celeriac, quince, maitake, grains of paradise, tender, the confit was really salty
*Coconut Coffee Tart, futsu squash, lime, perfectly puckered sweet, custard reminded me of an egg tart
*Frozen Chocolate, huckleberry, bourbon meringue, cacao nib, decadent, I especially enjoyed the meringue and nib

Interesting meal with carefully manipulated ingredients.  Well executed, beautifully plated, texturally varied and seasoned with restraint.  

Affordable, creative Michelin meal in an environment that is not forced and manages to still surprise the seasoned diner.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
A group of coworkers visited Aster as a "treat yo self" event, and it was really exactly that.  We all did the 4 course menu, which costs $65 per person.  We were advised to not do the wine pairings, as we would not get as much wine as we wanted.  

Since we were all sharing, I got to try every single dish on the menu.  Firstly, spring the $5 for the fresh sour dough bread.  I'm not a huge fan of sour dough but it's moist, fresh, and delicious --even the crust is good, and i don't even like crust.  

My favorite for the first course was the "dry aged beef, pickled plum, kimchi furikake, and brown rice crisp."  This was delicious, and was our favorite for the group.  I would definitely recommend it, and it may have been my favorite dish.  

For the second course, I really liked the "potato dumplings, black trumpet, cauliflower, pine nut, and sage" option.  The potato dumplings were so delicious and the dish overall was just surprisingly good.  

For the third (main entree), I think the duck was the best.  "Duck, celeriac, quince, maitake, and grains of paradise."  This was tender, cooked nicely, and the most flavorful option.  

For the last dish (dessert), I was shocked to find that I loved the savory option, "contralto, chardonnay pate de fruit, rye, and poppy."  The cheese and fruit combined with the cracker -- we honestly all loved this.  

Overall, the decor of the restaurant is very nice.  I love the lighting on the ceiling, and how mirrors really make the ceiling look larger -- and expands the space.  It is very intimate and romantic, I can see this being a nice anniversary spot.  The kitchen is open/exposed so you can see what is being done.  I loved the ceramic handmade dishes they use and the coasters that seemed to be made out of a felt like material.  Our waitress was very knowledgeable and very friendly.  

I would say the presentation of the food is phenomenal, service is great, decor is great, but I can't say I'd ever crave any of the dishes or think of them again. (maybe the bread) -- but overall we had a great experience and I'd recommend it.
author: Michelle S.

description: Great food for each course. Just be prepared to a break bank, especially when tell you about additions like caviar and truffle. Mmm.....
author: Linda C.

description:
I was suggested by Dean S. awhile ago to come here. (Thanks Dean!) Seeing that this was also a 1 Michelin Star restaurant, I was both excited and hopeful to finally dine here after a week of anticipation. I kept my hopes low in order to be truly blown away by their dishes. (Seriously need to do that or no restaurant will ever meet my high expectations. : ))

Aster is located on Guerrero Street in the Mission District of San Francisco. It's only a few blocks away from Mission Delores Park. It's mainly street parking and we were able to find a space pretty easy just a block away that night. Parking in the Mission is always hard, but you can get lucky if you park farther away from Valencia Street. 

The restaurant space is small but quaint with an open kitchen towards the back end. It has a contemporary decor with a dimly-lit romantic ambience. There's small tables for 2 and 4 with a long communal table in the center of the dining room. (Guessing that's for walk-ins?) Our server was very helpful and friendly seeing that it was our first time dining there; asked us if we had any food allergies first. He walked us through the menu and made his recommendations. 

Their menu consists of a four-course $65 prix-fix menu with $36 wine pairings. (Perfect if you go with 3 other friends if you want to taste every single thing on the menu.) In order to indulge, the whole table has to participate. There's also an option of ordering a là carte if customers don't have the appetite for 4 courses. (The amount per dish isn't teeny tiny either.) I must say that you cannot miss their desserts. Each one is delicious in their own way and a big amount too. 

Dishes not to be missed -

Soft Cooked Egg : So good! The coddled egg reminds me of the jelly-like yolk at Commis in Oakland. (Without the price at Commis.) The puffed rice adds a good crunch. You can totally taste the bacon vinaigrette too. 

Potato Dumplings : Soft and pillowy. Reminds me of Gnocchi but better. A very rich dish. 

Trout : MUST GET. Like now. Get it now. Crispy skin. Perfect texture. The best trout I've ever had! I would go back just for this. 

Poached Pear : This was delicious. A whole pear with vanilla ice cream on the inside and top with a crunchy pistachio cookie on top. 

Frozen Chocolate : Looked delicious as it looked. Smooth and rich. Bourbon Meringue added a light contrast to the rich chocolate.
author: Julie W.

description:
A reasonably priced four course tasting menu with options for each course drew me to Aster because it allowed my more selective wife and I to customize our dinners to our preferences. We enjoyed every course and the service was flawless.

Coming from Union Square, we had a about a 4 block walk through the Mission from the 24th St. BART stop. We were seated immediately in the cozy restaurant with an open kitchen and were briefed on the menu by our server Andrea. This is a review from our visit in August 2016 and comparing the menu from then to present, repeat diners that want variation will be pleased to know that the menu is fluid. The prices are also fluid as the tasting menu and wine pairing are both $6 more compared to 7 months ago. 

Service from Andrea was Michelin star worthy with her being laid back but still maintaining the utmost professionalism. Her extensive knowledge of the menu and wine made our experience that much better by offering great recommendations and descriptions of the flavors, even giving details of the rationale for the wine pairing for each course. 

After we ordered the sourdough bread, we received 9 dishes that were presented beautifully with a wine pairing for each course for me. All were delicious and we were both happy with our choices. Luckily, I was recommended to have the duck instead of the pork which turned out to be my favorite. We actually ordered the milk chocolate custard, which was our favorite dessert, after we finished our courses because we couldn't get enough.

The total for the tab was $192 before tip which is a fair price considering the number of courses and the quality of the food and wine. This is a great restaurant if you enjoy California cuisine and prefer to have choices with your courses.
author: Arthur M.

description:
Came in on a Thursday night to reunite with some friends. Was fairly easy to score an OpenTable reservation, and we had been meaning to explore this Michelin-starred menu for a while. We decided against doing the prix fixe, since we felt like it would be too much food. However, we did delve pretty deep into the starters, and had no regrets. 

The place is pretty small, intimate, and had a fairly casual, yet elegant vibe. The open kitchen was not very far away from where we were seated near the window, and we could still see a lot of the different dishes being prepared. Everything we ended up ordering was very beautifully plated, which is what sort of attracted us in the first place, after seeing the Yelp pictures.

Some of our favorites:
- Dry-aged beef tartare: A good balance of textures and sweet/salty flavors.
- Soft-cooked egg with puffed rice: The bacon vinaigrette that it came with was really well-executed, and the salmon roe added that bit of saltiness that really put it over the top
- Potato dumplings: Really nice and dense, without actually being too heavy, and the sage was a great flavor contrast
- Winter Mushrooms: A great mix of different mushrooms, and the slightly pickled cabbage really helped bring it all together
- Duck: Probably my favorite dish of the night. Perfectly cooked, and went well with the mushrooms and grains of paradise.

Service overall was very attentive, although the the time between the 1st and the second course was a little long (over 20 minutes). We still ended up paying around $65 a person, but that included tax and tip, as well as a drink from the menu, not to mention we were all very full by the end of the night.

Definitely worth a try for dinner, and wouldn't hesitate to come back and try their brunch menu. Very glad that we had a solid experience, and would definitely recommend for a nice dinner for small groups and dates.
author: Eric J.

description:
What an amazing experience in Aster! We were happy to know that Aster won its fist Michelin star and decided to try its New American Courses. 
We four people reserved a week ago. It was a small restaurant with warm lights and vintage decorations. The kitchen was in open style so you could actually see the chef preparing your food. 
We order all 4 different sets of courses. That was one reason for friend's gathering because all of you could share and try all courses in Aster! 
A set is composed with 4 courses. Simple but delicate. In my opinion, I fell in love with the desert with some orange flower petals. It tasted fresh and sour-sweet reminding of the feeling of a cool summer day! The main course with salmon was delicious. Crispy skin and fish meat seasoned with sea salt made you imagine the wide ocean in your mind! 
In general, the wonderful experience includes good service and aesthetic food. You had better try it!
author: Gigi G.

description:
We celebrated our 5th anniversary over dinner at Aster. It's one of the nicer settings we have eaten at, although there is still a sense of casual ambiance despite its Michelin star. They have a great corner location. 

We opted for the four course menu. There are four options for each course so you still get the choice to customize your own meal. We started off with their sourdough bread which is something Aster is known for. The fuyu persimmon appetizer was a unique but delicious bite. The potato dumplings were warm and paired nicely with the crunchy black trumpet mushrooms. My main dish was the pork with miso potatoes, Brussels sprouts and grapes - everything juicy and flavorful. Then we were treated to a special sorbet dish compliments of the chef for our anniversary. That might have been my favorite part! My poached pear dessert was so good, something I wish I could mimic in my own kitchen! 

Aster was yet another amazing Michelin experience. We were stuffed by the end, and it was half the price of most Michelin restaurants. Aster would be a great choice for an affordable first time Michelin experience!
author: Ashley C.

description:
I flew into San Francisco on Monday morning and bee-lined for Aster that same night. It is my first Michelin restaurant in California, though it certainly won't be my last, and I was really excited to give it a try. 

I made a reservation via OpenTable and received a call from the hostess the day before confirming it. She also checked to make sure that there were no food allergies or religious preferences, and whether it was a special occasion. (It wasn't officially but for the record, eating is always a special occasion in my book!)

Aster has a clean, contemporary California feel. It's dimly lit but not romantic per se. It's more of a cool edginess. We absolutely loved the ambiance. While the mirrored panels at the ceiling made the restaurant seem like it goes on forever, it's smaller than I expected. It probably only seats 40(ish?) people, and about a third of that is made up of just one large elevated table that runs the length of the restaurant. The open kitchen runs the length of the far end wall. 

Service was just OK, which disappointed me a bit. I wanted a little more assistance with the dishes as some of the ingredients were foreign (or just plain hidden). Two of the plates came directly from the kitchen and the server explained the best way to eat them, but for all the rest we were left to our own devices. (Is that even a complaint?)

It was both of our first visit to Aster so we both elected to do the four course menu and selected different items for each course so that we could try more of the menu. (Re: the tasting menu, it's $65 per person and the whole table must participate. The menu is split into four courses with four choices in each.) We had the following:

Course 1: 
- PINK LADY APPLES, yuzu preserve, brown butter-squash, yogurt, arugula ($16): just OK
- DRY AGED BEEF, pickled plum, brown rice crispy, kimchi furikake ($18): really tasty. The ageing process enhanced the beef's natural flavors. 

Course 2:
- THUMBELINA CARROTS, sunchoke, coconut, black lime ($16): unbelievable! Sunchokes are trending hard right now and this was honestly my favorite dish of the night. 
- SOFT-COOKED EGG, nori, puffed rice, salmon roe, bacon vinaigrette ($15): a little more on the Japanese spectrum. The salmon roe added some of that bonita flake flavor you find in a good ramen shop, and the puffed rice changed the consistency of the entire dish (in a good way).

Course 3:
- PORK, miso potatoes, brussels, grapes, verjus ($28): perfectly cooked and beautifully plated. I would eat this EVERY DAMN DAY.
- DUCK, celeriac, quince, maitake, grains of paradise ($29): again, perfectly cooked. I didn't think the plating of this dish was particularly great but I had one bite and none of that mattered. Really excellent. 

Course 4:
- POACHED PEAR, pistachio, vanilla ($12): YUM. This dessert was delicate and oh-so-tasty! 
- COCONUT COFFEE TART, futsu squash, lime ($12): I liked the tart but the crust was a bit tough. I almost flipped the whole tart off the plate trying to cut it with my dessert spoon. Flavor was great, though, and I loved the savory coffee flavor in contrast to the sharp lime sorbet. 

We also ordered the SOURDOUGH ($5). As expected in SF, the bread was on point! The portion was only four slices served with a whipped and salted butter, but they were BIG slices. I took most of it home and enjoyed it with that excellent salty butter and a strong black coffee the next morning - very European, right?

Overall, at $65pp (not including the $42 wine pairing), the pricing felt fair for the quality of the meal. We left completely full and fully satiated. I would definitely come back.
author: Lexi W.

description:
Ambient setting. Impressive food. And incredible service.

The four course meal was a fun experience and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Food quality was amazing and the presentation was worth gushing over. 

Good to knows: 
We called to let them know we were running late for our 5:45 dinner reservation and was informed that they would only hold our table for 15 minutes. Maybe this is a restaurant policy? But thought they would be more lenient on this 

Street parking is tough to find on a weekend, but there's a parking garage on 21st and Bartlett. Rate is $4.50 per hour after 6pm.
author: Ying Z.

description:
Serene space. Thoughtful dishes. Everything about Aster makes me think of San Francisco. Well, a certain slice of San Francisco. Not representative of San Francisco as a whole but a certain slice of it if that makes any sense. 

You have good friends if they treat you to a birthday dinner here! The birthday ice cream looked simple and unassuming but very distinct in flavor. A good finish to the meal.
author: Yad L.

description: Great place. Came here to celebrate my second wedding anniversary. Great food, and super friendly staff. 10 for food presentation. Impressive
author: Leticia R.

description:
We came here before seeing a show at SHN theater. We made our reservation at 6:15 since we had to be at the show by 8pm. We forgot to tell our waiter our time constrain so we did not get a chance to eat our desert. So plan to have time if you are planning on having a 4 course tasting menu. 

Ambiance was very nice and the service was very good. I really enjoyed the dishes I ordered and the wine our server helped us pick. Very artfully prepared food! I would definitely come back.
author: Irem G.

description:
I guess this could be 3.5 stars because their mains were prepared so expertly. The food was good, but nothing that blew me out of the water and service was fair. 

I came here with two other friends. I thought that this was the perfect arrangement because there were three choices per course. There were four courses to chose from. It's $65 for the four courses. It was nice to mix and match. 

Throughout the menu, it was good. I think that items were well cooked, but no flavor pairings were amazing. In the first course, I didn't think anything stood out too much. Even the beef tartare was only okay. It was good textures but it was under seasoned. 
The second course was probably the most impressive for flavor profiles. The spatzel was good; it was more so for richness than flavors. The egg with burnt rice was a mixture of good textures. And the squid was my favorite. It was cooked well and presented so nicely! 
The mains were also very good. I think the proteins in all of them were well prepared but the sides that accompanied them didn't do that much for me. They're simply seasoned. 
The desserts were kind of disappointing. I didn't like the olive oil/cake/goat cheese whip. It just wasn't up my alley. I did like the others. They were light and not too overpowering. It was good. 

I would recommend this place for a very safe American choice... but I don't think that I would come back.
author: Tina Y.

description:
I would say 4.5 stars....but rounding up to 5 because Aster was dee-li-SHOUS.  
Worthy of its Michelin star.

Came for the $65 set course meal with a group of friends and had the following:

Apps
- Aged beef tartare
- Shaved apple with yogurt and squash:  Refreshing, crisp
- Soft-cooked egg, nori, puffed rice:  Almost like a fancy bibimbap (for you korean food lovers out there)
- Potato Dumplings:  Soft and pillowy with a just-crisp outside, sitting in 

Mains
- Trout, artichoke, shelling beans:  Excellent crispy skin.  Overall good, but didn't blow me away.  Maybe I can't appreciate fish like others do?  I haven't been impressed by many fish dishes in the past.
- Duck, spring onion, garlic, bok choy:  MUST GET.  Major umami.
- Pork, endive, sunchokes

Dessert
- Coconut coffee tart w/lemon and squash:  Might be too sweet for some, but I liked their combination of very tart and very sweet components, which balanced each other in the end.
- Frozen chocolate w/huckleberry and meringue:  Like a light chocolate cloud in my mouth

Almost everything I tasted was like magic in my mouth with its play of flavors and textures.  Everything had a light and satisfying finish and yet I was very full by the end of the meal...flavorful without being weighed down by sauces...not overwhelming in the amount of food given.  They also did a great job spacing out the dishes so that you can fully enjoy each course.  The exceptions would be the tartare, trout, and pork, which I felt tasted fairly standard.

Side note:  If you're with friends and wanting a loud catch-up session...don't come here.  Quiet place...definitely with dates going on...we definitely got some stank-eyes, understandably so...although was it from awkward date participants wishing they were having as much fun as us? :p
author: Mon T.

description:
Aster is an elegant, beautifully decorated Michelin-star restaurant near the Mission District. Having been here for brunch before, I recently had the chance to try their dinner service as well (which has a completely different menu). The service was extremely friendly, and as one of my dining companions was friends with our waiter, we got some really great recommendations as well!

Our dinner started off with a plate of the homemade sourdough bread--this was one of the best sourdoughs I've ever had! It came with a cultured, salted butter that was absolutely irresistible, and the texture and flavor of the bread was unbelievable! For starters, we had the aged beef tartare, which was particularly beefy and raw tasting (thanks to the dry aging). We also had the brassicas, a light dish of root vegetables. But by far my favorite was the potato dumplings--these gnocchi were light and pillowy and sautéed in butter; they came with toasted pine nuts, which added a contrasting crunch and earthiness that was absolutely fantastic!

And then we moved on to entrees--the trout was decent, though it came with pieces of the hard outer leaves of artichoke, which were sharp and inedible, and these seemed to ruin the dish for me. The wild mushrooms with farro was a tasty dish as well, but my favorite was the duck breast, which was tender and had such a distinctive flavor--it also came with shreds of salty duck confit, which really brought the flavors of the dish over the edge!

Dessert here was definitely a highlight--the poached pear was served in a light syrup and filled with ice cream--so tender and not overly sweet. The frozen chocolate was unbelievable--the chocolate mousse was thick and creamy without being too heavy, and it was topped with a crunchy meringue, slightly tart huckleberry jam, and surrounded with cacao nibs, which added the perfect crunchy texture to the soft, delicate mousse. 

Overall, this was a great place for dinner--every dish was good, but some particularly stood out--the potato dumplings and frozen chocolate were probably the highlights for me! Given the menu prices, the portions were certainly a bit small, though this was not too much of a splurge for a Michelin-star restaurant!
author: David K.

description:
My first official "Michelin-star" meal in the city! 

Came with two friends at brunch time and would like to share some small dishes, as none of us were really hungry. We went with the black cod small bite (definitely a must-try! The cod was minced thinly and well-marinated), the duck confit hash with Brussels sprouts (crispy duck matched with crunchy Brussels sprouts, nice combo!), and the over-easy egg (this one was a bit of a let-down...). We also shared the citrus cake as an ending.

Felt to me, Aster did a good job bringing their best cooked food to us; yet was lack of signature dishes. Or probably because we only tried brunch?

Made reservation through OpenTable three days ahead (not too difficult), yet same day walk-in was tough.
author: Elaine H.

description: My friend and I had a fantastic prix fixe 4 course meal for $75 and did the delightful wine pairing for $42.  I enjoyed the market greens, followed by the soft-cooked egg, with trout as my main course and strawberries for dessert. The presentation was fantastic and the flavors and textures were really original. So, why 4 stars and not 5? I thought it was loud and it was also quite warm. Plus they have a large communal table in the center of the restaurant and it made the restaurant seem a little chaotic but is probably a good idea if you don't have a reservation.
author: Virginia T.

description:
Dined here the other night with a friend and was really pleased with the meal and service. We sat at the large communal table on Wednesday night, 7:30pm and the restuarant never got super busy (I guess for a Wednesday). It's a 4-course pre-fix meal, with 3 options in each course. While figuring out our orders we started with a bottle of red and the bread/butter which I read rave reviews on. It was definitely delicious and soft, moist (everything you want in a good bread) plus the unique salted flavor of the butter was great... but I also just love bread and butter. For my meals I had the following: 
- Dry aged beef - interesting tar-tar like consistency with large puff on. 3.5 stars
- Soft cooked egg and added uni - I love a good raw egg, but my friend and I both agreed this was kind of odd. The white was also decently raw, which was kind of weird to me. I could have done with just the raw yoke, but flavors were still good. It's one of their signature dishes, but I would venture to something else. 
- Hen - Yes, loved, moist, get this 4 stars. My friend's trout also looked delicious. 
- Chocolate custard - More like a soft chocolate bark with carmel inside and custard dots for decoration. It was a good, lighter way to end my meal so I recommend this if you like a lighter chocolate treat to end your meal

Overall, it is more expensive, but the quality of food is there and the service is great. I think it's worth checking out.
author: Aryn C.

description:
3.5 stars--

I really wanted to like Aster.... I really do. I thought the food was good, but wasn't blown away despite its Michelin star status. The restaurant is really cute (perfect for date night!), the host was really friendly, but the meal was overall a little disorganized and overpriced...

I was a little disgruntled to start because the restaurant raised their prices AFTER I booked my reservation on May 1 for June 10; well over a month in advance. This was when the prix fixe menu was priced at $65 pp, which I consider a good deal for a nice restaurant San Francisco. However, less than 24 hours before my reservation, I received a lovely voice message from the restaurant saying they have increased the price to $75 pp. Really.... I would expect them to either to 1) have notified me when they increased the price on June 1 as a courtesy; 2) honor the price made for guests who made reservations prior to June 1; or 3) list on their website their expected price change. I just think they have communicated/handled this poorly. 

I expressed my disappointment to the host, who said he'd ask, but never got back to me, so I had to reach out to him again at the end of my meal when we got the bill. I was referred to the restaurant manager who wouldn't budge about her decision and was not accommodating whatsoever. I'm also a little peeved that they didn't notify me until after the meal... At $75, I probably would have reconsidered dining here had I known about this price increase. $75 is a good threshold for price point. And they have a list of upcoming reservations, shouldn't they be transparent and let us know earlier? 

Anyway, onto the food:
Like I said, it's a 4 course prix fixe menu. 1 cold app, 1 warm app, main, and dessert. I really appreciate that the dishes were all on the more light and refreshing side. I loved the egg bowl bacon dish because duh, bacon. The crispy rice added a nice texture to the dish. The granita dessert was awesome as well and perfect for a hot summer day. All dishes were plated so beautifully and totally instagram-worthy, so keep your phone in your pocket to take pictures. FYI, they charge $5 for the bread, which I personally did not think was worth it. However, my fiance liked it because the bread was soft and not crunchy like most sourdough breads.

As for service... We felt we were ignored for quite awhile and two different servers asked what drinks we'd like to order. They also forgot to bring packed leftovers when we paid the bill. My Lyft driver was outside when I realized this and scrambled back into the restaurant to pick up m boxed food.
