Overall, Aster was just an average meal, with some improvements to be made. I have gained a huge appreciation for chefs ever since watching Chef's Table on Netflix (haha). Chef Brett Cooper's has such a cool culinary experience such as developing the fire cooking program at Saison, cooking with now chef of State Bird Provisions, etc... so I was a little disappointed.

Also, note that this restaurant is pretty small and you may end up sitting at the communal table. If you're looking for a private dinner, contact them and request a private table.
author: Janet H.

description: The food is great, and the wine pairings are fab, but the communal table in the middle is so incredibly close together and squashed that it blows my mind that a restaurant this expensive has 1/2 of their patrons sitting there. I could hear every word of conversation next to me, honestly so odd
author: Shannon M.

description:
I really enjoyed this place! Nice atmosphere with good food and friendly service.

My favorites here are the persimmon appetizer and the crab appetizer, both were super fresh and flavorful. The egg appetizer was okay... a poached egg with crunchy toppings and the potato dumplings were good. 

For the main dishes - the trout was good! My family also got the duck and pork which they said was good too. Definitely get the sourdough bread! That was a hit ($5 though).
author: Caley Z.

description:
If I were to leave without having dessert I would rate Aster as 3 stars. The main dishes are underwhelming and over salted. That being said the duck was perfectly cooked and had a wonder mouth feel. 

The saving grace for this restaurant is their dessert menu. Every dish is well balanced and the Lemon Grass mixed with the kumquat in my dessert was light and extremely pleasant to eat. With several flavors that could easily be overwhelm the dish, I can say they nailed it. This should be a signature dish that never leaves the menu especially throughout spring and summer. 

The servers are all friendly, but not consistent with the information each one offers. 

If they can nail the main courses and create a consistent flow of service for every guest they will easily move to five stars.
author: Brian K.

description: Solid solid meal.  I honestly went in with low expectations because I was disappointed in my last meal at a recent highly touted restaurant, but this place exceeded expectations and more.  I can honestly say that this was one of the best dining experiences I've had in a long time.  Every dish...I mean EVERY dish was delicious.  There were three of us, and after the first course blew us away...we decided to add every item on the tasting menu onto our meal.  I mean, I had no idea I could like carrots so much...and I don't even like carrots!  On top of that, the staff was super courteous, friendly and attentive...honestly I couldn't have asked for a better experience for me, my wife and her mother on her special night (retirement celebration). Thanks to the entire staff for a great night! Hope to be back again soon!
author: Chad K.

description:
Our first Michelin restaurant! We had a reservation a week before on OpenTable, and the restaurant kindly checked the day before our dining whether we have any food restrictions.

The meal was great and unique. The restaurant is quite tiny and elegant with a long table in the center. We were sit at a table of 4, near the open kitchen. The bread as appetizer was great. They spread the butter at the bottoms of the plate.

We had the 65 per person for 4 courses each. And tried almost 3/4 of their dishes. Great choice! I loved the soft-cooked egg with puffed rice. The winter mushroom was creamy and special. All their desserts look so pretty. I especially liked the poached pear with vanilla ice cream and also he frozen chocolate with huckleberry and bourbon meringue.

I like that they left us with a menu of what we have had for the meal, so that I could typed those food names and knew what I have really eaten ;)
author: Xuaner Z.

description: Don't get me wrong the food is lovely, but prefer the four course format Aster used to offer. Courses used to be small/medium size. Now with the seven course tasting menu the dishes are extremely small. It's a shame because the courses you are really looking forward to are gone in just a few bites (like the beef course with a very small serving of beef). The service is good. Staff are pleasant and know their menu and produce well. We had seven courses plus wine pairings (which are great and do perfectly complement or bring to life the flavours as they should) and an additional cheese course. The menu doesn't show prices for the food or wine pairings. In all honesty we were a little surprised at the bill which was double what it was when we came the last few times. So for that we felt the very small plates didn't quite match up and decor (or location) could do with something more. Also as others have mentioned tables are a little too close together. For that price point other restaurants, Michelin starred or not, offer a little more.
author: Kimberly ..

description: Absolutely loved everything I had. The menu is creative and packed with flavor. The staff was very knowledgeable and friendly. I was incredibly surprised by how full I felt although each meal was a moderate portion. Definitely recommend.
author: Dayris F.

description:
Price of dinner tasting menu just raised to $75. Portions we're smallish and they charged $5 for bread and butter which was good but in my opinion not worth the extra charge. Octopus appetizer was my favorite but again all dishes seemed small to me. Dessert was disappointing. 
One server was very pleasant and helpful but another one made me feel very rushed. She cleared the plates the moment we finished eating and brought out the next very quickly. Check arrived right after dessert. No "take your time" or anything. Bottom line, food was good but not great for what I expect from this caliber restaurant and at this price and I felt too rushed to enjoy it all. Wish we chose another restaurant to celebrate our special occasion.
author: Ann L.

description: Seasonal pre-fixed 4 course menu with 3 options for each course. Excellent presentation and flavors. Memorable dishes: dry aged beef, delicata squash, soft-cooked egg, wild mushrooms, hen and last but not least the FROZEN YOGURT. Oh and the sourdough with house cultured butter was crazy...in all the good ways.
author: Alex B.

description: I wish i can give it 3.5 instead of 4 stars. I have been here 3 times, and I always liked the meat dishes. Vegetarian dishes are a hit or a miss. Overall, lovely service, great dessert with decent food.
author: Balu V.

description:
This is an excellent restaurant if you have never actually had good food. Are Michelin stars suffering from grade inflation as well?! Of the four courses, only the second one, the egg, was memorable. The trout looked like salmon and tasted blah. The first course, the carrots, well, they were carrots. And the dessert: "smoked caramel with bitter chocolate". Bitter? I think they need to check their taste buds because it was overly sweet. I left almost all of it untouched. 

The atmosphere also leaves a lot to be desired. We spent over two hours on hard wooden seats, hearing bad music, and sitting so close to other diners who spoke so loudly we were forced to become informed of their business dealings, there family drama, and their love life.  

The only saving grace of the restaurant is their wine pairing which was for the most part pretty good. But seriously, for $200/person, I can have WAY better food in beautiful settings where I get to escape the everyday and enjoy my meal with the one I choose and not random strangers who are sitting way too close to me.

I am stupefied by the number of 4- and 5-star reviews people are giving this place. If you think this is a 4, you need to teach your taste buds better!
author: V B.

description:
I definitely have to recommend this place not only for it's great execution of flavorful dishes but also for offering one of the most affordable multi course tasting menus I've seen in the city

Every dish we tried (beef with brown rice crisp, octopus with fennel/nettle/salsa verde, potato dumplings, soft cooked egg w salmon roe, and the duck and halibut) were delicious and showcased an impressive range of flavors. Both entree proteins, besides being beautifully cooked, were also quite filling. I also recommend the frozen chocolate dessert, but that may be my preference for huckleberry showing. The strawberry dessert wasn't my favorite but would be enjoyed by any fans of shaved ice in your group
author: Neal B.

description:
Sigh. Underwhelming for $330 with a low tip (on food only) and wine pairings (for two). Half of an iphone X trade in. Or a plane ticket to NYC for 1. You get the picture. 

Sunchoke soup and pairing were excellent. Possibly was a chenin blanc.

Beef tartar was fine but didn't shine. Ok pairing. 

Egg + uni didn't blend well though individually the uni and egg were nice. Don't remember the pairing. 

Hen was good but over seasoned. Cider pairing off.

Green faro was too brassica-y and didn't blend well. Nice red paired.

Deserts (Chocolate and Strawberry) were both unsuccessful. Liked the Moscato paired with Strawberry but woulda been happy with just that on its own. Vermouth pairing with Chocolate was too bitter except maybe in some bites and tiny sips. 

Server was good and warm with some support staff a little awkward.

Bathroom needs seat covers. Communal table has false floor below table to accommodate taller chairs that is too high and bring your knees above your hips. Uncomfortable. 

Oh well.
author: Loren R.

description:
Tried this place for brunch. Had a reservation for 8 and we were seated at the front of the restaurant with plenty of lighting. 

Started with the following shared plates:
Sourdough, salted butter, dark chocolate - very interesting dish that tasted quite good. Sourdough was easy to bite into and the dark chocolate shavings just melt in your mouth. 
Buttermilk biscuit, bacon, honey butter - this seemed like an odd dish since the biscuit and bacon don't seem to pair well together
Goat cheese, poppy cracker, apricot jam, hazelnut - this was pretty tasty and the cheese had a light flavor that mixed well with the apricot and hazelnut

Entree: 
Duck confit hash - two perfectly cooked runny eggs, duck was juicy mixed together with brussel sprouts and some sauce. breaking the eggs and mixing everything into one bite was delicious

Sourdough and duck confit hash were my favorite dishes here. -1 star for lack of service. They never refilled our waters nor did they provide a prefilled water bottle. This place has a michelin star, but it is certainly not for the brunch.
author: Edward W.

description:
Very nice food, EXCELLENT desserts, truly EXCELLENT service.

The food changes, so I'll focus on the service: timing was impeccable and the staff noticed all sorts of little things.  We never had to ask.  I haven't had service like this since Europe.
author: adam s.

description: Had Mother's Day brunch here, which was a prix fixe menu, and it unfortunately didn't live up to the hype or expectation. It was good, yes, but I can't even remember what I ate. I do remember thinking, hm, nothing special. :\ Maybe (hopefully) dinner is different. Cute interior and great service, though.
author: Kathy L.

description: Had dinner here for my friends birthday. The pairing was great! However I would suggest the the main entries should improve-it was ok! However the starters we're great! Especially the beef tartar and the egg w/bacon/salmon roe. Also the macadamia honey cake was delicious- perfect sweetness!
author: Sharika S.

description:
I wasn't sure what to expect (I just needed an available dinner reservation for 6 and had Aster bookmarked on Yelp), but this was a surprisingly wonderful dinner! Although not every single dish was a winner, every course had 1 or 2 amazing dishes that made this experience great.

Be aware that it is a tasting menu and there is no a la carte for dinner.

Good playlist - I heard, amongst other bands, Lykke, Phoenix, Lorde, and Santigold.

RESERVATIONS: Made about a week in advance for a Sunday at 6pm, for five. I was able to change it to six the day before.

SERVICE: Very professional and friendly.

THE COST: $79.20 per person including tax/tip for the 4-course tasting menu and a Sourdough Bread split between five people. A bit pricey, but I felt this was worth the splurge for a friend who was in town! 

MUST-HAVES: Early girl tomato or Halibut (1st course), Potato dumplings or Thumbelina carrots (2nd course), Trout or Duck (4th course), Peach melba or Oat vacherin (4th course).

See my photos for additional review details!

* Sourdough ($5) - 4.5 stars - Spongy, definitely sour, good crisp.

FIRST COURSE
* Market greens & herbs - 4 stars - There's a surprise layer of avocado/seeds at the bottom!
* Early girl tomato - 5 stars - The favorite! Intense flavor to the tomato.
* Local halibut - 4.5 stars - Second favorite. Very fresh halibut. Served cool, the cucumber flavor dominates.
* Summer squash - 3 stars

SECOND COURSE
* Chilled green garlic soup - 3 stars
* Thumbelina carrots - 4.5 stars - A close second. Great flavors!
* Soft-cooked egg (crispy potato, salmon roe) - 4 stars
* Potato dumplings - 5 stars - The favorite by far. Great texture to the gnocchi.

THIRD COURSE
* Lobster mushroom & summer beans - 3 stars
* Trout - 4 stars - I would rate this higher but the trout was over-salted
* Pork - 3.5 stars
* Duck - 4 stars

FOURTH COURSE
* Oat vacherin (honey, lavender) - 4 stars
* Peach melba - 4.5 stars - The favorite.
* Milk chocolate custard - 3.5 stars
* Contralto - 3.5 stars - A subtly sweet cheese. Great dessert for cheese-lovers, but that's just not me!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Three stars for the food, one star for the service and atmosphere.

I was taken there for my birthday in September. There were open tables around the sides but they made us wait 1/2 hour for the communal table because those tables were for special occasions. Never mind that my husband specified when making the reservation that this was a special occasion- my birthday- which was never acknowledged by the staff in any way- a first for a restaurant experience when you specify it's someone's birthday.

All in all I have to say I hated the service and hated the vibe of the restaurant which seemed to be: you should be honored to be spending your money here. The place seemed to cater to a young well to do crowd and for being in the Mission and being in SF it had a suffocatingly stuffy vibe and judgmental feel. I had a strong yearning for the old Bar Tartine where the service could be sloppy and haphazard but was almost always warm and welcoming.

The food was good, though it's not particularly innovative, just the usual heavy-ish California cuisine that felt like you were transported back to the 90s. Even when the food was good it felt like the chef was trying too hard and the food lacked vibrancy. For example we got the lamb special which was an over the top umami bomb. I thought I detected added MSG or Maggie sauce or marmite or some similar Umami boosting ingredient which seemed to me like cheating.

But overall the problem with this place is not so much the food as the attitude. I will NEVER set foot in this place again.
author: George T.

description: Came on a double date and did the four course tasting menu. Food was decent and nicely presented but nothing really stood out. It's typical new American cuisine in San Francisco with amazing plating, small menu and minimalistic decor.  They got a one star Michelin star recently and it's not too difficult to get a reservation.
author: Cindy H.

description: This was probably the overall best meal & dining experience I ever had. Decor is very simple and it really showcases the food. Service amazing, friendly, not pretentious and I felt they really genuinely wanted us to enjoy our meal. Started with a nice bottle of Terrebrune dry rose. Excellent wine. You must get the bread with the cultured salted butter. I could eat it everyday. I had the market greens it was so good so fresh. I took a taste of the dry aged beef it was rich and delicious. My next course was the rye spaetzle, the aroma when the dish was placed before me was amazing, it smelled like a loaf of rye. I love mushrooms and this was full of mushroom flavor very rich. Next up for me was the green farro probably my fav of the evening, if green had a flavor it would be this dish. Again when the dish was placed the aroma wafted up, I couldn't wait to eat it. I ended the meal with strawberry so refreshing. For a tasting meal of this caliber (Michelin star) the prices are fair, the service outstanding and the food, delicious works of art. I am so happy I had the pure pleasure of dining there. Bravo Aster!!!!!
author: Karen R.

description:
The food at Aster is decent but pretty overpriced. The flavor combinations are faux-Asian and force the umami. Each of my savory dishes ate too unctuous, too gooey, too mayo-y but without the honesty of actually using mayonnaise. People still throw a loose sousvide egg on top of a stuff?! 2002 called and wants its tasting menu back. Farm-raised trout at a Michelin star place? WAH?!

Solid dessert, but I wanted something baked. An extra star for the amazing sourdough, but it should be charged as a cover for bread service instead of per-plate. Excellent service in general, but the tables should have tablecloths.

Sons & Daughters does the hipsteraunt vibe better, Commonwealth has much better food.
author: Ben G.

description: its good，but one of the dish have a green bug on top，and the waitress said because their vegetable all from their own farm.
author: Xiaoteng L.

description:
Review update for dinner:

Really dinner is worthy of 5 stars, but brunch not so much, so I would say an average of 4 stars.

We booked a reservation here for Valentine's day and it did not disappoint.  The dinner menu is far better than the brunch menu, and more substantial too.  We got the tasting with the pairing, which is nice since you get to essentially pick your own adventure.  My favorite was the duck (however I'm partial to duck) which was moist and flavorful.  I also got the pink lady apple appetizer which had an unique combination of flavors that really complemented each other.  The sourdough bread is amazing, and definitely a must order.
author: Tiffany C.
Miko B.

description:
We came here on a whim on a Friday night with a friend from out of town hoping to catch up over some delicious food and we were supremely pleased with the experience! First, great luck with walking in and getting seated immediately. The set up of the restaurant is very cool with a mix of tall and short seating options, a grand long high table in the middle and lower benches around the outside. The ambiance is very french, romantic, and I love the decor. 

We each ordered wines to sip while debating the tasting menu although the wines didn't come until dinner was served. This was a little awkward for me as I wanted a wine before doing the dinner and wine pairing set but in the end all were delicious and much fun was had. Unfortunately I didn't end up getting to specify which wines should come with my food pairings, so while I started with a crisp white for an aperitif and intended to transition to reds for my meals, I ended up with all whites in my tasting regime. Not my usual preference but I decided to give it a try and was pleased, though would have preferred reds for the last two dishes.

We started with the fresh bread and cultured butter which was totally delightful. The bread had a wonderful crust with a soft delicious inside and the butter was delectable. 

We all ordered the tasting menu which involves four courses and is totally worth it, and the price makes it an absolute must! For each course all members of the table can choose from four options which makes for a fun opportunity to mix and match. I am a lactose intolerant pescatarian and was delighted with the number of options I had to choose from which is rarely the case, especially for limited menus. I think this goes a long way to compliment the creativity of the chefs and dedication to local and fresh ingredients. 

I began with the Halibut which was a generous portion of fish, amazing pickled plum and shiso leaves which I love. The halibut was juicy and flaked off in plump bite size pieces packed with incredibly flavor. This was paired with a Sauvignon Blanc that was bright, smooth and really complemented the halibut and highlighted the shiso. 

Next was heirloom carrots with sunchokes, coconut and lime. This was simple but totally divine. The vegetables retained their hearty root nature despite being infused with incredible flavor making a great second dish. The sunchoke creaminess perfectly compliments the carrot crunchiness. 

My third dish was trout with nettle, snap peas and benne. Again, the fish was incredibly well prepared, retaining good moisture and fresh flavor with a delicate texture. I was particularly curious about the nettle though I enjoyed the dish together so much that I forgot to pick some out on its own. The wine pairing with this dish was a bit too sweet for my flavor. 

The final course is dessert for which our table ordered an assortment and shared (sometimes I defy my lactose troubles for the sake of deliciousness). The Oat Vacherin with honey and lavender was completely awesome, though I couldn't have very much of it. I specifically enjoyed the contrast of the oat chunks within the liquid lavendar/honey center. 
The milk chocolate custard, sorrel, basil was a tempting play on bittersweet and fragrant. I am a diehard basil fan which I think fueled my love for this dish. My dining mates agreed with the chocolate custard but were skeptical of the basil pairing but I found this a refreshing contrast well deserved. 
The final dessert we tried was the peach melba which was incredible. Absolutely vibrant and fresh flavor. 

Highly recommend Aster for a lovely evening, the four course tasting menu for a creative and delicious meal, and when it comes to the wine pairing, it's worth it just make sure to specify preferences!
author: Angela D.

description:
Get the $59 tasting menu. Great deal for the quality and service!

I came here with two friends so we got to try almost all the dishes. 

It's been too long to remember all the dishes but I remember the bread and butter was worth getting!
author: Daniela J.

description:
Holy crap Aster, your dinner was phenomenal. An affordable (by SF standards) 4 courses for $65, and every single dish was great. Wine pairings were a reasonable price (again, by SF standards) and well-curated with wines that brought out a lot of the subtle flavors of the food. 

There were thought-provoking dishes that melded together flavors that I wouldn't normally associate with each other, such as the persimmon, yuzu preserve, brown butter squash, yogurt, and arugula dish. There were others that provided soft and crunchy textures to an already well-done dish, like the soft boiled egg with puffed rice and ikura or the dry aged beef tartare with rice crisps and furikake. Then, there were the dishes that were just plain perfectly cooked, like the duck and the trout. I think I always avoid the trout at restaurants since it's such a bland, flavorless fish that is often overcooked, but after reading other people's reviews on here, I went out on a limb and ordered it.. no regrets. It was great!

I really hope they don't raise the prices like every good restaurant around here has been doing, because I would love to be able to come back again and again, and also to be able to recommend this to any out-of-town friends who are looking for a great meal that's representative of SF cuisine.
author: Kazu O.

description:
Aster is a super solid restaurant. All our dishes were well-prepared, with the exception of the kampachi appetizer, which I found to be a bit too fishy - like it wasn't entirely fresh. 

The potato dumplings (probably my most favorite dish) and the duck entrée, however, were both delicious. 

I finished off my meal with the frozen chocolate and bourbon meringue, and that too was yummy. 

You also can't beat their price: $65 for a four course prix fixe.

The reason I'm giving 4 stars and not 5, is partly because of the fish, but more because I didn't think the restaurant was SO amazing so as to warrant the Michelin star it has. 

So, Aster is a wonderful 5-star non-Michelin, and a great 4-star Michelin.
author: Erick T.

description:
Undoubtedly delicious four course menu. Only $59 per person, that's a steal! 

Super impressed with their service. No snootiness here!

Our food selection:

- Spring greens = avocado, seeds, kumquat, and honey-lime. Portion was generous. 

- Citrus-cured trout = fennel with sourdough crisp. The trout and citrus sauce was perfect.

- Soft-cooked egg = crispy potato, salmon roe, and bacon vinaigrette. 

- Potato dumplings = maitake mushroom and Brussels. SO DAMN GOOD!!

- Black cod = perfectly cooked, juicy, and soft. 

- Spiced duck = huge duck meat lover. LITERALLY TO DIE FOR!!! YUMMMMMMMY!

Dessert: 1) Contralto = goat cheese with boysenberry, poppy crisp and rye. 
                 2) Milk chocolate custard = an exciting refreshing dessert. I'm impressed!

Aster is a lovely dining experience with exciting menu. I highly recommend this place for date night or any occasion. 

I hope you give this amazingly delicious place a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description:
I came here for Valentine's day, and I loved it. 

The space is small, so make sure the make reservations! (and maybe ask for the side booths).  We sat at the long communal table in the middle, which was fine, (and the table is made of this gorgeous wood) BUT I could definitely hear the conversations to the left and right of me. I wanted to face palm when my fiance started talking to me about the same topic right after the people next to us started talking about it. Clearly, we were eavesdropping....

We had a 5 course meal, and since it was valentine's day, it was a set menu for over $120ish or so. This is almost double the normal menu price (granted the normal tasting menu has only 4 courses). Fine, it's valentine's day, I get it. Also, this was still cheaper than other michelin star's marked up Valentine's day dinners. So, overall, I think this would be a greaaat value at $65 for 4 courses. There was an appetizer supplement of uni that night. Of course I was super interested, and was pleasantly surprised that it would only be an additional $10, when I was expecting a heftier markup. (Hello Keiko a Nob Hill, asking me if I wanted to pay $50 for 'generous' shavings of truffle after letting me sniff it... no thank you... that's 1/3 of the price of the entire meal...)

Everything about the food was amazing, we had scallop for appetizer, beet salad, a mushroom farro type dish, trout and a chocolate mousse dessert. Also, the sourdough bread was amazing, and the butter, I couldn't resist. Though to be fair, the portions were light, so I did need to eat that piece of sourdough bread to fill myself up. 

Highly recommend, and would definitely come back again!
author: Cynthia X.

description:
I really enjoy dining at Aster. I've come here for brunch and dinner and both times were very enjoyable. Brunch is reasonably priced for SF and there's no lines, which is something I really like. Their service is great as well, so there's nothing not to like!

I really like the smoked salmon tartine that I tried for brunch once. It's quite small though so you'll most likely want to get something else otherwise it won't fill you. I also tried their lemon poppy pound cake, which was really good but soooooo sweet. There's no way one person can finish that entire dish. For dinner, it's more expensive but still quite enjoyable. 

I'd recommend coming here before more people find out about it!
author: Theresa L.

description:
This place is more like a 3.5.. The ambience, service, and overall dining experience was fantastic. The food was artfully prepared but in terms of overall flavor and cohesiveness was just alright for me.

We made a reservation for a Saturday evening a few weeks in advance and were seated at the end of the long community table in the center of the restaurant. We were right next to the open kitchen and it was nice watching some of the chefs preparing and plating food. Our server, Ricky, was very warm, engaging, and personable, and we enjoyed all of his recommendations. Here's what we got:

First course: 
Dry aged beef with sea urchin add on (5/5) - One of our favorite dishes of the night. The texture and flavor was beautiful; it tasted tart from the umeboshi but rounded out towards the end, if that makes sense...
Cucumber (3/5) - Good flavor and texture, but could have used a touch more sweetness...more nectarine or a little less yogurt perhaps. Just a tad bit bland. Wish we had gotten two beef tartares instead lol
Cured trout belly with charred avo and nori-togarashi (4/5) - This was an add-on, the skin was almost like a chicharrone and the whole dish was really beautiful and very tasty as well.
Sourdough bread (5/5) - This bread was so good, crusty and robust and overall just amazing; how can you go wrong with bread?!

Second course:
Soft cooked egg with sea urchin add on (3.5/5) - This was good but a bit too rich and heavy for my taste with the bacon..
Squid (4.5/5) - The squid had really good texture and all the flavors were very cohesive for this dish.

Third course
Trout (4.5/5) - I really loved this dish. The fish was cooked perfectly and the miso glaze was excellent, albeit a tad bit too salty (although I think it's hard for a miso marinated dish not to be very salty)
Lamb (3.5/5) - This dish had beautiful presentation, with the lamb prepared three ways. I didn't particularly care for one of the three types but I forget which one 

Fourth course
Strawberry (2.5/5) - We both really didn't care for this dish, it came with some weirdly flavored marshmallow-looking things and overall just tasted kind of meh.
Chocolate custard (5/5) - Smooth, rich, and overall just beautiful. 

Overall most of the food was just okay. I was pretty impressed by the presentation of the food and especially by the dishware. While the service was good, eventually another couple was seated next to us and our server wasn't able to give us as much attention as I was hoping for. Aster is a good place to try but if I were a tourist visiting SF I wouldn't go out of my way to eat it, as it seems some people have done. This was my first experience eating at a Michelin restaurant, and while I thoroughly enjoyed it, I probably won't be back for awhile.
author: Elaine W.

description:
Thanks to Eater San Francisco. Debated over a few interesting places to eat. But we're glad we chose to try out Aster. 
Booked dinner for my husband and I. As you walk in the door, the receptionist greats you and seats you. It's a nice small space, cozy, cool rope lighting in the ceiling which deceived us a little bit. Try to see what it is.
Food: full of flavor, amazing combination of ingredients that blends well and compliment each other. Market greens, octopus and pork loin will satisfy your taste buds. 
A nice night to start our vacation in San Francisco.
author: Digna B.

description: Guess what? I can sous-vide some eggs at 63 degrees Celsius too. This shouldn't be the focus of a dish in a 4 course tasting menu. I go out to eat b/c I want to experience ingredients I don't have access to, using techniques (or generally cookery) that is superior to the home cook in me. Aster fell quite short of my expectations, and its own accolades.
author: J. B.

description:
I visited here with my honey for dinner.  Pluses from the evening was the attentive service from out waiter and management.   My partner and I decided on the four course meal.  I ordered the   raw beef with gooseberries, potato dumplings, pork, and frozen chocolate.

Though we were able to be seated earlier than our reservation, after we placed our order, the first course took too long to come out. Our waiter acknowledged this with apologizes.  When  it arrived, I though the play on raw beef on a puff chip was excellent.  I thought the gooseberries were picked tomatoes, which our server informed me it was gooseberries.  What a great fruit that I will need to start buying it. It added a sweet and sour component to the dish that I enjoyed.   

The potato dumpling was like a gnocchi.  Fluffly and airy in texture, but heavy in the sauce. Quite a filling second dish.  

My pork dish was tasty. The pork tenderloin was tender and the pork belly pinwheel was a surprise.  As I was eating my dish I found a piece of plastic in it.  I informed my server and he asked if I wanted another dish or the same. I chose the same.   When the second dish came, it the dish was perfect.  Great flavors from the pork and the potatoes. Heavy and savory.

When desert came, we were served the desserts we ordered plus the coconut toffee tart as an  apology from the restaurant.   From the poached pear that my honey ordered. The frozen chocolate and the  coconut toffee tart, I thought the tart was the best of the three. The flavor of  the coffee bleed through the coconut and it was enjoyable.  The frozen chocolate was good, but I would recommend the tart.

Our server was really attentive. And the way management handled the plastic in the plate was excellent.   I will look forward to coming back to Aster anytime and recommend to my friends.
author: Marck N.

description: Fine experience. Cool interior. One of the wine pairings was sake, did not enjoy it much. However, the rest was good. Did not feel much special, maybe I expected too much.
author: Al L.

description:
I don't know how to describe this place better than saying 'pretentious'. Food is very good, well balanced and very well presented. The space inside is designed for great pictures and selfies and apparently you can't work in the restaurant if you don't show off your tattoos. 

The idea is clear and unescapable, you need to have the tasting menu or you'll be disappointed by the portions and the final check. If crowded it doesn't feel like you're having the best experience anyway due to the seating map and setup - essentially is a big long room.

Service is good, but as many times in the city, you'll find the attendant pissed off because your facial expressions betray no religious enlightenment while she's reciting you the menu. 

It should've been 4.5 stars, but it's 3.5.
author: Florentin H.

description:
Love everything we had... tried almost everything on the menu except quiche... in small bites I like everything but the star was smoked sturgeon and andante goat cheese.

In savory ... duck confit is to die for... rest everything was also brilliant representation of clean flavors...

In sweet ... coconut-puffed grain granola was killer... pudding and sweet potato waffle was also memorable... so all in all great experience
author: Manish T.

description:
3.5 stars. 

4 stars for food and value. Great presentation. Solid ingredients and great value for tasting menu. 

3 stars for ambience. A bit too bright with the blinding overhead lights. And the music is rock n roll with Tommy petty and Blondie, more for a beer place than a setting for classy tasting menu in SF. 

Most dishes are solid. I was not impressed with the wine pairing - skip it and pick your own. Out of the wine offered, I really liked the Hexamer Riesling from Germany. Very balanced. A hint of sweetness at the end. The roederer estate rose bubbly was quite good. Do not take the sweet wine pairing with the contralto cheese (just didn't pair well). If you are looking for rules of thumb on cheese wine pairing, read this article on Atlanta magazine: 

http://www.atlantamagazine.com/dining-news/high-on-the-vine-how-to-pair-wine-cheese/

In general, these Sauternes or sweet wine pairs best with blue cheese. I did a bit of research after the waiter mentioned that this is the typical pairing with contralto, and saw that even though Soyoung (the cheese maker) said that Sauternes is one wine that pairs generally across her cheeses, there are nuances of individual wines that pair well with each cheese (on her website) and white Burgundy tends to pair well with creamy goat cheese with the acidity cutting through the fatty tones of the creamy cheese.  

Onto the food...

Here are the best dishes:
Pork shoulder - very tender. Nice carrot sauce that adds color and vivacity to the flavor. Save your stomach for this dish though.

Beets - a bit of cameralization adds complexity. 

Solid dishes:
Lamb - lamb loin was of great quality. Order this only if you have the stomach for it and love strong gamy flavor of lamb

Potato dumpling - delicate. Love the vibrant green color of the Brussels sprouts, the subtle yet intense flavor of maitake mushroom, and the texture on the potato dumping. Quite buttery - I think that this dish can benefit from more acidity. Ask for a slice of lemon and try it out. 

Contralto - I am a bit torn about this cheese since the wine pairing wasn't on point. I will try it again with white burgundy. I don't think that the cracker is the best way to serve this cheese. Fresh bread (non sourdough) is probably better to absorb the creaminess of the cheese. 

Hokkaido squash soup - hearty but not exceptional. Again, I would add a bit of lemon to brighten up the flavor. Like the crunch that they have added to the soup. 

Skip:
Hazelnut gateau - a bit sweet for my taste and fell flat
Sourdough - if you are ordering tasting menu. It will fill you up and make you loose appetite for the other dishes
Sprouted grains - a bit too earthy for the first course.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Came here as it seem liked every Michelin 3 Star restaurants were booked solid on a last min SF getaway. 

Nevertheless, we settled on Aster, it is a Michelin 1 Star, which if you do not know the scale, isn't like a 1 Star Hotel, it's an elite restaurant at 1 Star. 

I had the 4 Course Tasting Menu, I think it was $65 ...it was:
MARKET GREENS & HERBS, AVOCADO, SEEDS, MANDARIN, HONEY-LIME

POTATO DUMPLINGS, BLACK TRUMPET, CAULIFLOWER, PINE NUT, SAGE 

TROUT, ARTICHOKE, SHELLING BEANS, ORO BLANCO, PRESERVED MEYER LEMON

COCONUT COFFEE TART, WINTER SQUASH, LIME


I'd say the coursing took a little longer than normal but not too long. It was a pretty crowded night so considering that it was fair. 

The food was incredible. If you have ever had an experience like this, you should!
author: Mike H.

description:
I dined here last night with my partner for our anniversary. Without exaggeration, there couldn't have been a more perfect meal to celebrate the evening.

Well in advance, my partner requested that we not be seated at the communal table. We had a cozy two top right next to another couple celebrating their anniversary as well -- a happy coincidence.

We opted to buy a bottle of wine instead of doing the wine pairings. Our server, Ricky, was very knowledgeable about the offerings and recommended a Furmint, a white from Hungary that had a great price point and that we both enjoyed very, very much.

For the tasting menu, our highlights were the dry aged beef, the squid, the green farro and the chocolate custard dessert. If I could have a meal comprised entirely of the chocolate custard dessert, I would -- sublimely sweet caramel ice cream, coconut mochi pieces and toasted coconut topped with fresh fennel. I'm not normally a star of anise flavor but every bite was delectable.

On our way out we took the opportunity to thank the chef/owner, Brett Cooper, for making our anniversary meal spectacular. As a sweet gesture, they had given us a complementary dish of a citrusy sorbet atop an omebushi compote that was a refreshing palate cleanser between courses. Brett was very warm and gracious and bid us to come back again soon.

With such great service, a spectacular variety of dishes and a ton of flavors, we will definitely be visiting again (and bringing friends along with us)!
author: Bianca P.

description:
Pretty good but not amazing. A good price point for a 4-course tasting menu, and I also did the wine pairing. First two dishes (cucumber and shellfish) were absolutely beautiful, and taste was very good. Main (lamb) was ok - it looked better than it tasted to me. That said I was with someone who has a much more sophisticated palette than I do and he thought the parts of the lamb dish I didn't like were great, so it may be just me. I didn't like my dessert at all (cocoa nib financier) because it tasted more like a caprese salad than a dessert, but switched my date for his strawberry dish which was mind blowing amazing with mixed textures and temperatures. Other than the sake (which is a personal preference), the wine pairings were great. 

The ambiance was higher end casual, in heels I felt overdressed. Nice lighting and the long communal table is nice. 

Service was fantastic. All people in the establishment were helping out, friendly, knowledgeable and made the night enjoyable overall. 

Likely won't go back but it's worth a try for sure.
author: Caitlyn M.

description:
It seems as though people haven't had positive experiences at Aster, but I had a fantastic time at dinner awhile back! Having heard a lot about Aster, and its recent inclusion on SF's Michelin List for 2016, I wanted to make sure that I gave it a fair shake before writing it off as a place to try but not in a hurry to get to.  In coming here with my in-laws, and knowing how hard it can be to sometimes come to a consensus on what to eat, Aster's four course menu option at $59/person seemed like the best way to go so that everyone could be satisfied with their meal.  That being said, it was pretty amusing that we all generally gravitated towards the same menu items save dessert. Since full participation is required by all parties at the table for the four course menu, we did our best to cover as much ground as possible. In any case, here's what went down that evening among the four of us:

Appetizers (I):
Chicories, Olive, Early Girl Tomato & Buttermilk
Chilled Golden Beet Soup with Mussels, Pistachio Crumble, Dill

I had the chicories salad and was a little hesitant about the inclusion of olives (not a huge fan) but actually this was really delicious and light! The tomatoes break up the saltiness of the salad, so it actually turned out to being a very well-balanced dish!

Appetizers (II):
Potato-Caraway Dumplings, Maitake, Brussels, Yogurt
Sweetbreads with Pickled Summer Squash, Charred Peppers, Thyme
Sourdough bread

I absolutely loved the dumplings! I tried a half of the sweetbreads dish, and to be totally honest, I was annoyed that I had forfeited half of the dumplings dish for the sweetbreads.  The soft, pillow-y dumplings were fantastic, and the yogurt sauce that came with it was money. The sourdough bread that came was also incredible, and the presentation of the softened butter on the plate was genius since we were sharing. 

Mains:
Trout with Tokyo Turnip, Grapes, Charred Scallion, Brown Butter
Pork Shoulder with Sweet Potato, Umeboshi, Grilled Bok Choy

I didn't get around to trying the trout, but the pork shoulder was good! It was a little on the small side for a main, so if you're looking for a hefty entree, be prepared. The pork was presented in little cubes/bite-sized, and was definitely pretty to look at.

Dessert:
Pink Lady Apple with Brioche, Sunflower Seed, Shiso
Frozen Yogurt with Concord Grape, Sourdough
Chocolate Ganache with Black Caramel and Cocoa Nib

I had the frozen yogurt, and I couldn't be more surprised when the dish came out and it was totally not what I was expecting! The concord grapes and jelly that came with the yogurt (which was presented in a square!) was delicious and definitely something that I had never tasted before!  Things were going well until I saw that my father-in-law had ordered the chocolate ganache, and had a small bit of regret when I saw how beautiful the plate was.  He definitely enjoyed the chocolate ganache but said that the black caramel was something he didn't really enjoy since it was a little too bitter.

Overall, we really enjoyed the meal at Aster, and service wise, everything came out in a timely manner and our server was very helpful in assisting us with the navigation of the menu.  The restaurant itself wasn't overly busy, but I felt like we had just enough attention paid to us and not overwhelming at the same time.  I would definitely like to visit Aster again, and I would like select the four course menu option as well since I think this was the best way to try as much as possible and not run the risk of being uncomfortably full.
author: Lisa I.

description: This was a hard review to put a star rating on because by all accounts, the food was good.  The halibut with berries was fantastic, as was the frozen peach mousse dessert.  The other courses were all good to great, and creative elements throughout.  My hang up, like many other recent reviews, is the new price tag.  To spend almost $500 for two people (after drinks, tax, tip), every course should have been spectacular.  You can have a meal that is as good or better for half the price all over the Bay Area.  It may not have the detail and attentiveness that the full staff offers at Aster, but I don't think we'll be back for as long as the 7-course tasting is the only offering.  At the end of the day, I think there's a reason this is the only Michelin-star restaurant in SF (that I've seen) that you can just walk into and get a table any time of night, and would be excited to see Aster revert back to the more accessible menu/price point that earned them the notoriety in the first place.
author: Daniel V.

description:
We loved our meal at aster ! The plates and pricing are great given the quality of the food. The medley of lamb was a particular highlight. Only slightly weak dish was the desert of raspberry ice over fruit. Flavorful but just not as good as the prior courses - which I have to say were fantastic. 

Service was super knowledgeable and on point. The place is casual and enjoyable. Not too big but still has great atmosphere. 

Definitely check out if you have a chance.
author: Stu K.

description: I went to Aster this evening for dinner, and the food was good! 4 stars good, however the service was horrible. In fact, the worst service I've ever had. We made reservations for 4 and a baby. We requested a high chair, however when I arrived at the restaurant with my 14 month baby girl, I was greeted with appalled looks from the hostess and uncomfortable stares from the waitstaff. She was upset and confused on why I would bring my baby and a stroller. She continued to ask me, why I didn't make a note in the reservation that I would have a stroller. She even scolded me. I have never been treated this way at a restaurant for bringing my baby and a stroller. The waitstaff stared and treated my baby like she was an alien. Like they have never seen a baby before. I have to mention, my baby did not cry during the entire evening, nor was she disruptive. I will NEVER return to this restaurant. And I would suggest anyone who has children not to bring their children to this restaurant. This restaurant should make it very clear that it is NOT kid-friendly because it isn't. In fact, if you bring your child to this restaurant, they will make you feel incredibly uncomfortable, so uncomfortable that you can not enjoy the delicious food. There are so many restaurants in San Francisco where the food is just as good and just as expensive with incredible service.
author: Ooh K.

description: The strawberry dessert with the Moscato was absolutely incredible, and I'm not even a strawberry or a dessert fan. Some of the other dishes felt a little too salty for me, but I'd come back just for the strawberry dessert and Moscato.
author: Theodora C.

description:
Where do I even begin? Oh, I know. Like Kin Khao, they don't deserve their Michelin star. Full disclosure: I went a few months ago. I was so upset about the experience that I decided to wait until I calmed down to write a review. 

My co worker and I popped in for dinner on a weekday night. We are both serious foodies and were wondering what the hype was about. I had, hands down, the worst experience, I've ever had at a restaurant. 

Between the 2 of us, we ordered the beef, salad, soft-cooked egg, the potato dumplings, duck, a fish entree,  the frozen chocolate, another dessert, and bread. We both also each had a glass of wine. 

The food was clearly not memorable, as I have already forgotten a few of the dishes. They tasted ok, but nothing that made me feel like I would come back to try more or have the same thing again. 

The service is truly the reason why I decided to write this review. The restaurant is not well lit. This is the type of place where people might hold a candle up to the menu or have their phone flashlight on in order to read the menu. I had ordered a darker sparkling rose. After drinking half of the glass, and was halfway through with my duck entree, I finally actually looked at my wine and saw that there was a black thing floating in my glass. Because the glass opening was smaller than my spoon, I decided to use my fingers to fish the black thing out. Turns out, it was a dead beetle. Yup, a beetle. The server served me a dead beetle with my wine. I stared at the dead beetle, now sitting on my duck plate, for a few good minutes due to shock before attempting to call our server over. He was nowhere to be found. Luckily(?), we sat close to the hostess. She just kept staring at me, as I had a look of horror on my face. After 5 minutes, she decided to approach to ask what was wrong. I pointed out the dead beetle, and she whisked my plate and wine glass away. 

To make a long story short, I never had a chance to finish my duck, nor did I want to eat much more after the experience. The glass was also taken away, and never replaced with something else. The server was never notified of the issue.. He only found out 15 minutes later, after I informed him. He never apologized. I asked to see a manager about this, and only saw the manager after another 10 minutes. The manager, like the server, didn't offer an apology. Instead, she said it was the winery's fault. I don't care that it was the winery's fault. You served me the wine. There was never any effort made to rectify the situation, like offering me another glass of wine because I never finished my glass in the first place. 

Even at a McDonald's, if you found a hair or an insect in the food, they would offer to make you a new sandwich or whatever, no questions asked. This restaurant has a Michelin star. There is clearly no communication or training on what should be done in a situation like this. Both the server and manager were like deer in the headlights. 

Thank you, but no thank you, Aster. I will not be back and I've been telling all my friends to never come to this restaurant. I understand that the beetle may not have been your fault, but it is your responsibility to not serve it, or apologize if you did serve it. Neither of which was done. And even if the beetle situation didn't happen, the food was not Michelin star quality. There are far better restaurants in the city where you can spend your money and not regret it.
author: Carolyn Z.

description:
Chef Brett Cooper has such an impressive culinary pedigree (Rubicon, Coi, Saison, Outerlands... Outerlands?) that it would have been near-to-impossible for him to fail in this relatively new venture under the auspices of Daniel Patterson (Coi). Jamie W. decided to take me here for my birthday even though he probably could have gone for a burrito bowl at Chipotle given what he perceived to be a persnickety approach to the dishes. I certainly won't argue the meticulous nature of the presentations, but thankfully Cooper has managed to balance most of the bold flavors he and his staff blend together on each plate. Our challenge, and perhaps it was a petty one, was the smallness of the portions.

Understand I was raised by a dad who constantly took us to "All You Can Eat" cafeterias because he was always looking to maximize his money even if the lasting impact was the bottomless pit of my stomach. Even with this in mind, it made sense to go for the $59 four-course dinner for me, while Jamie ordered two plates even if it meant a couple of bites a piece for both of us on a couple of shared plates. He first started with the $12 Chilled Golden Beet Soup, which required the server to present the supporting ingredients - mussels, pistachio and dill - naked in a bowl before she poured the soup (photo: http://bit.ly/1je7vBJ). It was a confusing preamble to a luxuriant ladle of soup. Yes, it was tasty.

Mine came next, the $13 Duck Liver Mousse which was almost completely hidden by a passel of fennel marinated with sesame, sprouted grains that tasted like wheat kernels and a strawberry coulis (photo: http://bit.ly/1Onhame). Bits of actual duck were mixed in to give the dish a bit more savory heft. Very good and gone in about two minutes. We decided to share the $17 Sweetbreads which were given a surprising deep-fried treatment and covered with a pickled summer squash relish mixed with charred peppers and thyme (photo: http://bit.ly/1R0C9bX). The consistency of the sweetbreads was perfect, but given my druthers, I would have preferred them more naked and less Southern in treatment.

Entrees came next, and here is where the meal started to pay off more discernibly. Jamie ordered the $24 Pork Shoulder with sweet potato, creamed rhubarb, and grilled bok choy, and it was a savory hit in a more satisfying portion (photo: http://bit.ly/1hrOQAo). Mine was even better, the $27 Milk-Fed Lamb, which was prepared three ways and accompanied by pole & shelling beans, smoked eggplant and nepitella (an Italian mint herb) (photo: http://bit.ly/1LmX6tu). That was a masterful dish beautifully prepared with the grilled lamb roulade particularly winning. I got a dessert with my meal, so we shared the $12 Chocolate Ganache, two small blocks of dark chocolate and an unbelievably creamy dollop of white chocolate, with black caramel and cocoa nibs (photo: http://bit.ly/1jaGkXT).

It was a strong finish to an impressive meal that was only curtailed by misjudged portion control. I forgot to describe the ambiance, which was deceptively casual in spite of the price points. The strings of lights on the ceiling were another source of deception but in a good way in the way they reflected in the mirrors. We were seated in the central communal table which fortunately didn't crowd up until we were finishing our meal. A particularly affectionate couple locked hands as if they were ready to arm wrestle despite the broadness of he table width. Jamie and I were not nearly as demonstrative. An occasional wave sufficed until we left the restaurant into the wilds of the Mission.

FOOD - 4 stars...a strong finish with the lamb and the ganache helping to overcome our marginal disappointment at the paltry portions
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...casual considering the price point, a bit loud judging by the cackling hen party behind us
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...efficient, not overly intrusive
TOTAL - 4 stars...Cooper has talent on display here, still think there could be refinements and maybe an extra sweetbread or two on the plate
author: Ed U.

description:
First time to Aster last night. The portion sizes were great, pauses were adequate. All dishes were great except the artichoke main dish.
I did not try the wine paring but got my own Pino.
I will definitely come back.
author: Mitali K.

description:
I really need to make it over here for dinner, but I will say that their brunch is superb!!

You walk in, and it's kind of a small place but when you sit down you realize they've actually organized the place so you don't feel cramped and too close to the table next to you. There is a large community table in the center which feels nice and "homey" as well.

They serve four barrel coffee. Nuff said. You don't go into a restaurant expecting to have some of the best coffee in town, you expect great food and mediocre coffee (at best) but it's was brewed perfectly! I decided to get the duck confit which not only tasted amazing but looked beautiful as well. I've never seen poached eggs look so beautiful in my life. Started off with the smoked black cod on a cute little pancake. You might think it to be odd but it was such a good flavor combination. Also, you must have the sourdough with salted butter and dark chocolate shavings on top. Perfection.

The last thing I would talk about would be the service. I've been here twice and both times the service was amazing. If you're ever headed this way and make a reservation, I recommend sitting in Nell's section. She was constantly coming over and asking how everything was, very talkative and extremely nice. Great experience overall and I'll be coming back soon :)
author: Jean-Luc D.

description:
We had a celebratory dinner with friends at Aster and it was worth it.  It's definitely an expensive meal but we enjoyed our overall experience and our waiter was great.

We did the four course menu with the wine pairings and added in the sourdough bread for good measure.  Since there were four of us and there were four options in each section we ordered the entire menu.  And everything was delicious.  The early girl tomato, local halibut, soft cooked egg and trout were some of my favorites.

Aster is a great spot for a fancy meal with your loved one or your friends/family.
author: Blake B.

description: The food is good, but not extraordinary for the price.I thought the bread was over salted.If it were not for the great dessert, this place deserves one star.Some of the servers appear arrogant, like they're doing you a favor by serving you.The hostess at the front desk was borderline rude.The bathroom sucks.Overall the atmosphere is stuffy and makes you uncomfortable.Never coming back.
author: Anna S.

description: Had New Year's Eve dinner at Aster. They offered a five course tasting menu, everything was delicious, adding their first class service and well decorated space, it was a perfect night. I would give them 6 stars if I could!
author: Carol Y.

description:
The food - 
Bread was incredible, heartier than expected for sourdough and house made butter was rich and milky.
Duck Liver Mousse - Light, rich and creamy with pieces of lamb hearts. It didn't come with anything to spread it on but I spread it on the bread. Not a fan of the wheat berries which threw off the texture.
Sweetbreads - Crispy chickpea (?) flour coating, fatty. Okay, I've had better.
Milk Fed Lamb - Done a few ways. Some pieces were tough while other cuts were chewier. Just okay. The braised cabbage was amazingly seasoned and the best part of this dish. 
Chocolate Ganache - Dense, chewy and dark but not remarkable. Usually not big on sweets but the caramel had deep burnt flavor and was the highlight.

Service is kind of strange. We were seated at the communal table despite there being a two person table that remained unoccupied the entirety of our time there. The server was mostly attentive and genial.

The food came out in bursts and it took over two hours to get served all four courses - not the waitstaff's fault but seems the kitchen is understaffed. Kitchen crew looked kind of heads down and stressed out. The bread (which they charge $5 extra for) held us over between courses, without it I may have been left hungry at the end of the meal.

I had a few bites of my friend's selections as well.
Scallops - subtly, well seasoned. One of the best.
Soft baked egg - runny yolk with some random vegetables.
Trout - really good texture, soft and buttery but fully cooked. I regretted not getting this as my main instead.

The most memorable part was the bread which was off the hook and costs extra. The food was pretty mediocre compared to other restaurants of the same caliber. Duck mousse was also really tasty. With stiff competition on the scene, Aster is not disappointing but won't knock your socks off either.
author: Truc N.

description: Was in town for a business trip and treated myself to a nice meal. I opted for the 4-course menu ($65/person) which consisted of trout, octopus, duck and frozen chocolate for dessert. The couple sitting next to me at the communal table (regulars) suggested I get the octopus appetizer, which was nice, but I have say my favorite parts of the meal were the trout appetizer and frozen chocolate dessert. Every dish was beautifully plated and my server was attentive and offered wine-pairing suggestions. Since I'm not from the area, I probably won't be back but I will suggest this place to others.
author: Kim C.

description:
This review is for the lack of communication from the restaurant. We had reservations for several weeks and were excited to try Aster. When we got to the restaurant tonight we found a sign on the door saying that they were closed tonight and tomorrow without notice. We did not get a phone call nor an email to let us know that it would be closed. We had checked their website before leaving to see the menu options and there was no mention of the restaurant being closed this weekend. It was going to be a very special evening but needless to say, Aster's lack of service was a huge disappointment.  I would expect better from a Michelin restaurant.

Sadly can't say much about the food at Aster since we never even got to try it.
author: L Y.

description: I was surprised by how underwhelming the Yelp reviews are of Aster since it got a Michelin rating but I decided to check it out recently and I'd have to agree with the overall ratings. I'd give the food and service 4 stars but the wine was terrible so 3 stars for that. Overall, the food was well prepared, but it was lacking any sort of surprise or "x factor" that made it exciting. It was a solid decent meal but didn't have the innovation I'd like to see. I felt the value was great, it's hard to get any kind of solid meal in this city for $75 anymore. But the food just didn't have much flavor! Sadly, it's not a place I'd return to, something is just missing here.
author: Eater S.

description: The dry aged beef tartar and the white guava frozen yogurt were the most memorable. Service was excellent as well.
author: Janet K.

description:
This review is for brunch only:

I have yet to try Aster's 4-course dinner menu, but I did try their brunch, and as delicious as the food is, I can't justify the quantity for some of their "shareables."

I've been to my share of fancy restaurants in SF and I've seen some small portions, but I've never seen anything less shareable than the two plates at Aster. Their buttermilk biscuits with bacon and honey butter was delicious, but the tiniest bits of biscuits I have ever seen. The two biscuits are barely bite sized. The fava toast with roe was equally delicious, but maybe an inch in diameter. Both dishes were $6. Does that mean I'm paying $3 for 1 in x 1 in piece of bread? The answer is yes. 

The regular dishes are by no means huge but perfectly respectable in size. I enjoyed both my quiche and the sweet potato and bacon hash waffles. 

Service was simply lovely. Our waiter made simple syrup for me and accommodated different milk requests. They were also very friendly and checked in frequently to make sure our dishes arrived promptly. For that I'm bumping up the review to 3 stars.

tl;dr: delicious food, great service, unforgivable tiny portions for shareable dishes.
author: Kate M.

description:
Came here for brunch with some friends. The service was average, not very warm at all. The ambiance was rustic and felt like simple coffee shop like Siteglass. 

The food portions were small and overpriced. Example? I got the crispy puffed grains dish, with was puffed cereal, yogurt, strawberry, thai basil...for $12. It was uneventful, and something I could put together at home for less than $5 and darn tastier.

My friends got the avocado on rye ($17 for four small pieces), over easy egg (one egg, grits and some veggies for $17!)  and sweet potato and apple hash (that all for $14). No one raved about their meal. The conversation was much more enjoyable. 

Maybe the dinner is better, but I was floored at the food, service, atmosphere to be deemed a Michelin, as well as top place to have brunch. 

Bottom line, save your wallet and time and take your brunch somewhere in the city.
author: Sonia A.

description: I am sitting here eating gastronomic delights.  Not my thousandth rodeo. Ethereal superlatives. What I want for my last meal.
author: Philip K.

description:
Not sure why the reviews are so low- my partner and I had a wonderful time here together. Four course meal was filling and more than worth the money. Honestly for a Michelin restaurant, we were surprised at the affordability (especially with portion size AND the fact that it was four courses!!!) Between the two of us, we also got the sourdough bread with house butter (delicious and definitely will help fill ya up,) and the Duchesse de Bourgourgone beer and a Mission IPA. The menu does change seasonally, and I think the summer's got everyone down beat-- everything felt and tasted so fresh that I can't see why people complain!

I got:
Halibut for the first course which was cured or smoked and tasted delicious. The shiso and cucumber were great additions to brightening up what could have been a heavy first dish. 
Potato dumplings for the second course, which im surprised wasn't more filling but done up right. There was a sprinkling of cheese and lots of beans which freshened the meal more.
Spiced duck for my main which was HUGE and also included pulled confit duck leg as an accent. I had to get my boyfriend to finish this up for me because the duck breast portion was HUMONGOUS by this time.
The oat vacherin was my dessert and was wonderful and delicious. If you want a heavier dessert but enjoy floral notes (if you're a gin drinker, you will like this dessert,) this was right on par. I loved the oat tuile cookie as the edge and the ice cream and cake on the inside was also a wonderful way to end the meal

The boyfriend got the:
Summer squash to start with. It had peppery/almost warm curry taste to it but felt light and unbelievably fresh. I wished I would have gotten this starter too.
His next dish was the chilled green garlic soup which was very citrusy and light- he enjoyed it! I had a small taste and very much liked it.
His main was the trout which was done up very simply, to showcase how fresh the trout was. He lapped it all up and he enjoyed it. (I had a bite and the skin was so crispy and delicious!)
His dessert, the mint chocolate custard was also delicious. Very fresh without feeling too chocolatey and dense. (Yes, we share everything lol.)

We will be back to Aster, as we live around the corner. Honestly can't believe how long it's take. For us to try this place!
author: Christa Lei S.

description: Two of us came in for a Sunday dinner. We made reservations in advance. We were seated at the communal table, which is fine, but not ideal. The restaurant is small and well appointed. Tasting menu looked fantastic, and we could choose different dishes each. Everything was fantastic. Also a great wine list both by the glass and bottle. Everything about the meal was perfection. The pricing wasn't as crazy as it could have been, but it's not inexpensive by any means.
author: Jonah K.

description: We had dinner at Aster last night to celebrate our anniversary and have to say the food was delicious, the atmosphere was wonderful and the wait staff was amazing. Thank you for a wonderful experience, we will be  back.
author: Randall R.

description: I've got back twice already since then. Was I imagining the cocktails before? In any case, still amazing. My favorite.
author: Laurie N.

description:
We made a reservation for two for a special occasion at this place. We are both vegetarian, and normally, we skip over places with such limited menus because we enjoy ordering a bunch of different dishes and sharing everything. But we'd heard good things and wanted to give it a try. We ordered the house sourdough and butter and our choices for the four course tasting were as follows (copied from the menu):
Market greens (avocado, toasted seeds, blackberry, honey-lime)
Matsutake (cabbage, apple, garlic)
Green Farro (peas, ramps, sheep's milk ricotta, nasturtium) 
Strawberry (chamomile, lemon, sesame, coriander)
Frozen Yogurt (berries, honey, Szechuan pepper) 

We also shared wine pairing.  Service was excellent, as one expects in a Michelin starred restaurant. There were a few service mishaps (wine pairing brought out late, mixed up dessert order) but they acknowledged and corrected mistakes immediately. 

As everyone has stated, get the bread. It's wonderful as is the salted butter that it comes with. We loved the salad. It was perfectly balanced in taste and in texture. The mushroom dish was great in that it highlighted the matsutakes, but it was pretty one note overall. The farro was good-- very green and fresh tasting, but we were disappointed because we prefer a slightly creamier preparation of farro and had been anticipating that. They were very kind and brought a small rice milk frozen treat with a candle to celebrate on the house. The desserts themselves were okay-- very complex and not cloying, but also not amazing enough that we kept wanting more (which is sort of a key indicator of whether we liked something or not). 

Overall? We liked it, but it felt like the food was high concept and we just couldn't appreciate it.  We'd recommend to our friends that eat meat and want a slightly more affordable fine-dining experience.
author: T K.

description:
San Francisco,

I hate that I love you. 

As my birth city and a city that I adore for its diversity, awesome eats, and liberalness (hello, bare butt cheeks in the castro) but the gentrification is just getting out of hand. From $7 beer in a plastic pee pee cup, $15 sammies, to a $49 million condo (yes, it exists: http://bit.ly/1CsQQ1V). For pete's sake, my parking space at work has gone up $90 a month and when I step out of my car, there's a pool of used needles on the floor and a drunk hobo offering me a sip of his 40. Sorry, dude...not before 7 am but maybe at happy hour?

When it comes to food, I know no boundaries...as long as it's good, I don't mind splurging. For date night, I picked Aster, the new restaurant that opened last week in the old Beast And The Hare space from the Daniel Patterson Group (Coi, Plum, Alta CA). The New American menu is small and focused with 3 small bites ($4-$6), 4 apps ($14-$17), 4 entrees ($27-$34), and 3 desserts ($12). Wines by the glass was about $12-$42. Prices included tip but not tax. 

Our waiter recommended that each person order one dish from each category but $200 for a regular date night was too spendy so we ordered 1 small bite, 1 app, and 1 dessert to share, and we each ordered our own entrée. Portions are tiny for the high prices but we didn't leave hungry. If you have large appetite, I would plan for a second dinner: 20 piece McD nuggets for $5. FTW!

We started with the Pig Croquettes ($6) had an uber soft gelatinous center with a nice, crunchy crust: http://bit.ly/1CsQQ1V. Good amuse bouche-type starter. 

Everything we had after that was underwhelming. Nothing was remotely bad but when compared to all the other brand new restaurants we visited this year (BDK, Sous Beurre Kitchen, Dragon Beaux, Liholiho, Al's Place, Cockscomb, Californios, and The Progress) nothing stood out. 

The Cold Smoked Trout ($17) was ok but I wish there was more smoke essence: http://bit.ly/1DbLCJp. My Black Pepper-Potato Dumpling entrée ($27) was like a pan-fried gnocchi: http://bit.ly/1xWSjPd. Mr. NSS' Lamb Shoulder entrée ($33) was tender but minuscule and way overpriced: http://bit.ly/1CbUjys. It reminded me of a braised beef dish we had at their sister restaurant, Alta CA except this was $10 more and half the portion. =/

For dessert, we shared the Strawberry w/ cultured cream ($12) which was light and refreshing but nothing earth shattering: http://bit.ly/1aCkJUt.

I washed everything down with a glass of the Hobo Cab ($15) and the La Rioja Tempranillo ($15). The latter was wonderful and highly recommended. 

Service was polite but there were some kinks as to be expected with any new restaurant. Our waiter was very friendly but went MIA after we received our order that we had to request a knife from the manager (?), and ordered dessert from the hostess. 

Contemporary rustic space with track lighting. Good for small groups only but there is a large communal table (fits 12) which I believe are for walk-ins. 

Parking is horrible in the area but there's a parking lot 2.5 blocks away on 21st and Bartlett. 

I feel bad for just giving 3 stars but the prices were too high for underwhelming food. I forgot to mention, it was $5 for a 6 ounce glass of soda filled with 90% ice. 

AND, Mr. NSS, had the balls to order two!

No wonder he said, it was my turn to pay...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Amazing food.. $75 Course meal is so worth it.. delicious. I give it a 5 stars .. great service . Very clean .. excellent waitresses .
author: Anna A.

description:
Never went to The Beauty And The Beast And The Hare And The Tortoise so don't have comparisons.

M.Aster
+ Lamb Shoulder $33
+ Delta Asparagus $16
+ Pigs Head Croquettes $6
+ Server's Menu Knowledge
+ Oneida Silverware
+ Hanging Tinker Toys
+ Forearm Tat Culture
+ Wavvy Track Lighting

Dis.Aster
- Iced Coffee Not Allowed
- Napkin Style
- Serving Sizes Kinda
- Squirmy Toddler

Rounding up to 4 bc food flavors.
author: Dan B.

description:
My first Michelin star meal in San Francisco.
The food is really creative, with elements from American, Japan and Taiwan. We ordered the 4 courses menu, and Duck impressed me. Only one thing I am not happy with was that we were charged $5 for the bread without being notified.
Overall it's a decent restaurant and we had a great time for dinner there.
author: Zack L.

description:
After a long day of searching for a nice restaurant to go to for dinner, I was disappointed after having my last meal of the day at this place. 
   To begin, my friend and I were warmly greeted by the nice hostess who allowed up to dine without a reservation (S/O to him). Once we were seated, the waitress came to our table immediately to take drink orders and to ask us if we had any questions. Throughout our meal, the service was very quick and the staff was courteous. I would give them a 5/5 for service without a doubt. 
   Now to the food. I can say the best thing we had was the appetizer. We ordered the potato dumplings (which do not resemble anything like a traditional dumpling). They were good but the description on the menu for this dish was vague. Next, we moved on to the entrees. I ordered the pork while my friend ordered the duck. Unfortunately, my pork seemed to be on the brink of being undercooked which really freaked me out because I recently contracted a food borne illness at a restaurant for having undercooked meat. The pork was just not cooked to my liking so I was unable to eat all of it. My friends duck was just okay but he didn't really care for it. Finally, we moved on to the desserts and we were underwhelmed by what we received. The frozen chocolate was very simple and we could tell it was pre-made by how cold the plate was. The lemon merengue was placed on the sides of the chocolate dessert and server almost no purpose because it lacked flavor and the texture was similar to chalk. 
  Overall, this place seemed really underwhelming and I was disappointed because the reviews were good when I scrolled through. I do not think I will be returning and I hope the food progressively becomes better in the future.
author: Ricardo R.

description:
I have a friend that I grab dinner with once a month or so and go to some really nice restaurants. (it's a funny story how we met - if you message me, I might let you know). This place is in the same group as Alta and that's one of our favorite places to grab a drink together. 

The Michelin star was definitely a reason why j decided to come here, but it was actually really enjoyable for both my friend and me. We went with the 4 course dinner and wine pairings. 

We did get some bread - some delicious bread that was. Sourdough with this awesome butter. 

I started with the trout; I guess I had expected it to be cooked, but it was raw. It was delicious though. The friend got the sprouted and puffed grains. I got one bite of it and it looked interesting. Definitely liked the trout more.  

For our second course, I ordered the potato dumplings and he ordered the soft boiled egg. The dumplings were good - the mushrooms were good even though if you know me - I dont love them. The soft boiled egg was interesting, but not as good as the dumplings. 

Next course, I got the duck and he the pork.  The duck was interesting - I didn't love the rhubarb and other additions (especially the olive jam that came along), but the duck itself was amazing. The pork was pretty good as well - didn't have much of it, but the sauce seemed really good. 

Lastly, for dessert, I got the milk chocolate custard and him the strawberry parfait.  I super enjoyed the custard - it had an interesting herby addition of sorrel which I had never heard of before. It was good though! The strawberry parfait was pretty good too! Frozen strawberries are amazing! 

Service was great! Lovely descriptions of the food and the wine whenever they came out. 

Protip: get a reservation and get a four course meal!
author: Nina Y.

description: Not all the dishes worked for me. This came across as a really try hard place in all of it: service, food itself, wine pairing. Honestly, if it wasn't for the great company we were in, I would have not enjoyed it.
author: Langston B.

description: One of the best meal I've had in San Francisco. Prix fix menu where every dish was perfect and portions just right. Not as fancy as the big name restaurants but the same level of food quality
author: Jerome C.

description:
I dined here with a friend last November and we both got the 4-course menu with wine pairings. First off, Aster is an affordable michelin stared restaurant, but I'm not entirely convinced that the cuisine is reflective of one. The cuisine is Californian with some farm-to-table influence. 

The good:
-The thumbelina carrots were so simple, but complimented with sunchoke and lime to create a harmony of sweet and savory. It is reminiscent of Nightbird's corn in 3 ways dish.
-Potato dumplings were an umami bomb with chanterelle, eggplant, black garlic, and hazelnut. I wish this came in a bigger serving because it was SO good!

The mediocre:
-Pork with miso potatoes, brussels, and grapes was a very simple dish. Very small portions; 2 pieces pork belly the size of a dollar coin and 2 pieces of 2 tenderloin. Overall it was an OK flavor combination, nothing spectacular.
-Soft-cooked eggs with puffed rice, salmon roe, and bacon vinaigrette was WAY salty. The puffed rice was more burned, and the bacon vinagrette was kind of like those burned bacon pan drippings. This was only exacerbated by the salmon roe.
-Kampachi with cucumber, pickled plum and shiso was simple. Nothing memorable.
