The wine pairing was OK as well. You get 4 glasses total, and for $36 its not that expensive to feel regretful about. None of the pairings elevated the dish much or were just standard textbook pairings. My gripes with this place are the portion sizes that are on the smaller size, making this place slightly more expensive than it needs to be. Another issue was the service was horrendously SLOW. Our whole dining experience took 3 hours; ~20 minutes for us to get our order taken after being seated. Our waiter kept putting us on hold. The interim between each course was also unjustifiably long. For 3 hours you could get swept away by a tasting menu, relatively speaking. 

Overall Aster had some interesting dishes, but the entrees were nothing memorable. Desserts were OK too. I think the kitchen is understaffed because I only saw 2-3 cooks there.
I'm not in any rush to come back with all the other great alternatives in the city.
author: Chad S.

description: Amazing service and outstanding food. Wonderful evening to celebrate my son 25 birthday.
author: Julie H.

description:
Aster is bombdotcom! The owner and executive chef, Brett Cooper, used to work for Outerlands in the sunset and he left there to open his very own restaurant which is just as good, or even better! 
I really enjoyed the layout of the restaurant and of course, the service was great. Great selection on the wine/beer list. I believe they do change the menu depending on the season. 

Items I ordered/recommend: 
- Rabbit Meatballs: morel, fava, pea greens, vadouvan 
- Black Cod: chard leaves and stems, smoked bone broth
- Pork shoulder: sweet potato, rhubarb, grilled broccoli
- King Salmon: peach, almond, chili oil, basil

As for dessert, I ordered the frozen chocolate with kumquat, cocoa nib and basil. YUM!!!
author: Jenn L.

description: Easy to get a brunch reservation, and hope no more people finds out about this gem. Lovely duck hash, friendly service and trendy, hip Mission decor. Love to come back for dinner service as well.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
The GM needs to learn how to deal with guests in a more tactful and respectable manner. I received a call the day before our reservation to confirm the appointment for party of five at 7:00 pm. First, she asked if we were still planning on coming. Duh. I made the reservation two months ago so yes we're planning to come. I mean it literally took me months to get reservations for a group of five that is at a decent dinner time instead of past 9 pm.  She then said, "Also there has been a price increase for the prix fixe menu and that we no longer serve ala carte items." This is what was annoying. I did not mind so much the amount of price increase (10) and the menu change, but what did not make sense was the way she informed me, which was one day before my reservation. For a one star Michelin restaurant, this was not something you would expect. She said, "this price change has been long time coming." Strange. If they knew this was "long time coming" how come I only heard about this the day before my reservation?? They had my phone number and email from day one. It sounded like they were planning this change for months. Could they have not made a call or sent a brief email to inform me of these changes given they literally had two months to do so? Any day between April and June would have been a nice gesture. 

Regardless we showed up the next day because we were not given any other choice since all other Michelin star restaurants were already booked in SF for party of five. I get there and also noticed their menu items changed. No more duck! The only meat item on the entree list was lamb and I do not eat lamb. So I ordered the following: 

1) Dry aged beef tartare: way tooo much and over-powering lemon aioli.

2) Squid: sauce was too salty. Squid was tender though. 

3) Trout: sauce was too salty again. I liked the crispy skin of the trout but it was nothing special. 

Bonus: small sorbet balls to celebrate our recent wedding. I just found it weird that only two out of five people at our table received a small sorbet scoop even though all five of us were celebrating together. 

4) Chocolate dessert dish: pretty yummy prob the best thing that happened all night. 

After all courses, I was still hungry. 

Overall take-away: not worth the money, lacks flavor, too salty. Two stars for our servers who were polite, patient, and competently answered all our questions at the dinner table. Minus one star for the way Aster management handled the phone call and menu change. Minus one star for food saltiness and flavoring. Minus one star for portion size.
author: J C.

description:
Raining evening. I walked gingerly, skipping puddles as I had been working and did not have time to change into my rain boots. Restaurant called and said that there were some cancelations due to weather and asked if we'd be willing to come early. I emailed friends mid day and solidified a 8 PM dinner schedule in lieu of 9:30. Pouring rain. We got the best seat in the house, it's tucked in by the front window, you simply cannot get a better view than that with the rain coming down. Endless Victorians. A bottle of Bordeaux was ordered for the table. San Francisco is now rich people's playground, with residential home sometimes well over $1000 per sq foot (Nice, Provence, in French Riviera, where I'm at, at the top of the market is about $400 per sq foot). Aster's prime Guerrero and 22nd street location is a quintessential food mecca. They are surrounded by their peers and the food, as I'd later learn, justifies its one star Michelin rating.

That evening, instead of looking at the traffic, with the rain storm hitting us, you see a skewed view of the streets and car passing, and a lot of Victorian architectural elements through the window. 

We went for the 4-course but there were lots to choose from. The price range is right for what we want to eat, the portion of the food well managed. The scallops were quite delicious, the second course were dumplings, pumpkin soup, and soft boiled egg with salmon roe. Simply all divine. The mains we chose were pork shoulder and lamb. The desserts were good, but for me, thankfully, they had included cheese. 

Overall, the food reflects this city: it's modern, Californian, European light, with abundant Asian influence. 

The menu is surprisingly assembled similarly to Sbraga, which also serves a four course menu for the same price range, and located in Philly. I'd be interested in seeing if the two chefs have studied under the same chef. 

Think, I shall rename the city by the bay as La Petite Ville de Bijou Victorienne (the Small city of Victorian jewel,) after dining here. It's that quintessential Californian cuisine coupled with the locale that give Aster, the newly minted Michelin star restaurant a leg up over its peers. While it's the chef's name dropping prior digs at Saison, Coi, State Bird, Outerlands that send new patrons here; it's the food, however, that keeps people coming back.
author: Victoria E.

description:
Received 1 Star on the 2016 Michelin List

3.5 stars but rounding down since I didn't love the majority of the dishes, and the portions were on the smaller side for the prices. I was able to make same day reservations for a dinner on a Thursday night, for a party of 4 at 6:30pm. Our table was ready when we arrived, and they weren't busy at all during that time. The restaurant eventually got busier, but they weren't packed by any means. We tried:

-Sourdough (House Cultured Butter, $5, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3V91ozGWsarim2yG3Wa3_A&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok- the bread was very dense, and I thought the butter was too sour and had the texture of a Greek yogurt versus butter. I wish restaurants had an option for diners to choose regular butter instead of all this house cultured butter, since I always think regular butter tastes better. Skip!
-Bay Scallop (Radish, Persimmon, Sunflower Seed, Basil, $16, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=iW1NuR3K3oYJtr2Pupfm0Q&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- the scallop was super fresh, and went really well with the rest of the ingredients. This is one of the better dishes we had.
-Duck Liver Mousse (Sprouted Grains, Strawberry, Fennel, Sesame, $13, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=SObYbeArDeqBwizb_TqTCA&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): The mousse was smooth and creamy, but the combination of ingredients didn't quite work for me. The texture of the sprouted grains was strange, and I didn't get the strawberries. We all felt like this dish needed a bread/cracker of some sort since the mousse was too rich to eat on its own. 
-Soft-Cooked Egg (Crispy Potato, King Salmon Roe, Agretti, $14 + Uni Add-On, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=LNrO4lpgUaRpUmpiilMZ7A&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I thought I would love this dish, and it was good, but the crispy potato really threw off the texture for me. I wasn't a fan of the combination of ingredients for this dish, and wouldn't order it again. However, the uni was really fresh, but not worth the cost of adding it on.
-Potato-Caraway Dumplings (Chanterelle, Brussels, Yogurt, $15, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=uv33KtF3oUmYDp7rnUMOoQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Yum- this was probably my favorite dish of the night. The dumplings were pillowy soft, and I loved the combination of chanterelle and brussels. I just wish they gave you a larger portion- recommended!
-Pork Loin (Delicata Squash, Kishu, Shiitake Furikake, $26, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=bkkz6zGdLhlzLybfq2EQzw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Just ok- I liked the delicata squash, but the pork loin didn't do anything for me. Skip.
-Milk-Fed Lamb (Cabbage, Quince, Sunchoke, Hibiscus, $27, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=A0lZ5-l2hXNohOkxJ264ig&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): Pretty good, and I liked this a lot more than the pork loin. The lamb was seasoned well and really tender- recommended!
-Chocolate Ganache (Black Caramel, Cocoa Nib, $12, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=pMvQWSO3nYIktohmDfr0yQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): This was my favorite out of the three desserts we tried, but it was still just ok. The texture of the chocolate was really smooth and creamy, but it didn't have much sweetness/taste. I wouldn't get this again. 
-Pink Lady Apple (Brioche, Sunflower Seed, Shiso, $12, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=RAytNjkaPGEAriW25STBaQ&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I didn't like this at all- the apples were kind of soft but still partially hard, and the flavors didn't work for me since it had a savoriness to it. Skip!
-Pumpkin Parfait (Pecan, Coriander, $12, http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=EXqf23sXv7tynEzU6Pizpw&userid=76vIFZcC7owykCBjMfGVXg): I also wasn't a fan of this dessert, since I didn't think it had that much sweetness/flavor, aside from a savory note. Skip!

They also offer an option of a 4 course menu for $59/person, but the entire table has to participate. The presentation of all the dishes was beautiful, and I wish the taste matched the appearance for more of the dishes. The restaurant itself is very sleek and modern, and I loved the ambiance. I'm a big fan of new and inventive dishes, but I felt like there was too much was going on for the ones that we had, and the ingredients didn't get to speak for themselves. Since it seems like the menu changes often, I hope the next version is more successful. Parking in this area is difficult since there is street parking, but a lot are taken by the residents.
author: Amy D.

description:
Food is really good. It's fine, small portions, very tasty. Nothing to say about that. Top notch.

But food is not all in a restaurant. It's a full experience, and it's been ruined by poor service. First, for a restaurant that charges fees for late cancellation, it's a bit dared to be 35min late on a reservation... it's even worse when they don't even offer anything to drink to make it up, and absolutely terrible when while you're not even done with done with your desert, they start cleaning the kitchen with all the fumes and all and you smell like you had a great barbecue with homeless guys under the 101.

It could have been great, but that's a miss.
author: Antoine M.

description:
This was a very lovely meal. Slightly higher on the price scale at $59 per person, but the quantity of food that you get for 4 plates is pretty decent, and the quality of the food, plating, and service is nice. The ambiance is also great, quiet, and perfect for a date night (but probably not a first date) or a party of 4.

If you choose to do the tasting menu, everyone in the party must participate. Otherwise, you can get items a la carte.

We got the sourdough bread & butter for $5 as a starter, and it was delicious. I think that if you're paying $60 a head, the bread and butter should be complimentary, because it probably costs them $0.50. But it was fresh & delicious nonetheless. You get 4 pieces with butter that has sea salt flakes on top.

I came here in April 2016, so some of the dishes that I ate are probably not on the menu anymore, but out of what I got, I loved the trout and the potato dumplings (gnocchi) the best. But I don't think you can go wrong with anything.

Local Halibut - This was a cold dish with cucumbers, pickled plums, and shiso. The proportion of fish to cucumbers was definitely light, and it seemed mostly like cucumbers. It was good, but not necessarily the most memorable of appetizers I've had.

Potato Dumplings - This came with fava beans, pickled mushrooms, and fennel and I really liked this. The gnocchi was fresh and pan-seared, and the fava beans were a nice complement to the starchiness. I'd get this again if they had it on the menu.

Trout - This was a generous serving size of trout, sprinkled with sesame seeds, and perfectly cooked. It was served on top of snap peas, and it all came together really well.

Hazelnut Gateau - This was a cake that came with sliced kumquat on top, and hazelnuts on top. I didn't really taste hazelnuts inside of the cake -- if it was ground up in there, I couldn't taste it very well. I thought it was on the dry side and didn't really care for this dessert.

Milk Chocolate Custard - This looked like it had a little garden growing on top of the chocolate cake. My friend got this, and once I tried a bite of her dessert, I wish I had gotten this one instead. 

All in all, a nice meal - they didn't really do a ton of crazy combinations and I didn't find the dishes terribly unique, but instead they focus on fresh ingredients. They don't go overboard on trying to combine too many different flavors, so that you can taste everything you are eating. With the 4 course menu, you won't be hungry when you leave (and I eat a lot). I'd come back here and recommend it if you're looking for a nice dinner.
author: Christina L.

description:
I had real high hopes for Aster as I had read about it on eater. I got a reservation as the start of a holiday weekend to kick it off right.

The decor inside is very nice, mirrors on the wall give the illusion of a high ceiling and the kitchen is open facing the restaurant. Initially all was well. 

To start I ordered the 'lady in red' cocktail, which was delivered in a small glass flask like bottle. It was incredibly strong, but more of a pre-mixed drink. It seems they don't actually have a bar, so they might just keep drinks pre-mixed in bottles and serve right out of them, i wasn't a fan.

For appetizers I ordered the halibut and garlic soup. The halibut was sashimi style, with radishes and chili oil on top, that was great, however they also sprinkled peanuts on it which just didn't seam to belong. The garlic soup was delicious, but again it had raw daikon which I had to just chew away, it didn't seem to blend well with the dish. Also ordered the house made sourdough (which is quite the rip off that they charge just for bread). 

For the main course I got the poached salmon and hubby got the lamb. Both were small portions and decent tasting. 

The dessert was by far my favorite course, as the frozen chocolate was delicious with tiny marshmallows and mango puree drops. 

Usually a restaurant will earn back some stars if the food is subpar but the dessert is good, but I felt Aster was lacking in the service. The servers never actually talked to us, just dropped off the food and left. Our waiter seemed chatty with all the other tables but us, and never really explained the menu. The only thing he did manage to say was that they now accept tipping, so that's encouraged. So after we tipped on our way out not a single staff member said bye, or have a nice night, we just walked our selves out.

So in total I was not impressed, the food was alright, but its definitely lacking in service.
author: Bevi K.

description: A tiny corner restaurant with great ambiance. The menu was small which made it easy to make decisions on what to order. I did the tasting menu which was $65 for 4 courses. Which they they you chose a dish from each section of the menu. It was well worth it.  The duck was really good and seasoned.
author: Jason L.

description:
Everything a restaurant should be- great ambiance, cool and friendly staff, delicious food and amazing wine pairings! I understand why they have a Michelin star! 

The food was very good and they accommodated my gluten free dietary needs without any issues. The wine pairing included a sparking French red wine like nothing id had before. They played good lounge music so it wasn't stuffy like other restaurants in this genre.

We sat at the communal table and honestly I think this is the best place to sit. Strangely, the only room for improvement lies in the desert. Aside from that, everything was excellent! Great service too!
author: J. C.

description:
Go for the tasting menu! It's a wonderful way to get a good feel for Aster's style and approach to food.

STARTER: The bread is so soft and sour, and the butter is seriously heartwarming.

1. DRY AGED BEEF, HUSK CHERRIES, BROWN CRISP RICE, KIMCHI FUNKAKE:
Texture was king here. The crisp rice was very brittle so it was a little difficult to eat with everything, but I liked the crunch with the beef. This is more of a tartare and a nice way to start a meal.

2. PINK LADY APPLE, YUZU PRESERVE, BROWN BUTTER-SQUASH, YOGURT, ARUGULA:
Surprisingly, this was hands down the most interesting dish we were served. The textures were interesting, but it was the flavor combo that really made the table go quiet and have a moment.

3. SOFT COOKED EGG, CRISPY POTATO, SALMON ROE, BACON VINAIGRETTE:
I saw this dish being made on Chefsfeed, and it made me immediately book a reservation here. It did not disappoint. As expected, it's super salty, but it was a an enjoyable, savory, umami explosion. It was a nice followup to the tart, creamy apple dish beforehand.

4. POTATO DUMPLINGS:
These were DECADENT. This was a course where there was closing of eyes, no real words, and knowing looks. I think we made the table next to us uncomfortable, until they too got this course. Loved the slight crisp of the dumpling, and all of the crispy/harder textures with it. I could have had all four courses of this.

5. DUCK, CELERIAC, QUINCE, MAITAKE:
This was the best cooked duck meat I have ever had. So soft and savory, and it paired really nicely with the sweet sauce. The duck is the heartthrob of this plate.

6. TROUT, ARTICHOKE, SHELLING BEANS, ORO BLANCO, PRESERVED MEYER LEMON:
Tasty, but definitely my least favorite. The bean flavor was really dominant, and the other flavors didn't come out as much as I would have liked (especially the subtle fish that had such a pretty sear).

7. POACHED PEAR, PISTACHIO, VANILLA:
I was excited for a pear based dessert, and this did not let me down.

8. FROZEN CHOCOLATE:
I thought I was sold with the poached pear, but this smacked me in the mouth and made me feel stupid for even considering a fruit for dessert. If you are a chocolate fan, DO NOT miss out on this.

We opted for our own wine choices instead of the pairing. Looking back, we think it may have been better to do the pairing, as it's not much more at the end of dinner of you know you'll have more than one glass of something.

Cute, quiet location.

Service was very personal, not too pushy and incredibly pleasant.
author: Haley J.

description:
Fancy food the way you expect: tasty, small portion, colorful, and expensive!

When I think of the typical fancy restaurant, nothing comes to mind faster than Aster with it's wonderful decor, warm atmosphere, well dressed servers, and ever changing menu.  But be warned that with all the wonders of Aster's dining experience will include small portion sizes, requiring you to order at least one appetizer with your main course so you do not feel famished after the meal, and each dish costs around $20.  But you are paying for quality as Aster's food makes up for their portion size with big flavor.  I sampled a green veggie salad loaded with avocados and duck dish.  Both of which are no longer on the menu, but were fantastic.  The veggie salad had a unique sour flavor which tickled the taste buds and the duck was savory and sweet.

For a true high class dining experience, look no further than Aster.
author: Nadav P.

description:
3.5 but I'll round up. My bf brought me for my birthday and as soon as we walked in I was greeted with "Happy Birthday!" and then our server said it, and then our a second server said it and as we were leaving they said it. So everyone knew what was going on lol. 

Rustic restaurant feel, less casual than the other Michelin restaurants I've been to. 
We ordered a Penicillin drink ($12) with a side bottle of extra drink. Free hot water refills for your tea pot. 

We both got the four course meal ($59). The best was the black cod, beet salad and soft cooked egg which created a great sauce for the grains. I normally don't like potato dumplings but they make it really good here too. Dessert portions are very generous. My favorite was the birthday dish which was a strawberry sorbet. *DROOLS*
I did NOT like Milk chocolate custard with a basil filing. The basil was too strong and it was too salty! The only thing I DISLIKED during the meal. 

Overall it was a great dinner and the service was great. 

tip: tell them it's a special occasion because the sorbet was the best dessert!
author: Elaine L.

description: Aster just received a Michelin Star for its 2017 guide. Book now before the prices go up!
author: Wanugee N.

description:
The Food:  Tried the tasting menu, and everything was tasty.  Highlights included the soft egg dish, beet salad and duck.  

The Service:  Friendly and considerate.  Nice.

The Drinks:  Some excellent wines available by the glass.

The Verdict: I'll be back.
author: Steven C.

description:
We came to Aster when it first opened, and we remembered thinking that some dishes were great and others were okay, but because I never wrote up a Yelp review, we couldn't remember whether we liked it enough to go back.  So we went back to check it out!  And we're so glad we did because the meal was delicious. 

SOURDOUGH, HOUSE CULTURED BUTTER -- 5 - bread was great.  the butter was served smeared all over the plate which was interesting. 

SPRING GREENS, AVOCADO, SEEDS, MANDARIN, HONEY-LIME -- 14 - the seeds added some nice texture and overall the salad tasted super fresh and woke up the palate.

SOFT-COOKED EGG, CRISPY POTATO, SALMON ROE, BACON VINAIGRETTE -- 14  - this was delicious - I remember this being similar to a dish I had the last time.  The flavors went really well together and all in all it was unexpected. 

TROUT, SNAP PEAS, NETTLE, SPRUCE TIPS, BENNE -- 27 - perfectly cooked and delicious 

PORK, GLAZED YAM, LEEK, NASTURTIUM, PRESERVED LEMON -- 26 - also delicious, although the portion seemed a bit small. 

HAZELNUT GÂTEAU, KUMQUAT, SPICED BAVAROIS -- 12  - the kumquat was kind of a cool unexpected addition to this dish.  

Overall, we really enjoyed the meal. Service was great and ambience was nice and modern. 

Glad we came back to check it out again!
author: Vivian W.

description: Exceptional quality food, cheaper than other Michelin restaurants and far less pretentious. The chefs and staff here put on an amazing show. The shellfish dish was mind blowing, as were the beef tartare and the desserts. My new favorite restaurant in SF!
author: Matthew R.

description: I will come back for this. Need to refresh memories on the fixed courses we tried.
author: Mofy M.

description:
One of the best meals I've had in San Francisco. And I've had plenty. Don't pay attention to the negative reviews (especially if you work at Aster), this place is excellent and it's obvious that the entire staff puts great love into every element of the restaurant.

Although everything was superb, my favorite dish was the beet soup -- it just stood out as totally unique and delicious haute cuisine. Aster is almost certainly beyond the palateal comprehension of most restaurant-goers but that's not Aster's fault.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Loved the decor and ambiance of the restaurant. Big windows allowed us a look onto the busy street and an open kitchen behind us gave us a intimate look into the busy kitchen. 

Sturgeon starter and the duck hash were fantastic and worth a try.
author: Amanda H.

description:
The old Beast and the Hare spot that is opened by Daniel Patterson with previous Outerlands chef Brett Cooper! Been waiting for this place to open to try and we stumbled upon a reservation a couple weeks ago.

Food- I can definitely taste the Outerlands' style in the food! Cod wing was interesting, prepared with spicy yuzu and plum vinegar. It was soft, light, and a bit tangy. Young kale was like a salad that came with delicious carrot chips. Green garlic soup was tasty, not very garlic and Aster split the portion into two bowls without me or my husband asking. Each portion was the size of one full portion! Potato dumplings were pretty delicious, a bit peppery, but that added some good heat, tasted like gnocchi, served maitake mushrooms, peas and charred scallions. I was so full already, but dessert did not disappoint! The frozen chocolate was yummy. Husband ordered the green elixir which tasted good.

Decor/ambiance- good use of the space and sleek design/decor. Dimly lit so each table had additional candlelight. If you want brighter lighting, dine here earlier. We had 7:30pm reservations and they dimmed the restaurant even more during our meal.

Service- staff are friendly and took our order accurately. However, our waiter came by and told us he will get us water when another staff member already poured us water. Another instance (I forget the details) suggested he didn't remember something. Overall, service was okay. I think a chef dined right next to us, so a chef always bought over his dishes with nice introductions. 
 
Overall- good experience with interesting food. I would come back to try other items and when they change up the menu. Portions are of decent size and service charge is already included in the prices, so your bill is only the prices on the menu plus tax. No need to calculate tip, which I thought was nice (unless service absolutely sucked).
author: Iris H.

description:
My good friend loves surprising me, especially in celebrating my birthday.  She confirms a time and date then gives me driving instructions.  Being familiar with the neighborhood, we were fortunate to score a street parking space just a few blocks away.  Walking into this corner restaurant, I gazed at its interesting design, a cozy feel to an industrial space.  I remember the restaurant name, but could not put the face to the place.  Only after searching my phone did I remember.  After a quick gaze through the menu, we agreed on the four course menu for $59.00 which went like this for me:

1.  Golden beet soup (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=3Dd3VqyifpoiKSOm76svPg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Great summer dish, serving a cold soup; nice flavors with the sweetness of the golden beet and the brininess of the mussels.

2.  Soft cooked egg (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=DiczIjnkFUK8FcpDsn8D9g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - What's not to love about soft egg?!  The crispy potatoes weren't all that crispy as this had more of a salad feel than a carb dish.

3.  Milk fed lamb (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=NBzNYqaByNx7gq7v2eFBGg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Done two ways, the lamb was tasty and not the least bit gamey.  The eggplant puree and flavors definitely gave this a Mediterranean feel.

4.  Chocolate ganache (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=kiQwjBZELYTjwsQSDA6r4A&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Probably my least favorite as nothing about this really shined.  Because my gracious host did not enjoy her dessert, I gave her my macarons.

Given the chef's pedigree and after reading M. Bauer's recent Sunday paper review, my expectations were tempered but with a lean towards the higher side.  The meal was fine and the presentations and flavors were interesting with the first two dishes being my favorites.  We also ordered the bread service (yes, it's extra) which did not disappoint.  
The dining room was only a quarter full when we arrived just about 6:30 pm on a recent Friday night, not really a good sign for a growing business.  The service was very efficient and professional as dishes were quickly cleared and beverage glasses were replenished.  The food rates 3.5 stars in my book with a 0.5 star bump for the service.  The location reminded me of several long gone restaurants that I do miss, Watergate on Valencia and Flying Saucer.  With the ownership and chef's experience, I'm sure they'll figure the formula to filling those tables in no time.
author: Mike C.

description:
I'm no food connoisseur, but for my first Michelin-star experience, I was fairly let down.

My whole family opted for four-course meals and started off with the bread. The bread was warm, delicious, and generous in quantity. It wasn't anything groundbreaking, but the salted butter complemented it nicely.

Since we got a lot of food between the four of us, I'll just review them all in list form:

Sprouted & Puffed Grains: eh. The puffed parts themselves were nice (reminded me of rice krispies) and the yogurt went well with it. It just didn't blow me out of the water and was almost an overwhelming flavor .

Beets: I loved these! They were cooked so nicely and I stole three off my brother's plate. They tasted earthy and just delicious.

Spring Greens: Delicious, but presented really poorly. Upon first glance, it just looked like a normal salad. We didn't realize there was avocado until a couple bites in because it was hidden.

Local Halibut: Yum! The fish was nice, fresh and tender. Reminded me of ceviche almost.

Soft-cooked egg: The concept was nice, but it really did not just work well together. In the words of my brother, "it tastes like that asian snack mix from Costco". I personally think the roe made it too fishy, but I also have an unsophisticated palate.

Potato Dumplings: Also not great. The gnocchi was cooked well, but the copious amount of cheese on top made it taste like one of those Pirate's Booty cheese puffs but not in a good way. 

Asparagus: The presentation wasn't nice, but the asparagus itself was cooked thoroughly and tasted good. However, I don't think it was delicious enough to merit 25 dollars.

Milk Chocolate Custard: Delicious (I love chocolate) but we found a hair in it. It wasn't a big deal but it just put me off, especially since we were in such a nice restaurant. They didn't really do anything about it, either, just briefly apologized.

Overall, an underwhelming experience at what's supposed to be one of the world's finest restaurants. Would not return.
author: Juliana F.

description:
I am usually not one to write reviews, but I felt that this review needs to be made so that others can learn from our experience. 

My family of 4 came in knowing that it was a $75/person, 4 course meal, (so around 300, not including wine). That was fine by me. However, the reason why I am upset is due to the service, portions, and pricing of the upcharges. 

Our reservation was at 545, we left the restaurant at 830... The restaurant was not busy when we arrived and it took an hour from our 1st course to our 2nd course (no joke) and this was just our appetizers. The server was also rushing through the menu and not very informative about the pricing of the extra additions such as caviar and truffle. If she was, we would have not ordered 2 orders of truffle and 1 order of caviar. The truffles are $40 each, and I couldn't taste it due to an over amount of salt on each plate, totalling up to an extra $80. The caviar is an extra $60 and a miniscule amount. So with the extra addictions, that totals up to an extra $140 to the bill. When we got the bill, it was around $700. More than twice the amount of just 75/person, and that bill didn't even include tip. I am in the restaurant industry, and I still tipped 20%... Which made my final bill total up to $840... 

The reason for this review is to let you all know before hand that if you're expecting a 75/person meal, don't add extra. It's not worth it. It's a sham and an overpriced upcharge for a small amount. My family dinner was not worth $840. I would have just gone to Pabu or Michael Mina. 

Hope this was useful.
author: Sarah M.

description: It was possibly one of my most disappointing dining experiences in SF and the worst Michelin starred dining experience ever. It started upon arrival when we were told that our table wasn't available and were told to go to "one of the bars in the area and we'd be called" with an estimate of 5-10 minutes. Fast forward to 40 minutes later and we had to crowd into the front door area to wait for our table with no communication. A $5 complimentary plate of bread served as our only apology, I would've expected at least a glass of wine. Turns out our delay was entirely Aster's fault and not the prior guests at our table. Service was incredibly slow, it appeared to be a combination of the kitchen and light service staff. It took them 2.5 hours to serve four courses, I recently did a 10 course menu in 2 hrs elsewhere. Due to the late seating we were ready to go to sleep in our dessert. We had the pleasure of watching the kitchen crew cleaning while still waiting for that dessert. The wait staff was clearly not up to a high level of service and did little to communicate or check on us. An overall disappointing dining experience.
author: Jason L.

description: Had the 4 course meal tonight - dry aged beef, local shellfish, lamb, and coca nip financier. First 2 dishes were good, lamb was okay, but the financier was not good and was too dry (I thought financier was supposed to be moist and light?). I took a bite of the financier and then immediately put it a side because I didn't like it. I thought the waiter would let me exchange for something else but I guess it wasn't the case for this restaurant. Oh well. My friend had the strawberry one for dessert and that was good. But since I'm reviewing for the food I got and not hers, 1 star for each of the dishes I thought was decent. And for service, since this is a Michelin Star restaurant, 0 star for tonight for the last incident bc I had a higher expectation for the Michelin status and for the $75 four course meal. It needs to be better.
author: Kerr T.

description:
I eat out more than anyone I know and always been a yelp user but never give back... that stops now. I will be reviewing all the restaurants I have been to recently and any going forward.

I rate a restaurant of 5 items w a star for each:

Atmosphere (.5) - it was good, but they have no shades for their top widows so we had the sun in our eyes most of the meal as the sun was setting (along w other diners)

Food (.75) - Started w the halibut it was ok (I liked it, my dining companion did not) and the gnocchi (good, not great). Then had the duck and pork - I loved the duck! Definitely the best item we had all night! Pork was ok. The chocolate dessert w pea was fabulous! 

Service (1) - very nice

Would I go back (.75) - I would go back when they changed their menu in the new season to try new dishes. 

Would I recommend (1) - yes

4 stars
author: Jess W.

description:
Dismissive and sassy service eclipse otherwise creative Californian cuisine.

We and our two guests enjoy leisurely dining, but both our servers and the stand-in manager   appeared to ignore repeated pleas to speed up the serving of courses once we waited 30 minutes after completing the first of four courses. 
The second course finally arrived a full hour after the first course. And the time elapsed before each of the ensuing two courses was also excessive especially given our further urging of the staff to pay attention.
All this despite being a small restaurant which was never full during the course of this 3+ hour marathon.
And at one point, one of the servers mocked one of us about whether to keep or replace a fork from a previous course.
Sure the food and wine was creatively conceived and presented and one would hope the real Aster managers will prevent their kitchen and servers from inflicting such an indignity on their guests again.
author: Harvey P.

description:
I came here on the strong recommendation of a coworker, who came when Aster first opened, and I have to say I was sad to report to her that I wasn't a huge fan of the food on the whole.  The menu just did not reflect what the food actually tasted like for the most part, and the food wasn't very delicious.  

The atmosphere and service, however, was fantastic.  There were lots of people on fancy dates, dressed to the nines and sipping on wine.  I felt a little embarrassed wearing jeans and a t-shirt, but was not treated any differently by the staff for my wardrobe.  Service, in fact, was hospitable and very knowledgable about the food.  The layout is interesting... One communal table in the middle of dining room and lots of booths and standalone tables.  I loved the feel of it... quiet and romantic, warm dark woods, lovely paintings on the wall, twisty light fixtures and sculptures on the ceiling, live plants lined on top of the entryway, and an open kitchen.  Cons: there is one unisex bathroom, and the door stays propped open if opened too far, which was a little distracting on a 50-degree evening, but staff was diligent in closing it promptly.  When my boyfriend and I got up to use the restroom, no one folded our napkins, which generally is the practice of a fine dining establishment, but obviously not a huge deal.

Cola was house made, not too carbonated, presented in a glass bottle the size of a Coke glass bottle. Not too sweet and you can taste all the spices used in making it.

Dish - Price

SOURDOUGH BREAD WITH HOUSE CULTURED BUTTER - 5
They charge for the bread here, and it is worth it to have a warm loaf to nibble on before the food comes out.  Other than that, the bread is not special and it is kind of sad to have to pay for it.

POTATO-CARAWAY DUMPLINGS, MAITAKE, BRUSSELS, YOGURT -- 15
These tasted like browned gnocchis and the caraway was an excellent flavor.  Maitakes were charred perfectly and tasted delicious.  Brussel sprout leaves were also good, but there was a brown sauce drizzled over everything that just tasted like salt to me.  The yogurt was compliment enough to the dish. 4/5

SWEETBREADS, PICKLED SUMMER SQUASH, CHARRED PEPPERS, THYME -- 17
Getting my boyfriend to like sweetbreads is becoming a losing battle.  I really liked the sweetbreads themselves here because the breading was light and preserved the fatty/cartilaginous texture of the sweetbreads.  I'm not a huge fan of squash, but I think plating the sweetbreads over something pickled was smart. 4/5

PORK LOIN, DELICATA SQUASH, KISHU, FURIKAKE -- 26
The pork was ever so slightly tough and was a strange cut, with a small vein of fat running in it.  I personally like the fat, but for those looking for a healthier option, I thought I should note it.  The squash was kind of mushy, and the mandarin oranges didn't make sense to me.  I did not taste any sort of furikake.  Though the pork was cut in large bite size pieces, I would have liked a steak knife to cut it with.  I sawed through my pieces with the knives that were given to us standard. 3/5

MILK-FED LAMB, CABBAGE, QUINCE, SUNCHOKE -- 27
The lamb was done in three ways: chops, stuffed, and one other I forgot.  The chops were good, but the stuffed one was very salty and the stuffing overpowered the flavor of the lamb.  The cabbage was overcharred and the sunchoke skin was tough while the inside was very mushy. 3/5

PUMPKIN PARFAIT, PECAN, CORIANDER -- 12
This was not at all presented like a parfait.  The pumpkin rectangular semifreddo was topped with an orange zest tulle, with a blot of a strong pecan puree.  I don't really understand why this was billed as a parfait.  We were instructed to take a dab of the pecan puree with each bite of the semifreddo.  It was a weird and not very satisfying dessert. 2/5

CHOCOLATE GANACHE, BLACK CARAMEL, COCOA NIB -- 12
Blocks of fudge sandwiching a dab of some sort of cream, with a semi-frozen caramel, topped with a sweet cracker.  This dessert was better, but still not great.  It just didn't taste very special, though I have to say the semi-frozen caramel was quite good.  3/5
author: Christina G.

description: Delicious food that is not pretentious. Solid good food with a reasonable price tag. Service was great as well
author: Jh L.

description:
Sometimes I have to admit that my tastebuds can get a little fancy schmancy. Next time a nice guy wants to take me on a date, I should suggest a semi-expensive place like Aster. Instead, I went with 3 friends and when I got there, I realized that they were not too pleased with the pricing on the menu.

I would've loved to try the $59 4 course menu but my dining companions outvoted me. We each got 2 courses. My first item were the $15 potato dumplings with maitake, brussels, comte, and rye. 4 stars for flavor and this was the largest appetizer on the menu. 

My "main" course was the $28 spiced duck with rhubarb, endive and black garlic. I liked the consistency of the duck and I was also told that this is the largest main on the menu. 

Even after spending over $55, I was hungry. We headed over to El Farolito for dinner, part 2.
author: Yi Z.

description: Must say this one of my favorite places to eat. It's a great spot because you can hear one another speak, the service is 5 star and the food is incredible. It is pricey but you get what you pay for her. It's very very well done.
author: Robin K.

description:
beginning of the year - i will be generous with my stars. more of a 3.5 experience for me i guess. nothing wrong with the restaurant at all - i thought the dishes were presented nicely, had nice components, service was pretty good, etc., but definitely a disappointment in terms of a patterson collaboration and a michelin star rating. but i think perhaps we dont have the best luck with his restaurants - visited coi a few years ago and definitely not  a 2-star experience for me...

anyhoo. had a 715 reservation on a thursday - we were early. the restaurant gets packed later in the evening. there is a long communal table with 2- and 4- tops along the walls. good decor - the space looks pretty inviting.  i did some research on their wine list and decided that i didnt want to pay 3x retail, so i brought a bottle of grgich hills chardonnay - nomsies - for a $30 corkage fee. not terrible, but not great either.

we did the 4 course tasting for $59 - pretty good deal, and added bread n butter to start.  i got - bay scallops, potato dumplings, trout and the cheese course.  boi got -  beets, soft cooked egg, lamb, and also cheese with a dessert wine pairing that was delicious. i think the potato dumplings were my favorite part of the meal, lol. really nicely cooked and chewy and made me feel warm n fuzzy inside. everything else wasnt super memorable, well maybe the scallops were good, but trout was kinda bland, egg dish had WAY too much going on in it, and lamb was very meh, and he likes ALL lamb, so...that was disappointing.

would i come back again - probably when the menu changes, and in a year so that i could judge any progress...
author: Christina L.

description:
We went here for dinner on a quiet Sunday night and both ordered the four course menu for $59 per person. 

First course: 
Halibut - Very light and refreshing.
Summer squash - Well-paired with apricots that made it fleshier.

Second course:
Soft-cooked egg - The yolk was slightly runny and it was a good combination with the crispy potatoes although we would have preferred a higher egg to potato ratio.
Potato dumplings - Sour, because of the pickled mushrooms, but the potatoes themselves were deliciously chewy and reminded me of gnocchi.

Third course:
Trout - Deliciously crispy and more flavourful than expected. The sesame seeds on the skin made us think there was an Asian influence and the snap peas balanced out the saltiness of the fish.
Duck - Extremely tender meat and the sweetness of the corn was a great combination.

Fourth course:
Frozen strawberry parfait - The diced strawberries were a delightful detail and worked well with the tartness of the dessert. 
Milk chocolate custard - Tasty but not particularly remarkable. 

Overall we really enjoyed both the halibut and squash, the soft-cooked egg, the trout and duck, and the parfait.

We left satisfied, but not particularly full as the portions were small, despite also ordered a side of sourdough. The service was good and we loved the décor. 

We would love to come back again!
author: Abra S.

description:
Each course challenged the taste buds in this trendy, low light sexy setting.  Like a 7 series Beamer with dark tinted windows, you want to peel back the layers to see what's inside.
We started with warm Sourdough bread served with a pool of soft salted butter, that had a great rustic texture.  The Market Greens & Herbs was a mix of avocado, various seeds, and blackberries in a light honey-lime dressing.  There were tiny edible flowers mixed in, making it a beautiful kaleidoscope of colors that had an amazing taste.
Duck was surrounded with dots of celeriac & quince, and served  in rare slices that was sprinkled with some dry Maitake mushrooms, which didn't seem to compliment the meat as much as I would have liked.  Odd, I don't remember the grains of Paradise.  I tasted the Pork which had more complex flavors, but was accompanied by potatoes in miso. Kind of a miss I thought.  The potatoes would have been fine served plain.
The poached pear was mounted with vanilla ice cream and topped with a lemon pistachio cookie.  Simple goodness.
author: Arlene C.

description: Great food! Went for their 3-course tasting menu and thought each item was sophisticated both in conceptualization and execution. There's nothing worse than spending a lot of money on food you could have made at home, but I'm happy to say that was not the case--I didn't even know what half the ingredients were, so I definitely could not have made even one of those dishes myself!
author: Neha S.

description:
Don't get me wrong here... The food is fantastic, the atmosphere great, the servers (while assigned to many tables) were on top of their game.
My big problem & it really is a huge problem was that they don't fully disclose important parts of their dishes.
For instance, my friend & I ordered duck liver mouse which I love & she was willing to try. When it arrived at our table our server presented it & then we were informed there were du k hearts in the dish. This was too much for my friend & I- I work in cardiac surgery.
Also, the local halibut was outstanding but it was not cooked~ totally fine with me but not if I were pregnant.
The servers were super accommodating & took the chicken heart dish away & off of our bill.
Instead we super enjoyed their house made bread & butter, their local halibut which was fresh, with spot on clean flavors & a little spice.
We also enjoyed the trout & park shoulder. The trout melted in your mouth as did the pork shoulder. My only critic of the pork dish was that the bok choy it was served with was waay over done & floppy from being water logged.
I would def come back again! In a heart beat! Not a duck heart beat ;)
author: Ashley G.

description:
I could not get comfortable at he long center table because there's a raised platform underneath.

Our server immediately started describing the "add on" items before explaining the main menu.  Felt like an upsell.  But I was glad I got the Uni add on.

Food itself was creative and some really great combinations.  But occasionally a dish was just ok.
author: Steve R.

description: I just had a horrible customer experience with Aster... I made reservations for this popular restaurant a month ago for my wife's birthday, and then they cancelled it on me with only 24 hours notice (after I gave them a deposit for the reservation). They just told me it was an emergency, and wouldn't give me any more details, nor do anything to accommodate. At the least, they could've given more notice (they would've required a 48-hour notice from me, or they would've kept my $75 deposit), or explained more why they had to cancel the reservation. My wife was really looking forward to this experience for her birthday, and now we're scrambling to make something special happen.
author: James R.

description:
I read many reviews after our experience tonight. If one were to average out reviews of those who gave Aster 4 or fewer stars it would be as follows: nice space, creative menu, over priced, good food that's not too memorable and not deserving of a Michelin star, too small but nicely plated dishes, over-precious and overly confident attitudes, good, attentive but cold service, excellent wine selection and basically they don't care about you. That's pretty much our experience tonight. This coming from people who dine out everywhere in sf all the time and around the world, who absolutely love great food and enjoy a memorable experience. 

Our evening began with a lovely hostess taking us to our table and telling us she knew all about us. I had mentioned in the reservation that I don't eat gluten and my husband has a nut allergy and tries to avoid cow milk and cheese. Mind you, we hate this about ourselves but we try to be clear to avoid misunderstandings later and these are merely food intolerances that we try to get out of the way early in the meal. We make up for it by being friendly, appreciative guests, repeat diners and generous tippers. This was not relayed to the waiter so when I told him our limitations he seemed thrown off and angry and told us there wouldn't be much on the menu we can eat. We were made to feel ashamed, not good. We told him we'll do our best to find something that works. He proceeded to describe one of his favorite dishes that he thought we should get, which had a potato purée in it, turns out its actually a Dutch word called Bintje which is a type of potato. My husband who is a Dutch native, got so excited and said, cool! I love bintje, this is actually a Dutch word and I'm Dutch! The American waiter had the nerve to correct his pronunciation of this Dutch word. Actually sir, it's pronounced ----. That was the beginning of the end. 

In addition to our dinner order I asked our waiter to select a great glass of red wine for me. He had quite an attitude and instead of just bringing me something great to try, he went through the fact that every wine was hand selected to pair with each dish, and they take pride in ... blah blah. He seemed a bit defensive. He ended up bringing me a glorious cotes du Rhône and I was a happy camper. After he left my husband still seemed a bit stunned by his pompous attitude. When he came back to our table the waiter knocked over my wine glass and all the wine went flying and splashed all over my husbands new jacket, new sweater and pants and my jacket not to mention all over the table. I felt bad because I encourage him to dress up tonight so he wore his favorite jacket. It was a huge scene with wait staff was super attentive and wiping wine off my husband and off the table, cleaning the floor and moving our jackets away. The whole restaurant was watching and it was a 5 minute ordeal. I was trying to comfort my husband who was not smiling and at this point wanted to leave. Our waiter obviously felt bad and said they would pay for our dry cleaning, and said, if there's anything I can bring you, let me know. But he didn't want to make a fuss. I figured they would comp our wine or bring something special at some point. Right? My wine was obviously replaced because it had been emptied out and I hadn't had any yet. After the B- meal which was beautiful but not at all spectacular, our bill arrived. No discount, no comps. No apology or acknowledgement. Nothing. So tacky. I asked the waitress if she recalled what had happened earlier and mentioned we thought we'd at least get our spilled wine comped. She said the the waiter had replaced my glass of wine and didn't charge for it but only charged for a single glass. I mentioned that the glass had been emptied onto my husbands clothes before I began drinking it. So obviously they wouldn't be charging me for the first glass.
She said that since we were only charged for one glass that was the comp. She obviously felt the need to comp our wine glass after leaving the table and returning and realizing that she was being super greedy. But only after the fact. We gave our waiter a full tip and left. Aster needs a major attitude check and an accounting class so they can lower their prices and learn some humility, humor and etiquette.
author: Lynn R.

description:
I dined here earlier this month. This place was delicious! Service was good.

Here's what I chose:
Sourdough w/ Housemade Butter
Dry Aged Beef Tartar
Soft-Cooked Egg
Trout
Chocolate Custard
+Wine pairing

Favorite items were the bread and butter, soft-cooked egg, and trout. I wish I would've skipped the wine pairing and got the Strawberry dessert instead.
author: J P.

description:
4.5 stars 

With several new(ish) restaurant openings, the intersection of 22nd & Guerrero has recently been transformed into a delicious dinner destination (didn't mean to alliterate.) 

Aster's sourdough & salted butter is so lush & so appropriately sour, balking at the $5 price will seem ridiculous after one bite. 

The aroma from his lamb dish was mouthwatering enough to get me to try the eggplant mash which was the base for the protein. 

I started with Cucumbers which uses blackberries & avocado as a condiment. Loved the abundance of preserved Meyer lemon tang. A verdant, beautiful starter, if not for these fronds which reminded me of succulents! 

I opted to have a smaller plate as my main -- potato-black pepper dumplings, maitake, turnips, & peas. The dumplings had great texture; velvety with a bit of give without being too firm. 5-star flavor. 

Including a homemade lemon-lime soda (albeit unspectacular), total was roughly $65 before tip.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Drink 4
Food 4 The menu is bit too tight and the portion is small. So even though we got 3 dishes for each one, we were still hungry... but every dish was very tasty
Ambience 4 Simple and comfy if you get a table. Im not sure the communal table that looks uncomfortable might need to make you squeeze.
Service 4
Price 4
author: Tory T.

description:
Michelin star well deserved. 

This is one of the few restaurants where both my husband and I were both very happy with all our dishes from beginning to end. 

Everything was delicious and the waiter was so great. He was super friendly and was very enthusiastic when telling us about each dish as they came. He was on top of advising on how to eat some of the dishes to make the most of it too. 

The price is really decent for a fixed four course menu. The atmosphere is super chill too. 

I had the beet salad and was so glad I did.  Not a big fan of beets but at nice restaurants they're usually pretty good and this was no exception. 

Squash with a lemon sauce, very different than what I would normally get but it was really good. My husband got the soft egg with rice puffs, roe and bacon vinegarate (spelling?) and it was freakin bomb. Highly recommend that. 

For my entree I had the duck as I love duck. The mushrooms on it were perfect.  My husband went with the trout and the skin on it was cooked to perfection, super crispy and almost with a caramelized finish.

We finished off with the coconut coffee tart with a lemon sorbet that my husband loved. You need to eat the tart and the sorbet together to balance the flavors out. The pear with pistachio cookie and ice cream was so good. 

We went to celebrate our anniversary so they gave us a goodie on the house I believe they said it was a rice milk sorbet and it was out of this world good. 
I would buy buckets of it if I could.

They offered beef tartare as an add on with Uni on top, get it!! It's just one piece on a single cracker but so good!
author: Annissa H.

description:
I had the good fortune of snagging a table on the same day Aster was awarded a coveted Michelin star, so I'm not sure I'll be so lucky again... My bf and I went for the tasting menu and each ordered something different.  At first glance, I thought that I would love everything I picked, but after sharing each of our plates I realized I liked all the other dishes even more!  

Each dish seemed small, but I was actually surprised at how full I felt when we left.  Granted we did order the serving of bread (and trust me--order the bread!), but with the relatively small portions, I was surprised nonetheless. 

The service was impeccable and friendly.  Our server was attentive but not hovering.  The ambiance was inviting.  Chef Brett Cooper honed his skills at the likes of Coi and Saison, and you can bet it shows at Aster.
author: Olivia D.

description:
Overpriced.  That about says it all.

The food was decent, hits and misses; but for what they are charging and their approach, you should expect Michelin star quality -which this clearly wasn't.

We started with the Cucumber with cherries, meyer lemon, avocado, and coriander.  It was OK.  Interesting but nothing remarkable.

The Young Garlic Soup was the standout, an incredible blend of  pickled fennel and lemon.  One of the best soups I've ever had.  

The Rabbit Meatballs with fava, carrot, and vanduvan were forgettable. Tasted like turkey meatballs.  

The Black Pepper Dumplings with mushrooms, peas, and turnips were decent but passable as well, nothing to justify the $20+ price.

The Pork Shoulder with sweet potato, rhubarb, and broccoli was commendable but nothing worth returning for either.

All in all, pretty disappointing.  They will need to up their game quickly or I see this corner being occupied by a new resident next year,
author: Saminda W.

description:
So here's the deal with Aster: If you want to impress a girl/boy, it's a great spot for date night.

The food is presented beautifully, it's refined, and it's delish.

But real talk- while I wasn't completely mind-blown, Aster is still interesting and satisfying enough.

The menu is broken up into different sections, and they want you to order a dish from each section for the full experience. 

Our meal started with some bread and butter. The bread was pretty amazing, but they charge $5 for bread! WTF?

Anyways, moving on:

+  The cucumber salad is a great and refreshing way to start the meal. Plus, all these flavors worked SOO well together: cherries, preserved meyer lemon, avocado and coriander ($12)

+  Red trout appetizer was SUPER fresh. It's topped off with peach, almonds, chili oil, and basil. It's a great change from most crudo or tartare's out there. Nice touch Aster! I would definitely recommend getting this as an appetizer.

+ Pork Shoulder: Most of the time, pork belly is served because it's easier to cook and has a ton of flavor already. But Aster does a phenomenal job using pork shoulder in this dish. It's tender, yet flavorful, and not dry at all.  Combine it with the sweet potato and broccoli, adds a nice touch to complete the dish.

+ The dumplings were OK. Ummm, I didn't hate it, nor did it like it. Get it if you want to try another take on dumplings.

+ The black cod was my FAV thing here. It's flaky, moist, outfitted with a coat of chard leaves that sits on a thin slice of miso levain, placed in a smoked bone broth, with a hit of lemon. If this dish is still on the menu- you HAVE TO, have to get it!

To sum it all up:

The ambiance is chill with good music and great service, which is perfect for date night. Every dish we tried was thoughtful, creative and awesomely executed. The prices aren't too ridiculous, but the portions aren't big, so you might find yourself ordering a lot of stuff.

Overall, it's a more than decent place to check out. You won't be mindblown (or maybe you will), but you definitely won't be disappointed!

For more pics and deets, visit: http://cyneats.com/aster/
author: Cynthia L.

description: Came her for my birthday and food was decent but pretty expensive for what it was. Another nice and cool 75 percentile overpriced new American restaurant in SF.
author: Eve H.

description:
Don't do it.

Overpriced, pretentious, annoying service. 

Our waiter wasn't attentive, was more preoccupied with serving his friend's table than asking how our meal was or getting us our check, and he made our dining experience worse. Place was empty and we couldn't get good service even then. 

I started with the cucumber/cherry salad. Good.

I then had the garlic soup. Interesting, inventive, but a little too tart for my taste. Don't.

The potato dumplings were ok, minus the turnip and mushroom action.

Not worth the $120 my husband paid for our meal. Whattabust.
author: Gabriela W.

description: One of the best culinary experiences (if not the best) I've had in San Francisco. Every detail was well thought of from the serve-ware, table, lighting, acoustics, service and of course the food itself. The food was superb, fresh, flavorful and the portions were decent.
author: Eric K.

description: This place is special. Lighting, ambiance, pacing, FOOD, FLAVORS, warmth... not many places ace the whole experience and this place is worth it. Trust Aster with a special occasion or night out, cause they will deliver. Thank you.
author: Grace M.

description:
Excellent restaurant!

Great service: Team of waiters will serve you and your party to deliver the meals together.

Great food: I had a salad to start with (tomatoes + figs + and more), carrot salad, pork dish, and then coffee coconut tart all with wine pairing. Everything was excellent though the carrot salad didn't leave much of a lasting impression (definitely not bad).

Nice ambiance: We enjoyed sitting by the window with view of street, and overall ambiance is nice.
author: Hamrez S.

description: I came here with few friends that I haven't seen for a long time. The server was very nice. You can either choose a four courses tasting menu for the whole table or order separately from the menu. The food deserved Michelin one star but personally I felt  the food was a bit salty. The duck breast cook beautifully but the sauce on the side was a little disappointed. Generally it's a pretty good restaurant for friends reunion and would come back again.
author: Maggie L.

description:
Came here for my bf's birthday recently. We're lucky enough to have eaten in Michelin starred restaurants all over the world & I have to say the food here was right up there with them. Super enjoyable. My bf particularly enjoyed the potato dumplings & I LOVED the brassicas. We also had really nice desserts. 
If I had to be picky, we would've liked a little more in terms of meat options before the entree (we're total carnivores I'm afraid) and we arrived basically in time for our reservation but they weren't ready so we had to shell out extra money for a drink around the corner. Typically we got our text to say the table was ready *just* as our drinks were delivered at the bar. Glug glug, quick quick! Sigh. 
I should say that one of the highlights of our meal was the service. The lovely Ricky was a fantastic source of information & advice!
author: Fi M.

description: It was an enormous let down.  Certainly not worth the $350 it cost me (for two).  For a full review see my post on Chowhound, as there are not enough characters allowed here. https://www.chowhound.com/post/aster-sf-big-1063797?commentId=10034900
author: Ed F.

description: My first Michelin star experience. Food and service is superb! Great ambiance. My favorite is the dungeness crab and dry aged beef. The price is reasonable. I just wish the bread and butter would be complimentary other than that the place is highly recommended.
author: mel m.

description:
Aster falls flat.

From former Outerlands chef Brett Cooper and the Daniel Patterson Group, Aster features NorCal-centric food with Japanese influences. The space previously occupied by Beast snd the Hare is so sparsely decorated that despite all the wood, it still feels cold. A long communal table fills the center of the room, while some booths and banquette seating line the walls. Seriously? For this price point diners expect a table of their own.

From the start, the menu at Aster insults diners by asking $5 for four thin slices of sourdough bread and house cured butter. This smacks of the "coperta" that diners face in Italy. The chicharrones ($8) were heavier than expected, but saved by the red espelette seasoning and charred avocado dip. Wrapped in chard leaves and stems and drenched in smoked bone broth, the black cod ($34) was quite tender, but a little hard to cut. Despite the profusion of somewhat tasteless sun choke, radish, and preserved Meyer lemon, the cold-smoked trout ($17) was good, but lacking in smokiness.

With only a beer and wine license, there is no full bar. As with everything else at Aster, the wine list is pricey with some glasses breaking the $40 (!!) barrier.

Gratuitously expensive even for The City, Aster further escalates the bill with its service-included policy. And, perhaps because of this, service is medicore: polite, but cold; accurate, but not friendly; precise, but somewhat uncaring.

With his excellent pedigree, Brett Cooper can do better. For the prices charged, he needs to up his game at Aster.
author: CJ G.

description: Came here on a lark..... Ohhh the larks are smart. Absolutely fabulous.... More later, am still enjoying.... Nom Nom.....
author: S L.

description:
My partner took me here for my birthday.  It was about the best dining experience I have had in a long time.  We both did the tasting menu with the wine pairing, and I think this was absolutely the best experience I could have hoped for.  We each decided on different Starter and second courses so that we could sample a bit more:
1a) Halibut crudo with pickled plumb & cucumber / cucumber broth - light refreshing,  perfect start
1b) Seared summer squash with pluot & mint - a pairing you might not expect and incredible!

2a) chilled green garlic and green pea soup - fresh peas added a crunch to an amazing take on gazpacho
2b)  Potato dumpling (gnocchi) with fresh fava and picked mushroom - !!! a must have

3) Duck - just get it, the best duck I've had in a long while

4) All of the deserts looked great, we were advised to try the Peach Melba (a panna cotta) style dish - it was  good advice.

The wine pairing was excellent.

I'll be dreaming about this mean for a while.
author: Nathaniel H.

description:
Overall, I was very pleased with my meal at Aster. As a new place, I feel it's still got a little bit of work to do to get up to snuff, but the food was delicious and beautifully prepared. There were three of us and we each started with the young garlic soup. Maybe it was too young, but the flavors just weren't terribly strong for us. 

We shared the soft-cooked egg dish which was very tasty, as were the rabbit meatballs. For entrees, we also shared everything. I think the milk-fed lamb with smoked eggplant was a standout, with strong flavors that elevated the dish. The black cod was perfectly soft and flaky and moist, and went well with its accompaniments. The gnocchi, however, was not terribly exciting.

As for desserts, the raspberry dish was amazing. A variety of raspberry forms, with a flaky meringue-like buckwheat cracker, creamy mousse...just wow. The frozen chocolate was good, but nowhere near the "wow" factor of the raspberries.
author: David B.

description: Honestly for a started restaurant was not impressed at all. The flavors on some dishes did not meld well, and frankly I thought all the desserts were horrible. As a group of three we did the 4 tasting menus and tried every dish. Honestly my favorite of it all was the bread and salt.
author: Morgan S.

description:
We chose Aster as our wedding anniversary dinner destination. Unfortunately, Aster was a poor pick for such an occasion since it was definitely on the casual side and we were directed to the "chef's table," aka bench seating, that totally lacked any intimacy. Now I'm not knocking stars for this, but I guess I would have like to have been forewarned. The ambiance is more suited for a casual date night or dinner-with-friends.

Our waiter was extremely well-versed and answered all of our questions. Of course, you have to get the 4-course! For the price, it's well worth 4 stars regardless of the menu. We had:

Sourdough Bread (5 stars) - Just get it.

1st Course:
Halibut (I'm preggo so taking the hubby's word - 5 stars) - Light and refreshing, paired excellently with the cool cucumber
Beets (2.5 stars) - I was disappointed with this one. The beets were fantastic, but only because they were fresh. I thought the pistachio topping was overwhelmingly salty. 

2nd Course:
Chilled Garlic Soup (4 stars) - Although my husband wasn't a huge fan, I loved. It was light and refreshing. Not garlicky as one would think. I thought the fresh herbs, nuts, and peas added texture and complexity without taking away from the base.
Carrots (4 stars) - Simple yet divine. The toasted coconut added a great crunch to the dish. The black lime puree was also delightful. TBH I could have licked the plate.

3rd Course:
Pork (3 stars) - Although the meat was expertly cooked, I felt that the pairing with the grits and smokey turnips was a bit off. Polenta would have been a much better choice. 
Trout (5 stars) - Trout is a tough customer and well this was just perfect: skin had that crunch and a soft, flaky interior. It paired well with the soured greens. One comment, the pureed nettle didn't add to the palate of the dish.

4th Course:
Vacherin (5 stars) - Wow! Now this is where the Michelin star came from. A very delicate dessert with great citrus and floral notes. 
Cheese (Tomme dolce) (4 stars) - I loved this cheese! But I would have liked a better cracker. The salted rye crisp didn't agree with the preserve.
author: Cassie C.

description:
Every so often, we swing 'round Guerrero. When this wasn't The Beast and The Hare anymore (which was awesome btw), we had to learn what in the world replaced it and why.

That happened to be Aster! I liked the architectural setup inside, where certain elevated mirrors made the room feel even larger than it actually was.

On with our order! We shared the following:
-Chicharrones
-Pigs Head Croquettes 
-Delta Asparagus 
-Broccoli and Pork Belly
-Cold Smoked Trout
-Poached Rhubarb Pumpkin Seeds Dessert

I was really surprised how much I liked the Delta Asparagus, almost addicting. Broccoli and pork belly was amazing. Hats off to the chef of Pigs Head Croquettes, as its mix of flavors will tickle your taste buds until the cows come home!

For dessert, I think we had a split opinion about it. I know I enjoyed trying something new, but we weren't sure if there were curry influences on that dish, not my partner's preference. By golly, I still liked it!

It was an enjoyable early-evening dinner for sure. Great service. Hope to return!
author: Garett T.

description: Very nice brunch.  Savory duck confit hash and porchetta breakfast sandwiches.  Dishes were well seasoned and pleasingly rich.  The waitress recommended a sparkling rose and it was a hit.  Small dining room but the space is used well.  I would be happy to return and check out the dinner menu.
author: Olivia W.

description:
Nice service 
Real food simple ant tasty 
And correct price 
I will come back very interesting concept
author: Gilberte G.

description:
A sudden change in the menu since today - an oat  vacherin was replaced by a melon dessert. Vacherin had it's own forthcomings - the buscuit was hurting the dish by being too dry. However, honey and lavender cream was very much close to perfect and I returned for the one more. Unfortunately, the whole dessert was taken out from menu and replaced by the melon biscuit with cream, where i didn't like neither biscuit, nor melon, nor cream. Texture was not interesting, taste is just good, leaving the potential to be fascinating. I wish cream was lighter, biscuit more Austrian waffle-like, and already presoaked in the melon+sage jus. Also, biscuit everywhere is wished to be warm and cream - colder. But better please return the oat vacherin, just kill the biscuit base there. The crispy walls were just amazing!!

A side note - I don't how to say it better, but the plates leave the feeling of dullness and not always show up the dish.
author: Lyuba F.

description:
My girlfriend and I left underwhelmed and hungry. Wine pairings were OK, service and dishes were hit or miss. Ambiance leaves something to be desired. For $410 I expected a lot more. 

They may have been a Michelin Star at one time but I failed to see it last night.
author: John R.

description:
Probably a 4.5 star-experience overall, but I'll round it up because Aster deserves to have more people discover it. 

Some highlights:
- Service was excellent. The staff was friendly and warm, but gave us plenty of space to enjoy our meal. They played great music, too!
- The sourdough and cultured butter were 100% worth the cost. The butter was some of the most flavorful that I've ever had.
- The octopus had a great texture and flavor -- I'd order it again the next time we come!
- Fresh asparagus with a light, fluffy potato puree (bintje) was unexpectedly delicious.
- The trout was delicious. Perfectly cooked and paired with crispy artichokes. 
- The frozen chocolate was one of the best desserts I've ever had. Pairing the chocolate mousse and huckleberry with fresh dill was a surprise in the best way possible. 

The one thing they could improve on is that a few of the dishes were a little on the salty side -- particularly the mushrooms and farro. Still, an excellent experience and I'm looking forward to going back in the future!
author: Ashley D.

description:
i never made it to outerlands while chef cooper was there. it was just way too popular. though i do think i caught his cooking when he was at coi. the opening consulting menu at huxley was also awesome so i suspected this was going to go well. it was smart of them to open earlier in the week than on the weekend. we got a table with a decent view of the open kitchen. it's dimly lit with burlap walls, floral paintings and a cool light pattern on the roof. the kitchen is well lit and it stands out in the dark. chef daniel patterson, aster's godfather was also working service. after perusing both the wine and food menus we ended up with a bottle of rioja and the dishes as follows:

sourdough house cultured butter

cured radish kimchi furikake 

pigs head croquettes mandarin kosho, nasturtium

young kale pickled beet, carrot, dill, grain mustard 

cold smoked trout sunchoke, radish, preserved meyer 

delta asparagus ham hock, alliums, egg yolk 

potato-black pepper dumplings maitake, peas, charred scallion

charred broccoli fritters allepo yogurt, turnip, cashew

black cod chard leaves and pickled stems, miso levain, smoked cod broth

pork loin fried potato, umeboshi, rhubarb, tat soi rabe

roasted lamb shoulder vadouvan, cabbage, wheatberries

strawberry vanilla, cultured cream, chamomile 

beet cremeaux white chocolate, hazelnut 

frozen chocolate mandarin, cocoa nib, basil

wait did we have everything? almost, just not the soup. and it was all delicious. i have to say that they really knocked it out of the park. i expected as much given the pedigree. of the team.. our servers took great care of us and kept us happy the whole time. the system they put in place with the included service charge like coi/haven/plum makes it easy to do restaurant math and everyone gets a cut like they should. cant wait to come back when the menu gets changed up.
author: Kim N.

description: Dined here for dinner with a 5:30pm reservation, reserved on open table. We dined in a fairly empty restaurant (4 filled tables including ours) and it would've been nice to dine a little later had we known that it would be empty. We assumed it would be full since the only time available on open table was 5:30. Even as we left around 6:30, it was still pretty empty. The service was great and the timing for each dish was perfect. Our party all opted for the 4 course for $59 (the entire table must participate). I chose the spring greens (fantastic! I have never loved a salad as much as this), chilled green garlic soup (I'm not a fan of cold soup but I loved the raw peas. It tasted very fresh), trout (great crispy skin and again, raw snap peas-very fresh), and the frozen strawberry parfait (also very, very good!)
author: Lily Z.

description: Loved this place! Great Michelin Star food and very professional service for a great price! 4 courses for $59  is hard to beat. We opted for beer instead of wine and found a new favorite. The house made sourdough was unforgettable.
author: Philip D.

description:
Went for dinner with a couple of friends and the wife. I like to try the new Michelin starred restaurants the year they gets it. It was ok, but not as great as I expected. Definitely in the bottom half of the One star restaurants we tried in SF, and I would even say that I enjoyed some Bib Gourmands as much or even more. 
The good thing is that the price is reasonable,  the place well decorated and the chef friendly. There were some mistakes you shouldn't see at this level though. More details below. 

We chose the tasting menu, which is basically a choice of 4 dishes for a (slighlty) discounted price compared to a la carte prices. $65 is pretty reasonable, and it is nice to see a pairing at $35.

The good part: I was pretty happy with my choices
- Local halibut ($16) was really fresh. Presentation was ok, the fish was perfect. Missed a bit of a kick (some yuzu maybe)? 
- Potato Dumpling ($17) was the most interesting dish on the menu. Never really considered gnocchis as a dumpling, but nice presentation and interesting mix of flavors. 
- Duck ($29) was fine, but too classic. Perfectly cooked (at least mine - more to that later). Presentation was not super creative - especially after the dumplings which were set the same way. The sides were good, but nothing mind-blowing.
