- Peach melba ($12) was probably my choice mistake. Presentation was ok, but it didn't taste like peach at all. It was basically some kind of panna cotta with red fruits coulis. Should have ordered the milk chocolate with basil, which looked way more intriguing. 
- Bread and butter ($5) homemade, small portion but really tasty. 

The less good: 
- Service was a bit snooty. The waitress was not really friendly/natural, but some places like to play it this way.  She was not really helpful, didn't provide suggestions when we were looking for a bottle of wine. A bit too cold for my taste. The chef was warm though.
- My friends were less enthusiasts about their choices. The soft-cooked egg was apparently nothing special, even though it was the (only) recommendation from our waitress. 
- One plate was named "lobster mushroom and summer beans with sungold bouillabaisse". I am really familiar with the bouillabaisse, it's a fish stew from my hometown in a France. What we are not familiar with though is the "lobster mushroom", which is a type of mushroom. All my friends ordered it with the assumption it was actual lobster with mushrooms and summer beans, which made total sense with a bouillabaisse sauce. They asked for "the lobster" without any mention from our waitress that it was actually a vegetarian dish with a "lobster mushroom". Luckily I asked a question which made us aware of this, and my friends all changed their choice for the duck. But they need  to do a better job at explaining the dishes. 
- As mentioned, everyone chose the duck. We got an issue that should not happen in any michelin-starred restaurant: basic cooking consistency. All four ducks arrived at the same time, only 2 were perfectly cooked (including mine). My wife's was blue. My other friend was a bit overcooked. They had to trade their plates to match their preference. That should not happen. 
- 2 of my friends ordered the summer melon with brioche, lemon thyme ($12). The presentation was cool, but this one had a huge issue : the brioche was extremely dry. I don't know if that was intentional or not, but they didn't like it. Brioche should be soft, light - this one tasted like it was a week old. 
-  A small side note, but it would have been nice to have a couple of amuse-bouche or palate cleanser as part of a "tasting menu". Especially for a place where you already have to pay for bread. 

Overall, it's a 2.5 yelp stars experience for us. I was still debating while writing the review but If I stick solely to my experience, I am giving it 3 stars. My duck was perfectly cooked and my dessert was ok.  Moreover, the price range is fine for what it is. 
But there is room for improvement.

I don't think I will come back, and wouldn't be overly surprised if they don't retain their star in the next years - It lacked originality, and consistency is a big component.
author: Lionel F.

description: Please have a good meal before you dine at Aster. The servings, while beautifully arranged on the plate, are very, very small. The service, snobbish. Some of the creative dishes work well (aside from their minuscule size that leave you hungry), others look nice on the plate, but barely edible. Be careful re what usually comes for free in high end restaurants, for which Aster will bill enormous amounts (4 half-slices of bread with butter, $5.00, and if you ask for another serving, because after all, the dishes themselves leave you hungry --  it's additional $5.00 for each serving of 2 slices of bread!). Likewise, be careful when the waiter wants to treat you for an additional minuscule dessert, on top of the one you've already chosen -- at high end restaurants such an add on is offered on the house, but here, additional $15.00. One Michelin star? for such a greedy grandeur?
author: Ayala K.

description: My daughter took me to Aster during my visit to SF. What a treat! The food is DELICIOUS!!! We ordered the testing menu with four courses. Our favorites are the summer squash and the Duck! But everything is amazingly good! I'm in awe of the creative combination of each dish! The soft cooked egg has a good mix of crunchiness and softness! The trout is tender and fresh. The service in top notch! I'm really impressed and would highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Cindy L.

description:
i came on thurs w/ my friend, and i thought it was a great meal.  i thought we were just going to order a la carte, but she wanted to do the 4-course, so i went along w/ it.  who is going to say no to 4 courses for $65?

we shared everything.  for the first course, we got the mixed greens and the persimmon.  the mixed greens were way better than expected and had lots of seeds and avocado for dif textures.  the second course, we got the potato dumplings and the soft cooked egg, which i loved.  for our entrees, we got the duck and the trout.  the duck was a bit undercooked, so we did have to send it back to the kitchen to heat up a bit.  finally, for dessert, we got the coconut coffee tart and the poached pear.  the pear was good, but the tart was definitely a lot of flavors in one.  it could have probably done w/o the coffee flavor.  

we also ordered the sourdough bread, so we went all out, haha.  i loved the long communal table in the middle, which is where we sat.  the restaurant is really warm and cozy.
author: Helen T.

description: Have only been there for brunch. That said, it's one of the best brunches in the Mission. They're one of the few places doing innovative brunch food - sweet potato and bacon waffle, puffed granola with herbs - and they execute really well. Kind of amazed this place isn't mobbed yet...
author: Mike T.

description: The four course meal is well worth it! The soft boiled egg and potato dumplings were the favorites of the night
author: Erica C.

description: Back again! Aster never disappoints. Their menu changed slightly, but I'm not complaining. Their desserts are definitely one of Aster's strengths. Highly recommended.
author: Gabby P.

description: Just had dinner and had the menu for $65, Very good food, I had the duck breast which was perfectly cooked. but the wine pairing at $42 was a real dissapointment. Our server was OK, but I don't think he knoew any more about the wine than the company line he had memorized.  In the wine pairing you recieve oneglass with each course (4). Each of the two first courses were 2oz pours, the main course was a 4 oz pour and the dessert course waa a 2 oz pour. And these were NOT expensive wines. Mostly California, nothing all that special. I really think they need to rethink this. A standard pour at most wine bars is 6oz. The tab for two of us was about $250. Really? this is why I don't eat out much in SF anymore. Too, too precious.
author: Clark F.

description: Beautiful restaurant in the mission district.  We wanted to go eat at a Michelin rated restaurant and decided upon Aster because as far as Michelin ranked restaurants go, Aster is very affordable.  4 course tasting menu for $75 and wine pairings for $45.  Don't skip the bread, it is divine.  Our first course we had the beef tartare and grilled squash, both very good.  Second course we  had the chanterelles and the soft poached egg.  I thought they were both tasted great, especially the egg.  For our third course we had the hen, which came served as a roulade with what tasted like hen breast meat and a ground forcemeat.  The gooseberry sauce served with the hen was overwhelmingly sweet in my opinion.  The roulade itself was very good.  They paired it with a cider, that wasn't the greatest pairing in my opinion.  I would have rather kept going with a Chardonnay or some other kind of white wine.  The cider came off a little too heavy.  For desert we had the chocolate mousse.  It was piped in a circle and served with what tasted like coconut dumplings and a Carmel ice cream.  This dish was the least pretty all and felt very anti climatic.  The plating was weak and the ice cream was to strong- I felt it could have been creamier.  It's was paired with a vermouth that went great with it though.  The service was fantastic and the staff seemed very friendly.  The music was a little too loud and not to my taste but I'm picky about music anyways.  All in all I do recommend Aster.  The food is great, tasteful, thoughtful and beautifully plated with the exception of the chocolate dish which wasn't bad by any means but just didn't live up to the dishes that proceeded it.  The restaurant space itself is beautiful with an open kitchen.  The service was great with a friendly front of house staff that were welcoming and not at all stiff and robotic which can sometimes be the case in Michelin ranked restaurants.  Highly recommend.  4 stars.
author: Ducky M.

description:
We came here for a late dinner on our first night in SF. The food and wine was memorable and inventive  (we ordered 2 small plates, including the potato halibut, the pepper dumplings and the trout entree to share). The trout was a stand-out with a combination of flavors that was surprising and refreshing. The halibut small dish was also amazing and topped with crispy radishes. The pepper dumplings seemed like they would delight but felt like they were missing something, no "pop" to the flavor really. 

We sat at the large communal table in the center, but with no parties on either side of us so it felt rather private. The lighting in the space is soft and nice. The direct view into the kitchen was a nice touch (prep space so clean!). 

Only downside, service was slower than expected.
author: Lily A.

description:
So a friend recommended Aster and I had never heard of it so I was very open. The only down side to Aster is no cocktail menu. We didn't realize that they didn't serve cocktails until we arrived, so wine pairing it is! I will also say that the music in the restaurant was so loud that when food was delivered to our table - we could not hear any descriptions. We just smiled and nodded. Although these are downers, it does not take away from the food taste and quality.

First, we both did the four-course menu which was a great deal and I liked the fact that you could choose one item from each course. I had the smoked albacore appetizer and it was amazing - as a heads up I will be using amazing a lot in this review! The albacore was fresh and the flavors were abundant but cohesive. I could eat it over and over again. 

Next I had the potato dumplings - it had the texture of Gnocchi and it was so delicious and rich. If I only knew how they made that! Ugh Amazing. I almost just got up and walked out after that dish because I would have been completely satisfied. 

The trout entree was perfect, and the broth was perfect as well. I would have liked the broth to be just a tad bit warmer since it got cold very quickly. I ate every single bit and the pumpkin dessert was to die for! I did not care for the nut based garnish next to the dessert at all, but the cold sauce and cold yogurt was absolutely perfect. My dinner date did not seem to give the same praise for all of her dishes but she chose the wrong items! She had the chicories, which she loved. Soft egg which she liked, the grits, which she didn't care for, and the cheese finisher. 

The wine pairings were also perfect, I will come back again and again and have the same items forever and ever.
author: Jazmyn W.

description:
Came here for brunch with my boyfriend. It was almost empty. On a Sunday. In the Mission.

HUGE RED FLAG. No brunch place in the Mission is *ever* empty on a Sunday.

The food was decent - one dish was pretty good (sweet potato hash). However, the servers were snooty and rude AND service was just plain bad. 

Also  - Only after putting in our order and getting our mains did they mention that they serve their "sweet" appetizers AFTER the mains. Sweet appetizers are not desert if they're called "Starters". Might want to mention that when people are ordering, not after they're confusedly waiting. 

Verdict: Pretentious service with a high price tag. Avoid and go to Range instead.
author: Sarah K.

description: Had high expectations going in given the Michelin star. The waiters were very nice but everything was really slow.  I'm 9 months pregnant and we didn't get water for 20 minutes, so was glad I had a water bottle to drink out of! The bread indeed was very good, but $5 is overpriced for what should just come with the meal. The market greens salad was fabulous, highly recommend. The sauce that came with the trout was so salty, we had to scrape it off. The staff was very nice and offered to make us something else. The chocolate custard dessert was very good (after you take the fennel off, very weird). The strawberry dessert had a sesame thing in it that made it taste bad.  The food came out so slowly, we asked for the check before our dessert came (the dessert then magically appeared as soon as the check came). Overall, the food was mostly very delicious, but 1 star off for the slowness of the service in what looked like a not very crowded space, and 1 star off for the misses in some of the dishes given the price and the Michelin star.
author: Anne M.

description:
Very impressed by this local neighborhood gem. The food, environment and service were pretty great. Get the prix fixe, but you don't have to get the wine pairing. 

I got to try everything on the menu, but especially liked the local halibut crudo, soft egg (amazing), pork roulade entree, and frozen strawberry parfait. 

Having had the chance to taste everything, I have to say what I liked best above were definitely not what I would have ordered normally, and the chef's inventive dishes have shaken me out of my routine. 

I'll definitely be back soon.
author: Steven W.

description:
Their attempts at being creative Californian came off as cold and corporate. They're more concerned about getting your cash than creating a comfortable experience. 

Our party called in advance to inquire about the mandatory four-course participation policy, and the manager confirmed that a la carte for our party of 5 adults and 2 kids was fine. 

Ten minutes after we all placed our orders the manager sent the waiter back to require us to select the four-course menu. We were surprised the manager didn't take responsibility for the fiasco. This dinner was a special occasion and we didn't want to cause a scene, so we reluctantly re-ordered according to the four-course menu. 

The food was okay but not worth the headache. Restaurants like this are a dime-a-dozen in San Francisco. 

Lesson to take away about Aster: NOT good for groups! Their communication issues ruined my birthday dinner.
author: Merri K.

description: Precious beyond precious. Portions are very small and not particularly tasty. Staff is nice, attentive. This place specializes in people who have too much money and not enough sense to spend it wisely. $5 for two slices of bread after you have already spent a small fortune for tiny appetizers and small entrees.  Prices are way out of sinc with reality.  Get yourself a burrito or a hamburger somewhere they specialize in good food and leave the precious food for the overburdened with money.
author: Alan B.

description: For fine dining, look elsewhere. The staff did a poor job presenting each course, stumbling for words and the food was sub par for what I think Aster is reaching. The waiter was clearly intoxicated. Overall, we felt like it was a poor attempt at something it is impersonating.
author: Jonah J.

description: Unreal. We had very high expectations after reading all the reviews and this place exceeded that hype. The service is amazing and the food is out of this world.
author: Roberto F.

description: Great food, simple presentation, and at times slightly on the saltier side. The ikura dish with some uni and crunchy seaweed on a sous vide egg was really nice. Great variety of crispy, soft, and milky texture with a punch of umami.
author: Sean G.

description:
Good dining experience. The space is relatively small so feels intimate and thanks to the design, warm and inviting.

Food was innovative and not your usual crowd pleasers. We very much enjoyed the pigs head croquettes to start. The asparagus, ham hock, and egg yolk were well presented and had balanced flavors. The black cod was perfectly cooked and tastes great but light.

I thought the potato dumplings were only okay. They were a tad too gooey for my taste but still a well presented and balanced dish with the accompanying greens.

Service was friendly and attentive. I wouldn't mind coming back here again.
author: Victor W.

description: Highest possible recommendation.  Best meal I've ever had.  Each dish was perfectly balanced, melted in my mouth.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Let's be real, the Michelin Star ratings are a bit inflated these days. There are definitely some places that deserve them, but there are also a ton of places that don't deserve them. Aster, while decent, did not live up to my expectations. I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could. 

My girlfriend took me here for my birthday dinner. Unfortunately, though we made reservations well in advance we were still seated at the communal table. I guess if you make reservations you are seated there by default. You would think that it would actually be the other way around. 

Aside from that, we both had the tasting menu so we could try everything. Honestly the food was pretty good. When I say pretty good, I mean the majority of the food was good, so basically 5/8 dishes delighted my taste buds. The one dish that really did stand out was the trout. TROUT TROUT TROUT, seriously come for the trout it is actually amazing.  Everything else was good but not memorable. 

Service-wise, Aster definitely needs help. You are a Michelin rated restaurant, so act like one. I already mentioned the communal table, but what really irked me, is that we mentioned it was my birthday, and I didn't even get a candle on my dessert... Okay I sound like spoiled brat, I guess I'm just used to going to these restaurants and expecting excellence. 

Regardless, one dinner at Aster was enough for me. Try it if you are looking for an affordable Michelin star restaurant to mark off your list, but don't go if you are expecting a Michelin experience.
author: Alex L.

description:
We made reservations for Saturday the 17th at 5:30.  The first thing we did was tell our waitress that we had to leave the restaurant no later then 7:20 PM to make it to a play off market.  She said we can do that.  

The food was a mix of disappointments from the guests at the table.  We found the portions to be very small.  They certainly spend the time to make sure the look of each plated course was very well done.  The lamb lacked taste and was over cooked for one guest.  The presentation made it look like duck with three styles of preparation.  While we were waiting for our desert the table next to us asked for their deserts as they had a movie to be at and had to leave.  The waiter who was a bearded man who looked a lot like the chef but could not confirm that told her that "the deserts are hand made and take time".  The customer said she asked for them and then said "get me my check".  I found him to be rude.  Sad you are sitting eating a desert with the bill in your hand dealing with a credit card in a restaurant while paying so much for the four course ($75.00 per person). At 7 PM we asked that same guy about our deserts and he looked at us and said, "I can assure you that that no one is standing around"  and before he walked away he was asked to send the manager over.  He never did.   I asked our waitress at 7 pm to bring us our check when I was waiting at the restroom and she walked out of it..  I told her we are nervous about the time frame at this point.  She never returned to our table nor sent our check.  We asked again to speak to the manager.  No one came.  At 7:13 we asked a male food server (African American) to tell our waitress we needed our check and to send a manager to the table and that we have asked twice before.  At 7:17 Sarah came over with two deserts and said that she heard we were having a time issue.  At this point our mother was fairy upset and refused the deserts.   It was nearly 7:30 by the time we left the restaurant and with $800 in theater tickets we were not pleased.  Sarah apologized and without us asking made an adjustment on the check that was very generous.  Our waitress never did come up and say anything to us at all.  

The restaurant was clean and had a nice decor.  Our main issue was the lack of professionalism displayed by the bearded waiter/chef? One can be polite and not come across as confrontational when dealing with the public.  Would we go back?  Most likely not.
author: Tim C.

description:
I went here for brunch and would give this place at least four stars, but for the poor service.

The receptionist was accommodating and warm.  She allowed me to sit at a table 15 minutes prior to my reservation time and without my other person having arrived.  The restaurant had plenty of seating, so it was okay it seemed.

It wasn't that crowded at all, so I am very confused as to how the waitress assigned to my table ended up taking the food order of the table 6 inches from me on my left and then, several moments later, taking the drink order of the table on my right without so much as asking me if I was okay, or wanted to order drinks while I was waiting on my friend to arrive.  So, I approached the receptionist after being blatantly ignored by my waitress and made my drink order with the receptionist.  The waitress then came to my table quickly and took my drink order.  I told her I'd have ordered with her, but had failed at getting her attention.  Then, as time progressed, she asked other tables if all was okay and not me.  Had she done so, I would have gotten started by ordering our appetizers so that they would be ready once my brunch date arrived (and to save time).

The waitress was later replaced, without mention (which is a departure from other fine dining restaurants- usually your waiter/ waitress lets you know).  The replacement was far superior and attentive.

Clearly their front-of-the-house staff has varying levels of competency as this point.  At this price point, I don't expect to be waiting ten-fifteen minutes to only get up to make my drink order with the receptionist.

The duck confit was the star of the show and very well made.  The dessert I chose was unexpectedly good and... healthy.  Too bad so much of my experience was tainted by the poor service from the first waitress.
author: Jannah M.

description: The interior was fairly typical of the hipsterly modest deco that you see everywhere these days, but the food was outstanding. Really surprised by the food.
author: Fred C.

description:
We were ready to give five stars but the last hour cost this fairly new place in the Mission two.  Four of us went based on finding Aster on a list of the best of SF restaurants.  We arrived at 6:30 and got the best table in the house at the large street-side window.  We went for the prie-fixe and ordered everything on the menu.  The first three courses came at a good pace and were excellent, with special kudos for their duck breast.  But, it then took nearly 45 minutes to get our desserts, which were pretty good, not great.  There was obviously a mixup in the kitchen and at no time were we notified of the delay.  It took a couple of us getting up from the table to finally get the serve.  We were a bit surprised to find that we weren't comped at least a bit for the lousy service. to 

We were ready return when relatives came to town, scheduled for a coup;le of weeks from now.  We've changed our mind.  If you do go, be sure to order the duck and avoid the pork.
author: Larry H.

description:
The potato dumplings were by far the best thing we had. That would be the one "must have" in my humble opinion. 

The menu is rather limited and pricey. Many of the dishes we tried were just mediocre, and expensive... and yes, also small. Not sure why tip is included but not tax - if you're going that route why not to all the way and make it you pay what you see? Maybe because the prices are already inflated?

Agree with the other review that I much preferred sous beurre over here - more comfortable space and ambiance and the price was way cheaper AND included tip and tax.

The baby kale salad was ok. 
The croquettes also ok  
Lamb shoulder the other girls liked. 
We all loved the potato dumplings (also randomly cheapest main). 

The service was mediocre. We were left hanging in situations - after ordering the $5 bread -4 thin slices we didn't have plates to eat them on and had to ask. The place wasn't even busy! There were only a few people at the communal table and maybe 8 other people in the restaurant. Which also leads me to wonder WHY reservations were so limited on opentable yet the place wasn't even half full when we went?!

Overall am not eager to repeat - sous beurre much better choice overall! Mindblowing Brussel sprout and apple salad there.
author: Melody T.

description:
Aster was a great dining experience.

We were in a booth (4 people) and the table was comfortable, the restaurant was quiet but still playing great music, and the decor was modern and interesting. I always love an open kitchen, too.

The service was perfect. Helpful waiters, attentive but not overbearing, and perfect timing for all courses and aspects of the meal. 

The food was delicious. If you're going to do the four course meal, everyone at the table has to do it, but each person can pick whichever dishes they want. The homemade sourdough with butter was so comforting and good, the bread warm and the salted butter melted on top. Definitely worth getting. The cold starters were 5 stars. The salad was beautifully plated and delicious, the smoked albacore was a highlight, and the beets were also fantastic. All the plating was gorgeous. The hot appetizers (second course) was also delicious. The potato dumplings were my favorite dish of the night. The main courses were creative and incredibly tasty. Overall, just really interesting flavors that were executed very well. The desserts were very interesting, all of them had a savory aspect; not typical desserts, but really good. 

I highly recommend this restaurant!!
author: Toby S.

description: Great food and had a lovely experience. Ordering a la cartel isn't the end of the world to them, and it's appreciated for those that aren't starving. Lovely service and pricing was fair.
author: Carly H.

description:
Given the reputation of the Daniel Patterson Group, I wanted to like it, but I think the bar is set too high for them to accomplish, especially with their food. 

I went in with a few friends on a whim about a week ago and from the moment we walked in, it was an appealing vibe. The hostess was very real and cool (tatted) and she sat us right behind her on the communal table. 

The menu's set up to encourage a four course menu which we were down to try, but did have some reservations. The server was friendly, approachable, answered all of our questions and  we decided to do the menu. 

First course came out fairly quickly and the portions are fair (five beets in a large bowl, plate of bay scallops covering one side and chicories), but as we wanted to share everything, it created an unnecessary tension among us to withhold from truly enjoying each dish. Plus, the flavor are striving for complexity, but are bland. From that course onward, the timing became very lengthy and the wait was the norm. 

In the second course, the egg was spectacular and was the true standout of the night food-wise. Again, waiting for small courses is a net negative. 

We practiced patience through the rest of the meal, but as each dish is dropped, the runner explains every component of the dish and it becomes a bit invasive after a while. I wish they wouldn't have interrupted us. Read your guests. 

The food is fine. The story is fascinating, but each dish is treated too precious to enjoy; instead, you spend energy trying to preserve the dish's components and less time satisfying yourself. With the emphasis on food, it seems they are missing some major connections to nourishment. I want to eat something that taste good, inspires conversation with my friends and creates a memorable feeling. This food is overthought, smaller and makes me question if I'm getting enough. 

The atmosphere is sweet. It's romantic, darker setting. The mirrors make it appear far bigger than it is (nice touch). 

The price is moderate in SF, but the overall experience was underwhelming. 

I think this is the kind of place that you'll go to once, maybe twice (for a special occasion), but you'd never visit regularly because the price point is higher for less. I appreciate the service and the ambiance, but would invite them to quit trying too hard with the food. Create an experience not a dissonance. 

Go there once, but I would understand if you don't rush to go back.
author: Greg M.

description:
Good food from a new establishment in the Mission.

I visited early on a Sunday evening without a reservation as was seated right away at the communal table. The restaurant features dark wood furniture, artwork on the walls, and an open kitchen that looks over the restaurant.

The food itself was pretty good, although I personally preferred the small plates over the large one I tasted.

My favorite dish was the smoked trout: the lightly smoked fish, the radish, the sun chokes, and the preserved meyer complimented one another well and left me wanting more. The asparagus with ham hock and egg yolk was also a good mix of flavors. The pig head croquettes are worth trying; I don't think I'd want the croquettes by themselves but they pair really well with the mandarin kosho on top.

I was a little disappointed by the lamb shoulder. While it was fine, I didn't think it was quite as interesting as the smaller plates.

If you feel like dessert then I'd recommend tasting the beet cremeaux and white chocolate dish. (I didn't try the other two desserts on the menu.)

Finally, be aware that service is included in the price of menu items. I personally like this approach.
author: Glen G.

description:
The duck confit hash was the best meal I've had in a long time.

I don't usually comment on decor, but this is a clean and stylish restaurant. I very much enjoyed watching the chefs cook in an open kitchen.

My second favorite was the smoked sturgeon. I could eat a dozen of those little pancakes.

The staff was attentive, friendly and helpful. I hope they stick around because I'm definitely going back again.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Great new restaurant with a very talented chef and a few service bumps.

I entered Aster with a reservation just as it opened and was seated at the less than entirely comfortable communal table.  Assuming that the restaurant would fill rapidly I assented to this; however the place was only a third full at the end of my meal.  Why do places make their guests less comfortable than they might be?  Common sense and hospitality should be a rule.

However, the food was really good.  Golden beet soup came with mussels, pistachio crumble and dill.  While the mussels were a bit lost in the mix, this was a perfectly astringent plate that wakened the appetite.

Potato caraway dumplings with maitake mushrooms, brussels sprouts and yogurt was perfectly balanced and perfectly wonderful.  Some version of this should be on the menu always.

Trout with grapes, tokyo turnips, charred scallions and brown butter was another big winner.  The trout has been basted in olive oil just to the point where is was custardy.  The scallions, turnips and sweet grapes were in perfect equipoise. 

Next time I will ask to be seated at a table.
author: David D.

description: Aster is a Michelin starred restaurant near the Mission district. It's menu changes quite often so it is hard for me to tell you which dishes to try. However, what I will say is that the 4-course meal I had was generally pretty good. I started with a salad of wildflowers and greens, which was actually quite amazing. This was followed by an octopus dish, which was pretty good. My entrée of lamb was probably the most disappointing part of the meal. The lamb was cooked three ways; however, I couldn't really taste the meat because it was overly marinated with other flavors. Last, I had a very yummy ice cream for dessert. The atmosphere of Astor is like many restaurants, but what makes it stand out is the service. My glass of water was always full, and there was always someone close by to answer any questions or to take drink orders. It was very impressive. As for the price, it was also fairly reasonable. I would visit this place again.
author: Ian C.

description:
All in all, I was pretty disappointed.  My gf really wanted to check this place out since we recently read about it.  We were easily able to get a reservation and it wasn't that crowded but in a cool space.  I had been to the restaurant it was previously and they did a good job renovating.  We shared a quite a few items and our waiter got our order wrong - oh well.  

Sourdough bread was really good!  
Duck liver mousse - We didn't order this and it wasn't accompanied w/ any toast/cracker, etc. to spread - weird
Sweetbreads - Nothing special
Black pepper dumplings - I've had better 
Farro - My gf is a huge fan but me - not so much.  The best thing on this dish was the kale crisp!  
Pork shoulder - Surprised w/ the super small serving and there was nothing special about it.  
Surprisingly nothing wowed us on the dessert menu which is hard to do!  

Service - they're super attentive & helpful, almost too much.  There was staff constantly circling.  Our waiter forgot who ordered the sparkling (thought it was house and we ended up paying for a large pellegrino, smh) vs. still water.  Another person came by to refill my gf's water and refilled it with the incorrect one.  Le sigh.  
Parking was difficult so be prepared!
author: Meredith K.

description:
Decor: clean, cozy, trendy and intimate.
Service: Very good. The staff was kind and attentive, but not in-your-face. 
Value: Excellent. Tough to beat a $65 four-course Michelin-starred meal!
Food: All four courses were unique and worthy of mention. We had: 
1. Sourdough+butter - worth the extra $5. Get it. 
2. Red ace beets, Dry Aged Beef.  Note: the beef is a tartare dish. This wasn't disclosed to me, but was tasty all the same. 
3. Soft-cooked Egg, Potato dumplings. The egg was my favorite course.  
4. Pork, Duck. The pork was good, the duck even better. 
5. Poached Pear, Frozen Chocolate. 

I found the dishes a little high in sodium, particularly numbers three and four above. Otherwise, the food was what I expected from a restaurant of this caliber - delicious, unique and beautifully presented.

The space is tight, though not overly cramped. However, given the layout and the way the waitstaff constantly circles the room, my chair was repeatedly kicked throughout my meal - I stopped counting after 20 bumps. Tolerable, but annoying.
author: DS K.

description:
Ambiance / interior - 5/5
Service - 5/5
Food - 4/5
Price - 2/5

Upon first glance, the menu looks very reasonably priced, with appetizers and small plates ranging from $13-16 apiece and entrees in the $25-30 range. They offer a four course tasting menu for $59 in which you can each choose one item from each section, but since none of us wanted dessert we decided to order a la carte and share.

Almost everything we got was super delicious, except for the pork which had an odd flavor, texted, doneness and just overall was not good. We actually ended up sending it back and trading it for the duck, and were told that we were not the first table to comment on the pork that night so clearly something had gone wrong in the kitchen. They took care of it very graciously and we appreciated that.

The only other comment I have about the food is that the portion sizes are VERY small - and, the entree sizes are barely bigger than the starters. That made our meal way more expensive than expected considering our first impression of the menu.

The interior is absolutely beautiful, not too dimly lit, spacious and rustic. Our server was very articulate and helpful. 

Recommended for work dinner, date, or special night out - just know that it's definitely $$$.
author: Amy Y.

description: The food was delicious... every single dish we had was perfect... our only complaint was our waiter... he was snarky, almost rude at some points. A couple of times we asked for his opinion on certain dishes/wine and he would respond "only you can answer that"... clearly we couldn't answer ... he did make us laugh a couple times but our group agreed that he was far from a good waiter.. everyone else was great...
author: chris n.

description:
Visiting from Minnesota and found Aster after searching affordable Michelin star restaurants.  We are glad we did!  My wife and I had the tasting menu with wine pairing and it was a fantastic meal.  First course was tomato/ricotta and summer squash dishes.  Second was soft cooked egg and potato dumplings.  For our third course, we both had the duck.  Amazing!  Best duck we have ever had.  The breast was cooked perfectly tender with a small confit croquette.  Wow!  For dessert, we both had the coconut and coffee tart.  Our only tip on dessert would be a smaller portion as it did get rich after a few bites.

Service was top notch.  Bread and butter add on was well worth it.
author: J T.

description: Went there for brunch, pure and simple overpriced. The quiche was a huge miss, tasteless and the duck confit hash was a hit but the eggs were overlooked which is a culinary sin. Service and staff were great but overall for what you get, it's super expensive. Apps were OK and again way overpriced for what you get. I don't think I'd go back and recommend it.
author: Lo F.

description:
Came here with a friend last night and we both enjoyed our experience. I was able to book a table same day (Wednesday) without a problem, and we were seated promptly. Each of us got the 4-course tasting menu, which is priced at $59 and I thought a reasonable price, although definitely a splurge for a Wednesday. I got the following:
Early Girl Tomato dish with figs and ricotta: 4.5 stars, one of my favorites of the night! The dish had a slightly sweet tone to it, and tasted very fresh. 
Soft-cooked egg: 4-stars, very good and a bit more savory, although I felt by the end of the dish a bit bored with the flavor. Overall very enjoyable. 
Trout: 4 stars, nicely balanced with the snap peas.
Summer melon brioche: 2 stars. I was disappointed with my dessert, I was hoping more melon flavor would shine through, but apart from a few cubes of melon on top, it just tasted like plain brioche. I think this dish needs to be reworked--it is not bad, but I found it uninspired and boring. My friend got the Chocolate Custard instead, and I think she chose better. I had a bite of hers, and wish I had ordered that instead. :(   
Service was good, but didn't have any personal touches that I would associate with a 1-star Michelin restaurant. However, overall the food was very good and reasonably priced, and I would return again.
author: Rosa V.

description: Amazing, out of this world brunch and no wait! (Shhhhhh).  Delicate, delicious, perfect food items.  Seamless, professional, friendly service.
author: Dan D.

description: Their avocado on rye, cured trout belly, radish, sprouts not only tasted great but was presented like Monet's art!  very impressed!
author: Ile F.

description:
I don't suspect this restaurant stays in business much longer - price doesn't match what you get, and charging for bread (it's the principal). 

Service was poor. Food was good, I might even say great (some dishes innovative) but the portion sizes were very small. And the fact that the cost was so high made us feel like the food wasn't as good as it probably was. 4 people for dinner was $350, and I'm definitely not full. 

They charge five dollars for bread. Who does that? Bread and the butter were exceptional. But it actually made the bread seem much worse given that they charge for it. If you're so proud of your damn bread and butter then give people as much as they want and then people will talk about it - instead of a guy like me who almost never (truly) writes reviews writing something!

Chocolate for dessert, trout and pork were the only ones which stood out. Cheese plate for dessert was presented as a dessert not a cheese plate (server prob didn't know better, he explained it wrong) - yet what came was a TINY cheese plate (way too small). 

Two stars, food good but everything else brings this place way down.
author: SFfamily S.

description: I went to Aster with pretty high hopes. Looking at their menu, every thing seemed really exciting. Things began well, with the sourdough bread and freshly churned butter being simply mind blowing! However, the positive environment didn't last long. My friend was unsure that the wine bottle he ordered was the same that arrived and so started looking at the label on the bottle, and the waiter was extremely condescending. He could have been gracious and politely offered to bring the menu, but instead, he seemed to act like we were calling him a liar. This basically soured the evening for us. Honestly, most of the food was good. I had the beef tartar, the potato dumplings and duck confit. For dessert, my friends had chocolate mousse, which was great. I had the poached pear which was simply terrible. It wasn't properly poached and I couldn't even cut it with a spoon. The vanilla ice cream was depressing. I was quite sad with how the meal ended.
author: Shashank C.

description: The one of two best meals I have ever had (the other was Michael Minna, no surprise there). Extremely well priced at $65 per person for the tasting menu- which is not to be missed. This is truly creative, adventurous and genius cuisine. I went through the whole tasting menu and realized at the end I hadn't even had any meat, so sure to say it's vegetarian friendly. If you can understand food as art, this is your spot.
author: Nadia M.

description:
We've been here a few times now, and the experience has been fantastic every time. The food is not only beautifully plated and presented, but is also complex and incredibly delicious. I've loved every single thing I've eaten here.
I also love what they did with the space - it's dark, but the mirrors on the upper walls make it feel much larger and more open than it is, which is great. 
Their wine list is also well selected, at a nice range of prices, and the servers are quite knowledgeable about it.

Is it pricy? Yes. But it's entirely worth it.
author: Don H.

description: It's the best atmosphere restaurant I've ever visited. There are many decorative lights and paintings on the wall. Food is very good. I got the most fantastic salmon that I've ever eaten. I had a appetizer which is raw beef, it was very fresh but I couldn't enjoyed that dish. There service is very fast. Even though the prices are expensive for me, I had a great dinner with my friend in Aster.
author: Amy L.

description:
I think I've been to every incarnation of this space over the last ten years, so I was excited to try Chef Patterson's new offering.

First, I love what they've done with the space. The mirrors & lights around the top of the walls make the cozy space feel larger than it is, and OMG SOUND BAFFLING?!?!? Yes. Yes please. Second, everything we had was fantastic. I enjoyed the cucumber salad (subtle flavors, but the flavor combinations of cucumber, Meyer lemon, salt, & cherry worked very nicely) & my bf loved the smoked salmon appetizer. Seared lamb was maybe just *slightly* chewy but otherwise perfectly cooked, & I loved the farro & mushroom porridge. My bf had the black cod in broth & it was also stunning. The wine list was not huge but included many tasty offerings, including a very good 2008 Tempranillo that was perfect with the lamb.

I think the real trick with this place is the dissonance between the feel of the restaurant ("cozy neighborhood dining") & the quality of the food (gorgeously plated & expertly crafted). They already had to yank the all-inclusive gratuity model because their costs are already so high (because of the quality of the food -- it was a $200+ dinner for the two of us after tax & tip), so it will be interesting to see whether the place survives. In the mean time, I would love to go back & see what else they do!
author: Angela B.

description:
I had high hopes for Aster -- and unfortunately, I was fairly disappointed.  Lackluster food and a bizarre service marred what could've been a great experience.

--Food--
Certain dishes were inspired, other dishes were unfortunately just off.  All dishes were stunningly presented -- but the flavors just didn't match.

Cucumber Salad: Very good, a little overpowered by the coriander flowers.  Somewhat extremely priced at $15.

Green Garlic Soup:  Nice flavor, however, the pickled fennel was a bit overpowering, and I was expecting a bit more depth...especially given the garlic.

Black Cod: This dish shone - it was beautifully balanced, and the broth was delicious.

Lamb Loin: Lamb was excellently prepared and tender, if a bit gamier than it should have been at times.  The spring porridge was just weird.  Cloyingly sweet for a savor dish, with hints of an awkward sourness.

Raspberry dessert:  Good but not brilliant.  The shiso was a nice touch

--Service--
The service was just....bizarre.  Our waiter didn't seem to understand how to interact with us.  We noticed a chicharron dish that we had seen reviewed on Yelp on another table.  The waiter said it was a special service for the "chef's friends," but mentioned he would ask the chef.  The interaction took quite some time, with the chef clearly displeased that the waiter would have the audacity to ask.  The waiter apologized that they were "out" of chicharrones.

The pacing of the dishes was also terrible -- we waited 30-45 minutes between our starters and our mains....and the place wasn't very busy.

--Summary--
It just seems like the place is trying a little too hard.  Can they improve?  Sure!  I hope they do.
author: Wojtek K.
D.V. A.

description: Tried this place for brunch, and similar to other's brunch experience, was underwhelmed.  The food was decent, but the menu is very limited, portions small.  Perhaps the expectations from what a michelin star restaurant would be was what disappointed me.  I would like to try the place for dinner sometime however.
author: Robert K.

description: Amazing food, tasting menu is extremely well-priced for the quality. I thought it was as good if not better than Lazy Bear, and less than half the price.
author: Katherine M.

description:
Aster has long been on my "need to go to" list since it arrived in the SF dining scene. After sitting on my hands for a couple years I finally went here for the first time and I was really pleased on what I found and kicked myself a bit for not coming sooner. 

We dined here late on a weekday so it wasn't terribly busy when we arrived. I noticed everyone was sat on one side of the dining room on two tops and the left side had a bunch of empty booths.  I really hate it when restaurants seat you among the crowd of people rather than comfortably seating you in more than available booths. Aster did not add to my hate. So right out the gate they were off the a great start especially because my friend and I expressed how comfortable with thought the booths were.  I'm a huge fan of clean stylish bathrooms and Aster is right up there. The room itself is well lit and beautifully designed. Loved the art work and the lighting throughout the restaurant. It all paired nicely with the large windows that looked out to the neighborhood around us. I could see myself dining here alone as much as I could with a friend or a group. 

The best reason to dine here aside from the food is the value.  It's one of the best deals around to have 4 courses for 59 dollars.  Only Trestle can boast a better deal in my opinion. The food here was a touch better for me and I especially liked that we could mix and match so we weren't each forced to have our own courses (there were 2 of us). We were able to try 8 different courses and none of them disappointed our palettes. They went well with the wine our server suggested us.  The bread and the homemade butter here is amazing and we were even gifted a loaf as we were the last customer out the door.  A very nice gesture on their part which added to the really great service we received. I don't recall the details of the meal but that often happens to me. Like when I watch great comedy I just remember the laughing and rarely can recall the jokes. A good meal does that too. I know my stomach was a happy camper that night I just can't tell you why. Usually I take pictures for recall purposes but I dove right into it that night. 

All in all I expected great things out of Aster and it definitely backed up my expectations. I suggest if you go make sure you do the 4 course menu. You can't beat it.
author: Joco F.

description:
The Pink Lady Apple dessert is perfection and was a beautiful final chord in a masterfully composed orchestral dinner. The basil oil in the Apple dessert was in complete harmony with the other ingredients. I would go to Aster just for their desserts. 

But, it would be an injustice to not mention the other courses. They were stars in their own right. I had the olive salad, warm egg and the pork shoulder. They offered uni with the egg, but I declined. Each movement was beautifully constructed and was absolutely delicious. I especially enjoyed the pork. It was perfectly seasoned and cooked to perfection.

I highly recommend Aster.
author: Jasper L.

description:
Pro: Great wine list. 

Con: The food was pretty lack luster. We got the lamb two ways and it was way overcooked. They didn't ask our preference before ordering. 

The bill came out to $90 with a line for tip. It was only after the fact that I found out that tip was included (http://sf.eater.com/2014/11/20/7254735/daniel-patterson-to-eliminate-tipping-at-new-restaurant). We tipped 20% on top of the bill unknowingly.
author: Susie R.

description: This is upscale neighborhood dining at its best. New American with flare. The food is thoughtfully composed and inventive enough to make it surprising, in the best way, but not too fussy. The restaurant has good sound proofing and is relatively quiet, a rarity in SF. I could hear my dining companion perfectly. Finally the four course is probably the best value in the mission. Service is excellent, of course.
author: Jane N.

description: Aster is a cute restaurant with a very cozy vibe, but without a doubt, it is the food that will bring us back!  We dined with a vegetarian who had several choices on the four course menu and they all sounded delicious!  The three of us tried to order different dishes so we could sample the fare and nothing disappointed!  We genuinely appreciate artistry in food and Aster hits the mark.  Our waiter was friendly and knowledgable, but not at all pretentious.  The price point made the experience a real value for a Michelin starred meal (which in our experience usually jacks up the $$), so we want to give the owners a shout-out for keeping it real.
author: Jody T.

description: Aster is by far one of the best restaurants in San Francisco right now. I've been here for dinner and brunch multiple times and the quality, price, atmosphere, food, and wine choices are excellent. The quality of their chefs is up to an international standard and their taste in wine is among the best in the city. The staff is nice, welcoming, attentive, but not intrusive. Highly recommend Aster.
author: Angel P.

description: Excellent selection and execution - nice atmosphere - not too quiet but quiet enough to be able to hear others at your table - all the food was perfection and attentive service - and the price was quite reasonable ($60 for 4 courses) - loved the lamb 3 ways - and the sourdough bread
author: Jeff H.

description: Overall the food is 3.5 stars and the ambiance/service is lucky to get 1 star.  My boyfriend and I came up to the city for Valentine's Day and were disappointed from the start- we arrived and were told they were having an issue turning tables and it would be a 15 minute wait.  We were finally sat 30 minutes past our reservation time without more than a cursory apology.  Once we sat down we were given a special Valentine's Day menu- this was not mentioned online, on the reservations page or when we confirmed the reservation over the phone.  This led to a dinner that was literally twice as expensive as planned and felt like a complete waste of money.  While we were looking forward to Aster I doubt we'll be back soon given the lack of respect for people's time.  If a reservation is made and there is a significant delay there should be a more significant gesture to make up for the inconvenience, especially on Valentine's Day.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Excellent food...Agree with Andrew's review that the potato dumplings were absolutely delicious. We had the vegetarian option and the lamb shoulder entrees, both of which were wonderful.  Wandered in without reservations on the opening night, and got seats at the communal table.  Lovely wine list.  Cannot wait to return!

Enjoyed that the tip was included...
author: Jeannie B.

description:
Great atmosphere, warm and inviting interior, attentive, yet unintrusive service. 

Definitely try the sourdough bread, a delicious homage to San Fancisco, I was wowed by the flavor. 

Pig head croquettes are a must have, and as a former vegetarian I am quite finicky about meat but they are brilliantly executed. 

New American cuisine is about local ingredients, the use of the whole animal, and getting away from industrialized agriculture. This concept is executed here with a touch of finesse and creativity, and I cannot wait to return for more. 

Both wines I tried were delightful and they had a fairly large by the glass selection.

For the quality of the food and elegant ambiance I think the price is just right. Good luck to the owners and staff, I love seeing more quality places surfacing in SF.
author: Caitlin S.

description: Came in for the 4 course dinner with my date. We tried I think 7 dishes of which 5 were phenomenal, 1 okay, and 1 a bit disappointing. The wine pairings were very good. The service I don't think was Michelin worthy so they need to work on that otherwise it would have been a yelp 5 star experience.
author: Will D.

description: Excellent restaurant. I've been in San Francisco now one year and am going through a bucket list of restaurants to hit in town. I've been to about 40 right now, and this is one of my top 3. Food was excellent, well presented and very tasty. Go with the four course meal and the wine tasting. You won't be disappointed.
author: Jeff R.

description: I would say the food was 5 star, but I experienced below 1 star service. I and my four girl friends went to Aster for celebrating my friend's birthday on Saturday. We spent about $500 for dinner. If I spend $500 dinner, I will expect descent treatment from the restaurant crew. We are all foodies who go to different restaurants very frequently. Funny thing is a wait person for our table provided us an excellent service, but I experienced horrible attitude from a manager of the restaurant. We ordered a bunch of appetizers, four main dishes, and two bottles of wine to start. A partial appetizers came out pretty fast, so we were enjoying wine and food together, and a lady(we didn't know she was a manger at that time) brought out the second last appetizer. Our side plates had already been used for other appetizers, so we asked her if she could bring us extra small side plates. Then she pointed out the side plate that we were alread using on the table, and said this is the small plate you should use, why do you need extra plates for? She asked us twice the reason why we needed to have extra plates, so we had to explain that it was because the side plates had already been used for a few appetizers, so we just want to clean plates. I thought she was already being really rude at that point, but she countinued to show her rudeness. She put down the dish that she was holding while we were asking for extra plates and gave us the name of dish and a brief description. However, we noticed that it wasn't what we had ordered, so we told her politely that we didn't order the dish. Her face expression was like she was so annoyed by us as if we ordered the dish but we were claiming that we didn't order. Without saying any word, she just snatched the wrong dish and walked away. We were pretty bothered by her attitude, but I didn't want to make a scene at that point because we were celebrating birthday. However, I don't think she should have reacted the way she did on Saturday when we didn't demand any kind of unreasonable request to her or to the restaurant. I'm so surprised that a so called 'high-end restaurant' that obtained Michelin star provides such an unpleasant experience to its customer.
author: Julie P.

description:
* They no longer have the 'price includes gratuity' policy*

This place rocks. I love every dish we tried - they were thoughtful, creative and awesomely executed.
The ambience also was really great, I loved what they did with the space. It felt much bigger with some smart decor they did.
I would not hesitate to recommend this place.

This place truly deserves 5 stars on normal circumstances.. but I have to say a few things about the service we received.

Upon walking into the place, I knew it was very crowded and understaffed. But a place with those price tags should've figured the service part out by now.
Our waiter was a very nice guy - he was knowledgeable and friendly. But he forgot to refill our water, asked us which dessert we wanted without giving us the dessert menu, and.. forgot to inform us about the change in the gratuity policy which led us to going back to the restaurant and asking another waiter if it was okay, then only to be told our waiter forgot to mention it.

I hope they figure this out soon cuz I think it's already a rock star place! But some people WILL turn away or never return for reasons like this.

Thank you, Aster!
author: Sung C.

description:
What a great surprise. The food was very sophisticated but not in a pretentious kind of way. Very tasty and interesting. LOVED the desserts. Definitely a good date spot. Was a little more formal than I expected, which is nice in San Francisco, where most places seems to very casual.

Will definitely go back!
author: David V.

description: Outstanding meal!  Tasting menu was an excellent value and allowed for a full sampling of the menu.  Service was attentive without being obnoxious.
author: Jonathan M.

description: Perfect. Ensue for a romantic dinner or a special occasion. The food is superb as well as the service. Prefer their dinners to brunches
author: hasan a.

description: Very average food. Flavorless. Expensive. I wouldn't go there again. It's over hyped food like a lot of places in SF.
author: neha c.

description: Had a wonderful dinner here, and opted for the tasting menu. Thoroughly enjoyed the selections but hoped for slightly more adventurous flavors. We will definitely give this place another try.
author: Patrick F.

description:
There is a lot to love about Aster.

Its unassuming interior (photography does not do it justice), well-chosen playlist at the right volume (just loud enough to complement intimate conversation or mask awkward silences), and very thoughtful, tasty, and well-presented food.

My husband and I went for the 4-course menu (a steal at $59). I had beets (on a bed of cultured cream and pistachio), potato dumplings, black cod, and cheese (contralto); while he had spring greens, potato dumplings, spiced duck, and chocolate tart. The beets were really really fresh and tasty - toasted pistatchios added a lovely texture. The potato dumplings with hint of comte and caramelisation were warm and hearty - although I felt like there was too much happening on the plate with added maitake, brussels, rye crumbs, and dill. I think they could have shown a little restraint, but it was nevertheless a good dish. The cod came in a gentle broth (charred allium - but tasted more like a dashi), and was just what I needed on a rainy evening. The star of the evening however, was the duck - perfectly pink and seasoned. I would return just to have the duck again (and again). The tart was served with caramel ice-cream and dark chocolate shortbread crumbs - to die for. 

Service was attentive but never stuffy. Each course was well-timed so we didn't have to wait long between dishes; but also didn't feel rushed. 

What I love most about Aster is its authenticity. Everything about the place felt honest- tableware, ingredients, service, retro green wallpaper. Will definitely be back!
author: Eugenie Y.

description: Great service and food. We finally tried Aster and it did not disappoint. The menu is fantastic. We opted for the four course fixed menu and it was amazing. They plated our food at the same time and discussed the flavors that made up the dish. The space (used to be Beast & the Hare) looked so big. I was very impressed with our experience and look forward to dining again.
author: Analise T.

description:
2 stars, not because the food was bad, but it wasn't at all memorable for the price. 
Between 2 of us, we had the bread - $5 for 4 pieces of bread with butter....
Started with the Halibut and Duck Liver Mousse 
Both of these were OK, not a lot of Mousse underneath the pretty presentation but was mostly tasty. Halibut wasn't anything new.

Next we had the soft cooked egg and rabbit meatballs.
The soft cooked egg dish was nice, I'm curious what type of egg they found that was so small.
The rabbit meatballs were a disappointment to me, they lacked any real flavor I thought. 

Last dishes were the pork shoulder and milk-fed lamb.
I liked the lamb, and the fixings that came with it. 
The pork shoulder was nice too, but once again didn't stand out really.

We had a glass of wine each, and the meal came to $180 after a 20% tip.
Service was average for SF, cooks bringing out plates, promptly asking if we needed more wine. Slower to refill out water. Nice descriptions of the food as it was brought out.

Nothing was bad or wrong with our food or service, but also nothing stood out as memorable.
Other restaurants in SF stand out much more at this price point.
author: Jon B.

description: Brand new restaurant that's definitely going to take off! Fantastic vibe, great service, outstanding food! Must must get dessert. We had the Bert and blood orange deliciousness, and I really don't have enough words to describe it! Potato dumplings were delicious, croquettes were great, smoked trout was perfect. Will definitely come back! Bonus points: this place takes Cover! Download the app!!
author: Alma A.

description:
Aster was this month's restaurant of our Dinner Club -- probably my least favorite of the 8 places we've been to*

As other reviewers have noted, the price doesn't match what you get -- and we went knowing it was a little pricey. But usually something makes up for that: out of this world food, amazing service, beautiful decor. Maybe it was our uptight server -- he didn't get us & we didn't get him. By the 4th bottle of wine, he finally got us ...

The food was A-OK (hence three stars) but nothing really stood out and it certainly wasn't worth the price. It's New California cuisine -- but nothing was surprisingly harmonious or deliciously daring. It was a strange bunch of mish-mash, a few dots of this & that. The most flavorful dish we got was the green garlic soup. And yes, we finally ordered the $5 bread -- mostly to satiate our hunger, which wasn't going to be satisfied by the meager portions of food and tiny dots of flavor.

Maybe it was because my best experience had been at the most recently attended Central Kitchen, where everything was flawless, so Aster greatly paled in comparison. Or maybe they haven't found their voice yet. Our hostess was really nice and the other servers seemed to do better with their tables. 

The one highlight is they let us linger for a long time and drink our wine....


* (1601 Bar & Kitchen http://www.yelp.com/biz/1601-bar-and-kitchen-san-francisco; Seven Hills http://www.yelp.com/biz/seven-hills-san-francisco; Kin Khao http://www.yelp.com/biz/kin-khao-san-francisco-2; Beso http://www.yelp.com/biz/beso-bistronomia-san-francisco-4; Prubechu http://www.yelp.com/biz/prubechu-san-francisco; Stones Throw http://www.yelp.com/biz/stones-throw-san-francisco-2; Central Kitchen http://www.yelp.com/biz/central-kitchen-san-francisco).
author: Yasi S.

description: There are lots of nice restaurants in San Francisco, and good food and good service is what sets the really fine ones apart.  I was extremely disappointed by the both the service and the food here.  When we sat down for our 6:15 reservation, the entire communal table was open.  The sun happened to be be right in  our eyes where they seated us.  I asked if we could move over one spot (as the entire table was empty).  Our server had to check with a bunch of folks until someone finally came over and said, we were able to move.  We had the four courses, the salad was AMAZING!   The appetizer was okay and the main course was bland.  I asked for hot sauce and was notified that "the chef does not like the flavors of the dishes changed".  I asked for chili flakes and was also denied.  To me, this is poor customer service and arrogance/ego.  An evening out is meant to be enjoyed and lighthearted. This place was arrogant and stressful to diner.  Unfortunately, we had to go down the street and get a slice of pizza later in the night as neither of us really enjoyed the food (other than the salad and dessert).  I would not eat here again when there are so many other great restaurants in SF, full of flavor and minus the arrogance.
author: Lily K.

description: This was a fantastic dinner. Came here on a work celebration and everything from the wine recommendation to the four course meal was wonderful. Not to mention the service was phenomenal. George our server even folded the napkin when my colleague went to the restroom and gave her five choices for full bodied wines until she chose her favorite. Thank you to a great celebration and look forward to coming back here again soon. Cheers!
author: Melissa H.

description: A chef from Toronto recommended this restaurant to us THANKFULLY! It was a true dining experience not to be forgotten. The vibe is classy cool! Is that a vibe? The menu always changing based on seasonal ingredients. I'm still dreaming about the halibut appetizer and the lemon custard dessert.
author: Kelley W.

description: Ate here for the first time last night and I will be back.  The heirloom, fig and fennel salad was to die for.  The potato dumplings were cooked just right.  Pillowy and light.  Lobster mushroom was savory.  Wine list is lovely.  Not tons of choices but definitely the right ones for the food.  The service was great.  Professional and friendly. Loved it.
author: Cyn S.

description:
I think between all four of us we had everything on the menu. It was astounding, so beautiful and balanced. We shared bites and I tried them all, loving every morsel. 
I think we also need to talk about the lighting because it's pretty special. You just have to see it, but the reflection makes it feel like you are sitting outside under strings of lights. 
I was with my kids and I think it's good to note that they were really comfortable at Aster. Thanks for a perfect evening.
author: Kara E.

description: I was brought here by surprise for the first time and didn't realize Aster just received a Michelin star two months ago, so I didn't have any expectations. Every dish was really good, and service was attentive and what you would expect for a Michelin starred restaurant. There are a lot of modern-designed Californian restaurants in San Francisco, but I felt Aster was a tad better than most all-around and would recommend trying it for sure.
author: Michael N.

description:
inventive, fresh, casual
service was prompt and cordial
i enjoyed the radish appetizer and another with liver mousse.
beautiful plating.
author: Marie r.

description:
We ate here just a few weeks after they opened, which can always be a risky decision.  Considering that they were so new, it was an excellent experience, and we look forward to visiting again.

The service was great.  Our server was knowledgeable and down to earth. She also didn't skip a beat when we didn't like the first glass of wine.  She replaced it without a fuss and without making us feel bad. Big plus.

We had a kale salad which was delicious and the potato and pepper dumplings, which were also delicious.  The wine wasn't outstanding, but it was good enough.

It was nearly fully booked while we were there and had a nice atmosphere and buzz, but it was still quiet enough that we could have conversation. We appreciated this.

Gratuity is included.  Entrees seemed reasonably priced despite this, at $29 - $34.  The place where they get you is on things like sides ($8.00 for broccoli) and bread ($5.00), but it was a good experience and we will return, especially since it will probably be even better in the coming months once they fully get going.  Definitely recommended.
author: K. B.

description:
This place left me wondering how it managed to get a Michelin star,I wanted to like it but actually wound up kind of hating it, and this is why:
There were 5 people in our party and we were seated in a booth which was too small to accommodate more than 4 comfortably, we lucked out and got the side with only 2 of us but the other side of the table had a lot of fighting for elbow space, even though one of the people on that side is a little 91 year old lady no taller than 5ft.
I didn't mind the choosing 4 things from the menu concept but found it weird that everyone at the table had to choose that option also. I also found the menu to be very vegetarian heavy, especially considering the prices.
The first thing that really annoyed me was the bread, it was decent but there was not enough butter for the amount, but the thing that really chapped my ass was that there were 5 of us, as we've already covered earlier, and they gave us 4 pieces of bread,  I find that incredibly chintzy, come on people it's bread and you're probably marking it up 70%, put on an extra bloody slice.
Service was INCREDIBLY slow, almost 3 hours for 4 courses, too long for a Tuesday night supper.
I found the menu to be a little off, seasonally speaking, it was mid October and I was still seeing things like Early Girl tomatoes, summer squash and blackberries on the menu.
Most of the food we ordered was alright, but portions were small and no ones socks were being blown off, and there were definitely a number of fails, notably the kabocha squash second course dish was very strange and none of the flavors on the plate meshed. My mother in laws pork entree was also a miss,the pork  tasted bitter and overly salty, I suspect because of the brining liquid.
I ordered the duck which was cooked well but everything else on the plate was freezing cold, including the actual plate. I sent it back to the kitchen and when I got it back 5 minutes later it had been replated sloppily and the garnishes were still very cold and unfortunately by this point so was the duck. Epic fail.
I'm glad I ordered the cheese plate for my dessert course as it was the best option, between us we tried all the offerings and we found all of them to be subpar, my cheese was good but the cracker it was served with was stale.
As I already mentioned it's a real head scratcher to me how this place has been given a Michelin star, maybe we were there on a bad night but a restaurant of this supposed caliber shouldn't really have those...
Will not be back.
author: Leal L.

description:
Had some friends from out of town for the holiday weekend and this restaurant was on several "Hot restaurant" lists, so decided on Aster.

Called to make a reservation a week in advance, got a table at a reasonable time. Good.

Night of the dinner, we are seated right away. The server seems somewhat knowledgeable of the menu and wine list, but had to go an ask someone else on a few occasions, when we asked a harder one like...this glass of Riesling for $42, how much is the bottle...ten minutes later that bottle is $150. Okay, so we order a bottle of Pinot for the same price. Oh and there are only THREE cocktails on the menu, which is why we went with wine. So if you are a cocktails person, do not attempt to come here.

The menu itself is pretty limited. It is designed for four courses. I don't count the $5 bread and butter as a course. Each person is recommended to order one from each section. Pricing per plate per section per person runs about $20. Times four, you do the math.

I ordered the halibut appetizer, garlic soup and potato dumplings as my main dish. Originally I wanted the trout, but then the server mumbled something about they only had three fish left and it might not be fresh....hmm not fresh seafood no thanks! I decided not to risk it and went vegetarian. 

The halibut was delicious. Presentation was very nice. When they bring out each course, someone comes by and tells you what's in it, the sauce, etc. The soup was alright, not too garlicky as promised. The potatoes were not good. Oily and hard to chew. 

We ordered four different desserts to share, and boy, was that the worst! First, the menu does not describe the desserts correctly and second, they all came out too salty and sweet. Especially the frozen chocolate. 

Even though the staff, appetizer and wine were okay...everything else did not meet standards...so it is unlikely I will be coming back.
author: Grace L.

description:
Really enjoyed Aster. Service was excellent and friendly, not pretentious.
4 course tasting menu with wine pairings was great.
Greens with avocado and seeds at the bottom were delicious. Soft cooked egg dish with roe was amazing, and so was the pork belly item included the pork dish. Basil chocolate desert was very good, but strong basil taste is nit for everyone. Strawberry parfait with oil drizzle was surprisingly refreshing and delicious; I would go back just for that and the fresh sourdough bread that everyone loves.
author: ej l.

description: Terribly average. I ate the scallops (too much going on in one plate), potato dumplings (excellent), pork shoulder (bad) and chocolate ganache (good, but overly dense/gelatinous ganache and mediocre presentation keep this dish from being great). I don't understand the raves this place is getting. I chalk it up as yet another overhyped SF restaurant that is disappointing.
author: Sumier P.

description: Decor is really interesting with mirrors lining the ceiling edge that make the place appear larger.  Service is really attentive, however it was almost too attentive as one of the plates was taken away before we were finished.   Food was hit and miss.
author: Paul C.

description: Amazing food and a great atmosphere. Brett Cooper and his team are putting out amazing plates that hit your taste buds in all the right places! Super well balanced in both flavors and textures. Bread and house made butter are 100% worth the $5. It was so good I had to order it twice in one night. Looking forward to coming back to Aster every time I'm in the city.
author: Hannah H.

description: The place looks really nice. I did not like any of the desserts but everything else was great, including the wine list.
author: Marco K.

description: I didn't dine with Aster, but I did send a special request for 2 good friends who were dining with them. They were very helpful and accommodating. Great Staff.
author: Gia C.

description: Really excellent four course tasting menu for $59. Multi layered flavors and textures and a perfectly filling overall meal. A great overall dat night. The only criticism is that the wine pairing pours were a little light.
author: Andi T.

description:
Sloooow service took 45 minutes per course. Overpriced even at $55 for a four course meal - which I know is dirt cheap for the city. But:

Halibut:nice presentation, but bland
Duck liver mousse: more like pudding with shredded lettuce
Soft-poached egg: too salty
Potato dumpling: like gnocchi, as advertised, but pasty. 
Main course and dessert - it's been two hours and I'm still waiting.
author: M V.

description:
WONDERFUL!  Have been there twice.  Food is just what you would expect from a 1-Michelin star restaurant.   A neighborhood gem and also a destination restaurant.  Service is also stellar.
The trout was the best I have ever had. I have all 3 of their desserts and I could not pick a favorite as they were all so good.  Everything was plated beautifully and served with love.  They make their own bread and butter. Although I too balked at the $5.00 price, it was well worth it.  The prix fixe menu is really worth every penny.  I can't wait to go back to see thier
next menu.
author: Helen S.

description:
Very nice effort from a group with high expectations. Was initially a bit annoyed to be seated at the communal table with a reservation, but the seats are well-spaced and it doesn't feel cramped. The new decor is attractive, including the ceiling lighting.

Everything we tried -- cold-smoked trout, asparagus with ham hocks, potato dumplings, lamb shoulder, and two desserts -- was well-prepared, nicely presented, and delicious. Seasonal vegetables were fresh and perfectly cooked. 

The service is still working out some kinks, but glad we got in here before it becomes impossibly packed -- as it certainly will. That will bring it up to 5 stars. 

Maybe a bit gratuitously expensive, as are many new San Francisco places (do they really need to charge for bread and butter?), but I really appreciate the service-included policy and hope it catches on. Overall, glad to have this in my neighborhood!
author: Liz H.

description:
Aster is a restaurant where presentation truly matters, and the details are not only considered, but celebrated. After only four months in, they seem to have settled into the neighborhood quite well-- the place was bustling with patrons on a Thursday evening.

The key is indulging in their four course meal for $59/person, and bring at least four people. If you wanted to, you could all easily taste the entire menu. My group, due to various dining restrictions, ordered without the intention of much sharing and still enjoyed four courses. The first course are cold, salad-type entrees. I had the Cucumber served with blackberry, avocado cream and coriander flowers. Others found the coriander overpowering, but I thought it was a complex flavor on top of fresh cucumber. Next came their black pepper dumplings-- which our waitress informed was something they were known for. This was my favorite savory bite of the night-- the spice of the pepper was calmed by the yogurt and peas served along it. My main course was the farro, served with sungold tomatoes and topped with crispy kale. The great thing about Aster is the servers take the time to explain every dish, proving that they studied and know the menu well. She informed me to eat from the center, as there was an herb sauce that made each bite brighter.
